A dense, organic, dazzling and funny tapestry, making use of varied and subtly colored animation and stop-motion; candid video; playfully verbose direct address; chapters and footnotes and doodles; and suavely chosen music and sonic bridges.
An advocacy film better suited for a class than for a cinema.
It is surprisingly boring to watch a movie being made, on the set or off, and a beleaguered production is not necessarily an exception.
Beginning as a psychiatric freak show, "6 Souls" eventually trades serial-killer intimations for backwoods bad mojo before becoming just another dimly lighted pop-up-stalker flick.
A snappily edited, archivally wallpapered recollection of fearless behavior in the face of an antsy establishment. But it's equally significant as a pointed act of retelling.
As heartening as it is to see a slum child tutored about vicious cycles of adversity and using the buzzword "partnership" with aplomb, the film comes to feel cut and dried.
It would take a firmer hand to right this "Wrong."

In a film plunked somewhat unfortunately between the inspirational and the ordinary, the impressively patient Mr. Conde voices public-service-announcement sentiments about being able to do as much as anyone else.
movie_title: You Don't Need Feet to Dance (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This trifle about two soldiers who sneak away to America while on leave unfolds in a world about as realistic as a flashback on a sitcom.

A well-sourced account of a perfect, broken dream, Drew DeNicola and Olivia Mori's slightly shaggy documentary captures what it's like to discover music so good it seems as if it were made just for you.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its cultural detail and fetching leads this Jamaican director's colorful debut feature is undone by ragged scene construction, weak acting and a scattered script.
The film mixes emotional accounts by proud survivors from two families with foreign-language re-enactments that are perhaps too faithfully murky.
Their story can feel almost too ready-made for the telling, but it's well worth a listen.
The filmmakers behind "Elemental" might have done better to commit to a single portrait and been more fearless about avoiding familiar oratory, but small steps are progress too.
Set in modern-day Kazakhstan, where the quiet is broken only by brutishness, this classically shot and edited film is a spare yet entrancing tale drawn with precise strokes.
By not centering on the victims, Mr. Khalfoun nearly makes the film about pitying the panic-prone killer; the camerawork lacks the ominous, confident glide of much Steadicam horror.
It's more convincing than many films pegged to specific causes. But its ambitions are also head-clutchingly broad ...
movie_title: Creating Freedom: The Lottery of Birth (2013)

movie_review_blurb: At once loose and dense, Ms. Endo's treatment wilts somewhat when drawn out to feature length, though it's a nice place to visit.
Scahill's voiceover has a grim relentlessness that ties everything together, while maintaining the pretense that the viewer is at his side as he makes his discoveries.
Yet from the get-go an ambient unease has been built into the film's thoughtful cutting and framing, more Antonioni than Haneke.
Bulgarian cinema has, for many years, been close to nonexistent, but Christov and Todorov's fervid fictions might just start to fill the void.
With a rich sense of lived experience, Potter first portrays the blithe excitement and sense of joyful conspiracy shared by the two friends.
For all its faults, "We Steal Secrets" reminds us that despite the potential of WikiLeaks, its project of truth and consequences remains treacherous and complicated in practice.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Motivation is the weak link here, with characters major and minor making choices that don't compute and/or serve mainly to advance the narrative down the next twist of track toward the tragedy looming on the horizon.
Let the Fire Burn outshines the lackluster likes of Our Nixon by combining the death-trip of a Senna with the radical history of Black Power Mixtape.

A gently wry sense of humor about human foibles and some well-turned exchanges keep the proceedings drifting along pleasantly enough, until characters start convening for the requisite heart-to-hearts and making-up.
Mostly you root for Mr. Michel's couple to reconnect simply so the movie will come to an end.
Mr. Strickland's movie becomes a bit of a vortex at the beginning, though its milieu is too engagingly recreated to dismiss.
Less a documentary than an experimental essay tapping age-old notions of the sublime, it's a perplexing artifact that flirts with the banal yet moves with lovely intuitive rhythms.

Whether stuffing its graceless hero into a clown suit on a construction site or sending him on a first date with an offbeat neighbor to give a safe-sex talk at a home for the elderly, the film is funny only on paper, if that.
Neither the very relaxed pace of this builder, Chris Overing, nor Mr. Stone's sporadically amusing neuroses about his filmmaking make for a gripping documentary.
The image of a plane in a holding pattern feels all too apt for the film's conceits and characters, which never quite land.
If the lineup is bipartisan, the analysis oscillates between apt and obvious, culminating inevitably in amen calls for popular action.
Seamlessly fashioned from television news footage, public hearings and other sources, the movie relives an incredible chapter in American history.
The way the movie strikes its chosen couple of notes resoundingly, making clear what makes Singh run.
It'd be a mistake to be scared off by the subject matter, so often a vehicle for moralism: suburban teenagers hang out around town, go to parties, hook up, are annoying or sweet.
In his 19th feature, Mr. Barreto assuredly embraces an approach that's counter to much received wisdom about Bishop's life and work. But his film ultimately dooms itself.
The movie is not always well unified and sequenced, but that seems to reflect Mr. Henin's ambivalence over a past that's like a book he is at once rereading and rewriting.
movie_title: Couleur de peau: Miel (Approved for Adoption) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "The Wind Rises," with its complex diminuendo, underlines Mr. Miyazaki's much longer, richly creative odyssey.
For Ustaoglu's young leads at least, there's more to come: each, after portraying a lifetime's worth of grief, turned 20 last year.
He speaks the truth much of the time, yet all the whipping back of the curtain ends up covering up other realities about movies and life.
This heart-wrenching and deceptively conventional documentary manages the tensions in its subject and in the vérité approach in a fruitful, illuminating and surprisingly moving way.
The filmmakers record the flash of youth's headlong energies, its bumps and bruises, and its melancholies and brilliant chaos.
Mr. Chou taps into something profound about the dream life of a nation ...
The directors, Shasta Grenier and Sabrina Lee, delicately find moments of openness in casual, lapidary interviews with five men at different points in recovery.
This dully structured film makes its points early and often, treading water before a purposely delayed big finish.
Blithely hokey, amusingly eager to distract and rather entertaining, the film resembles a children's travel show with music-video elements more than it resembles a straight-up documentary.
It's a mix of brash celebration and sexual-wilderness heartbreak.
Lifted by the sepulchral Stephen McHattie as Lisa's nemesis, the film's frazzled thought experiment becomes an adequate yarn.
The fuzziness of Mr. Avitabile's sentiments on boundary-blind unity is echoed in the movie's slack, tag-along portraiture.
Akin to a children's novel (the sort where the shadow of death fuzzily looms), About Time turns into a successfully sentimental family film in the literal sense of the term.
But what lifts this studio comedy, Stiller's fifth feature as director, is its sincere ambivalence about fulfillment in the age of iPhones and image saturation.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In a classic case of filmmakers prioritizing their own pitch over the actual goods, Ariel Schulman and Henry Joost put Schulman's toothy-grinned brother Nev front and center as he investigates his fishy long-distance Facebook crush.
The orchestration wobbles now and again, but Ms. Wallach has fashioned a multifaceted, informative portrait conveying the emotional urgency of the Kabakovs' work.
movie_title: Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Might have been better off in a kid's-size portion as a short.
"47 Ronin" can't entirely paper over the void at its center, traceable partly to the shadowboxing of computer-aided filmmaking or studio tinkering.
With a character who can essentially say and do whatever she wants, you might expect a bit more.
Like a dismaying coming-of-age movie in which little is learned beyond the fickle chemistry between dreams and business.
More reminiscent of public television than of cinema, this rather humbly wrought movie makes no claim to being comprehensive in recalling a scary time.
movie_title: All The Way Through The Evening (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Desultory, dauntingly DIY but secretly efficient, "Breakfast With Curtis" is something like a leafy summer afternoon in movie form.
Ms. Hanna and her message of empowerment are disappointingly translated very nearly into a cult of personality in this film's idolizing portrayal.
There's a slightly nasty twist to some of the violence, with an air of school shooter menace ultimately creeping in as the group's tormentor is revealed.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A messy collision of strained portrayals, semi-comic incidents and tear-jerking tactics.
The film feels like a work of community advocacy.
Over all, "Die Narbe," scored with music-as-wallpaper by F. M. Einheit, comes across as more of an extravagant gesture than a fully realized artistic conceit.
At one point, someone marvels at Calvin's sheer "lust for life," and while Mr. Schroeder, no doubt, has a parallel fascination with his favorite comic strip, the film doesn't follow through.
Even if some of the crudeness and the drama feel forced, it's hard to hate.
Shot handheld and mostly confined to the apartment, the film is (despite some mild food tourism) a delightful feat
The Duel drops us into a pool of languid provincial life ( ... ) Kosashvili gets the delicate falling ending of short fiction that is so hard to achieve on screen.

its most emotionally raw moments are indicative of their military subjects' exceptional comfort level with their observers ( ... ) the arid yet woody outcroppings high above the valley are an intriguing new terrain
Relates the weak-tea parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.

The movie gratifyingly observes the openness that seems the base line for Philipp and Walter, and the glimmer of realization in a stage actor about the void that may lurk among his many liberating roles.
"The Institute" stumbles between documentary and exploratory simulation, at once confusing and pedantic.
This static documentary portrait relies on the usual panning over photos and tag-team interviews, but the format, like the radio length of a song, doesn't get in the way of its subject's heart.
Mr. Eenhoorn (whose patient expressions here suggest a kindly priest) gives his character the shy charm of palpable decency.
The film's stacked stories naggingly lack a cohesive train of thought beyond the often harmful pervasiveness of pharmaceuticals in American society.

Though not terribly nuanced, a bit muddled and lacking certain perspectives, "Zipper" drives home the fragile identity of even the city's signature locales and the alarming cultural myopia of much redevelopment ...
movie_title: ZIPPER: Coney Island's Last Wild Ride (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Some low-budget manifestations of the supernatural jazz up the frights now and again, but as the novelty of worshiping a hole in the ground fades, the film paints itself into a corner.
"Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer" could be slicker, but it does its part in sharing in its central figure's project of recording the living history that surrounds us.
Mr. Ponsoldt ably charts a journey through the high stakes of adolescence, with both Sutter and Mr. Teller showing great promise.
The insider's level of detail that gives so many good crime movies their bite is also what makes the documentary "Smash and Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers" guiltily absorbing.
movie_title: Smash & Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Neandertal is a valley in Germany. That meager fact is a spoiler for "Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man," because there is virtually nothing else of value to be gained from watching this film.
movie_title: Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As "Terraferma" tightens its focus on a courageous resolution of tough issues, too much nuance is jettisoned along the way.
Cars careen, lazily written infiltration plans are executed, and the violence is plentiful and toothless.
An urban drama limited by its nonprofessional cast and impressionistic, scattered storytelling.
The film's final shot might seem a little too apt a summary of an audience's reaction: Mr. Trêpa, looking into the camera, shrugs.

Romanian-born ex-painter Negulesco aims for sophistication with Hitchcockian banter between rivals -- Lorre and perennially suspicious Sydney Greenstreet -- and a crafty Wellesian figure of hearsay in Dimitrios.
The actual events already serve as a parable of race in America, but Coogler's dramatization does them justice.
All too many music documentaries send you away feeling unsatisfied, but with its heartfelt backstory and generous helpings of music, Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me is a shining exception.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: All these encomiums grow wearying to watch. But you could do worse than this introduction to an inspiring artist and farsighted patriot.
"The Trials of Muhammad Ali" succumbs to the looming danger of hero worship by its end, when Mr. Ali's daughter appears and his continuing trial, Parkinson's, is addressed.
"Dark Tourist" takes an effectively unpleasant trip down the lost highway of a morbid mind before its bad choices start catching up with it.

This directorial debut by Liz W. Garcia, a writer for television, bears some echoes of its creator's origins, going from deft to trite in its drama and setting up character arcs that feel sappily resolved within its feature length.
This reserved, tragicomic story of existential flight across Argentina is defined by its shifting, literary voice-over about the textured, wide-screen expanses crossed by its protagonist.
movie_title: The Dead Man and Being Happy (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Reich ties together his talking points with a reasonable-sounding analysis and an unassuming warmth sometimes absent from documentaries charting America's economic woes.

What little we learn of Pascal, who has worked in Switzerland as a shepherd for more than 30 years, and Carole, who is a former dietitian, fits in a scene or two, but their practical journey yields a certain contemplative equanimity.
Though heavy with interviews that can be shallow, the movie provides an angle on a country remaking itself after Taliban rule.
Predictability and clichés get in the way of comedy here, especially with a lead character who rarely comes across as more than blandly sweet.
A reserved, très simple tale that raises the occasional smile and tummy rumble but keeps hiccuping because of the drawn-out parallel story about her subsequent tour of duty.
Seriously, if not always elegantly, the film portrays the great Ip Man as someone trying to survive, which is to say just as often a victim as a victor.
Ms. Passon ultimately seems to skirt some of the larger life questions hinted at along the way.
On a cuteness scale -- where 10 is a fuzzy kitten yawning in a hammock -- the chattily uninhibited 7- and 8-year-old golfers of The Short Game score high.
With their love of their craft and their respect for other talents, these bighearted musicians make for a warmly gratifying film to watch.
If his methods don't come off smoothly, Mr. Meltzer's conclusion does leave you feeling that even the whole story would be cold comfort for those involved.
As we watch hosts and announcers talk away on the air, the movie begins to feel like a series of communications between the speakers-and unseen millions.

Forsaking the chatter of his risibly exposition-heavy MARGIN CALL (11), and one-upping LIFE OF PI by stripping things down to the bare minimum, Chandor charts an admirably uncompromising if curiously aloof course into nothingness.
A film that, amid cinema's hit parade of violent but curiously instantaneous deaths, reminds us what it means to bear witness to the very end.
"American Milkshake" merrily bumps along as if it were the first movie to find humor in a white kid's idolizing desire to "be black," whatever that may mean to him.
Mr. Meyer adheres to a cinema of broad experience by casting rugged but uninspiring nonprofessionals and focusing on the rebels' long, lonely struggle rather than on triumph and tactics.

It's the latest of Mr. Berliner's dogged investigations into identity and family, and his strongest work yet, elevated by the presence of another artist in Mr. Honig, playfully insightful and eloquent even as his powers wane.
This tedious chronicle has the interest level of a home movie of a vacation with bickering and yammering left intact.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Ice (2013)

movie_review_blurb: What might have played well as a multipage Poe rumination gradually gets pulled to bits by thudding Ricci-Neeson face-offs in the poster-ready funeral-prep chamber.
This promisingly tragic tale is sunk by cartloads of context and an overbearing, slanted narration.

Say what you will, but the lead actors in Argentine director Juan José Campanella's latest film do have lovely (or at least handsomely shot) peepers. But the secrets you ultimately find therein are hilarious.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Bundles together prizewinners and other notables from the most recent edition of the festival in Park City, Utah.
Audiences expecting a blissout of swirling galaxies will wonder why so much time is spent on astronauts sweating over screws and bolts.
Everything zips by our eyes, thanks to the director's penchant for editing together footage of mutilated corpses and tense gunfire way too snappily.
A wispy story of revelation that's blessed with gorgeously photographed Southern discomfort, and beset by on-the-nose dialogue and awkward time-shifting.
Neither the investigation nor the suspense (hobbled by editorializing) have much impact; the movie, necessarily shot in Thailand, plays like secret-history tourism.
What actually happens is less important than the barest glimmers of that old Polanski magic.
Like a good after-dinner story, the film's charm comes from casual storytelling, enhanced by gently barbed interviews with Aebi's family and ex-wife.
Cedergren is a little too bland, but that works with Hansen's air of haplessness and sets him apart from the colorful locals.
Though he's ready with easy charm, [Withers'] sensibly jaded edge makes things interesting (both tendencies may be reactions to stuttering since childhood).
The bleakness and resignation running through the film can be gut-wrenching.
Though Ryan Samul's textured cinematography makes the stubble and shadows seem nearly 3-D, the story chokes on a dull twist from Rosow's past.
An explicitly antiwar conclusion unwisely makes the grim focus feel like a bias, but the power of the interviews makes one wish for more stories, not fewer.
By faithfully documenting Ruppert's long-simmering analysis, Smith lets us experience the feeling of a world gone to pot, whether or not the claims are factually accurate.
The writing by director Hans-Christian Schmid and Bernd Lange is more stilted and righteous than even the U.N. environs, with its humanity-embracing procedural-speak, calls for.
Kim's filmmaking is generally cartoonish in a bad sense, as he squanders his set pieces, flashbacks, and other attention-getting with sometimes downright wretched staging.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Backed by an eclectic soundtrack, Crocker's 2009 doc traces the hubbub around the decades-departed ivory-billed woodpecker, purportedly rediscovered near Brinkley, Arkansas.
The latest Cinema Purgatorio release is really a scary story told in the dark, in the get-this whisper of documentary.
The film's frustrating treatment is actually more like the local reporter who is shown struggling to stay in the loop.
A refreshing alternative to many fictional representations of large nations weathering cataclysmic changes.

Doubling as cinematographer, Dereck Joubert skillfully integrates slow-motion and creates a rich sense of space with godlike long shots.
The big-kid-bulky Dayton-born comedian gets some welcome playtime in Jim Pasternak's patchwork tribute, but not nearly enough.
Despite eccentric touches, like a handheld street-shot overture and Grand Guignol Omen references, there's little difference between this story and soap-opera intrigue.
It's hard to appreciate things like the character detail amid the insufferably squealy voicing and arbitrary suspense.
The ultimate break comes with a glorious full-screen CGI zoom into blazing heavenly bodies, a refutation of the title's modesty.
Requiring cuts, some sense of direction, and dialogue that doesn't either declare or dither, the film looks like it was fun to make.
Wang's letter from Beijing feels too breezy and light on fresh insight.
For all the unvarnished coastal beauty and hypnotism in routine, there are stretches when the experience (of duration, of observation, of landscape art) can feel like, well, a bit of a chore.
Õunpuu's orchestrations and barbed surprises, which greatly depend on cinematographer Mart Taniel (and various Estonian theater vets), hold continued promise.

movie_review_blurb: A fine-grained picture of stasis, both on the street and in the faces of lifers shuffling into gin mills and flophouses.
Mesrine's promised end in November 1979 arrives as history recorded it, but, by that time, you're hoping the next vogue in biopics is the short film.

Since the filmmaker's main agenda here is to keep things bumping along, the fraught situations are happily played and funk-scored as crowd-pleasing rather than issue-stroking.
Those jumps between missions are confusing, but the in-field kvetching and no-holds-barred shots of wounds make this a vivid dispatch from the frontlines.
movie_title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Lomborg sounds like an infomercial huckster, down to the vow to have money for "all the remaining problems of the world" thanks to his low, low price for managing global warming.

For all the pretenses of roiling or suffocated desires, the cast appears to have been ordered to deaden all sensation (except for Basinger, who frets away in an underwritten part).
The film is pleasingly meandering, till the more typically Majidian soulful and teary-eyed climax.
The military junta that ensued in Greece gave the film a sense of urgency approved by Cannes and Oscar alike.
The spectacle of two dudes mucking about in the primal forest becomes tedious...
movie_title: Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Bumpy transitions and organization, along with New Age composer Kitaro's temperamental soundtrack, prevent a sense of polish, but this Japanese-produced doc, which includes Reagan's 1988 reparations, testifies with dignity and restraint.
In a sense, Phillips's mission is a variation on the tradition of semi-orchestrated socially conscious documentary that stretches back through Lionel Rogosin's On the Bowery and beyond.
movie_title: Great Speeches from a Dying World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The asexual, adopt-a-fogey impulse is a well-established one, but Simon's oldster act, glasses a-perched and dawning comprehension at the ready, is mannered and tiresome.
Bertelsen's puffy sheepishness isn't involving enough to distract from the routine plot perforations.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We're not talking the Dardennes brothers here, but fellow Belgian Christophe Van Rompaey gives this light May-to-December pair-up an agreeably mussed, pedestrian milieu.

Despite the totalitarian drumbeating and the Constitution love, the movie feels strangely ahistorical and lacks real systemic analysis.

The production makes the most of shoestring means, however, with many a candlelit colloquy, though the apparent background reading in Lowlife and New York by Gas-Light is more alluded to than illustrated.
Rather than present a clichéd fall from grace, Truffaut elicits ambivalence by closely tracking the Enlightened scientist's optimism; after the fascination, our inchoate sadness seeps in.

Between the hordes of stowaway rats that accompany Dracula's arrival, and a town-plaza dance of folly by doomed survivors (a Herzog addition), it's like being present at the birth of a medieval legend.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

It's usually a dangerous sign when a director casting about for an idea gets fascinated by twins.

movie_review_blurb: The resulting experience could very easily be described as off-putting -- which well suits the uneasiness of the subject.
movie_title: Babi buta yang ingin terbang (Blind Pig Who Wants to Fly) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film comes to feel curiously incomplete, like one long fretful afternoon.

The performance excerpts, starting with the head-clearing invocational introduction, are by far the most interesting part of the show.

movie_review_blurb: While the portrayal of collaboration is respectable, and the balloon enchanting as it shimmers skyward, jellyfish-like, the doc is too flat for its own good.
True escapism this summer is to be found with the Page family in Philip Trevelyan's 1970 steam-engine idyll-doc.
Without proselytizing, what's left in this machetes-to-ploughshares tale is, unexpectedly, a powerfully Christian film.
The sensory disorientation climaxes in a freakout that wipes all your troubles away, as well as anything else lying around in your head.
The repetitive material hobbles the actor's energies.
The heavy mood of indolence and rage, calibrated with ellipses in action, is stifling -- everyone seems to move in a queasy haze.

Through graph-wielding scientists, picturesque seascapes and Ted Danson's voiceover, director Rupert Murray lays out the facts about the ongoing decimation of world fishing stocks, which could mean the end of tuna as we know it.
No one would confuse the movie with a short-story collection. But it's more ambitious and effective at blunting cynicism than most consciousness-raising efforts.

Fusing together documentary footage and tense dramatization, Wakamatsu has produced the kind of heterogeneous cinematic object that doesn't usually get released in the U.S. unless it takes place in the Thai jungle.
The resulting object is less about the world than about itself, and feels like a hey-that's-neat 90-minute troll through the video-sharing website.
"Orchestra of Exiles" aspires to a level of primary research that other historical documentaries could take a page from.
Doing yoga proves more appealing than watching a film promote it.
Ms. Letourneur's film ... bears a rare, even strange, stamp of authenticity.
The film is most illuminating in showing how democratic practice can still find a new voice and innovative means with each generation.
movie_title: We Are Legion: The Story of the Hacktivists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Thoreauvian self-sufficiency or classical pastoral engagement with nature and its creatures takes a back seat to the company of objects, trees and music.
Even political foes agree here on today's parlous state of disagreement, leaving you keen to vote but feeling a little defeated already.

A relatively respectable slice of high school outsider storytelling.
Like the two characters, the film has trouble finding purchase, which yields a more acute feeling of dissatisfaction than was probably intended.
Mr. Collins's treatment, though jam packed, leaves one itching to understand more about the bigger picture and the political and social connections involved.
Zhao's film faithfully rotates among these indifferently acted representatives of contemporary China but still feels halfhearted.
A hokey story with a needless reality-show overlay.

Mr. Magierski patches together the storytelling, delivered at home and during a visit to Poland, rather clumsily. His general effort to take the children's naïve point of view has amateurish and cutesy results.
Following the efforts of a South African housing rights group, the documentary "Dear Mandela" illustrates how fresh injustices have succeeded the inequality once enforced by apartheid.

movie_review_blurb: The sort of self-impressed tedious effort that many thought had died with the post-Tarantino imitations of the 1990s.
Sometimes a movie is so awful that you worry you are doing yourself some form of harm simply by watching it.
Vonicos ... misses an opportunity to make a feature-length documentary that takes the full measure of his subject's work.
Gradually becomes an echo chamber of personal dramas and exploits, not to mention propulsive soundtrack cues - all within a sport already nursing a penchant for self-documentation.
[It] is about the familiar more than it is about the forbidden.
A typically eye-catching, years-in-the-making chronicle of animal life that is tainted by the urge to anthropomorphize.
As soon as "The Berlin File" takes flight with its exhilarating action set pieces, memories of any muddles evaporate amid the tension and vivid engagement with settings, from courtyards to fields.
