"How come we never heard of him?" you cry. Deep mystery. But it develops an unexpected power in the final reels, when skeletons fairly rattle out of cupboards.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Paradoxes, riddles, exchanges; apocalypses of the mind and heart. This tender, funny, constantly surprising film is the debut of the year.
The bigger the scene, as melodrama intensifies in this movie, the more its truth-based tale turns into grand guignol on the griddle.
A Mexican thriller-with- a-message, brings the message and forgets the thrills.

Sombre and moving in early scenes, and shot with a penumbral grace, the film doesn't quite go the dramatic distance. By final reel, insightful humanity has been replaced by inter-ethnic parable and socio-political point-scoring.
More well-aimed wit was needed, less grapeshot wackiness.

A worse film might be dismissed as sobsploitation. But Stephen Walker's documentary - a labour of love inspired by Walker's first sight of the group in a London West End show - touches the mind as well as the heart.
A transcendentally batty essay in am-dram costume cinema, starchy with recitative, fragrant with period fabric conditioner and white with laundered emotionalism.
The Women has a cast to die for - Meg Ryan, Annette Bening, Candice Bergen, Carrie Fisher - in a film that dies before our eyes.
The curse of modern Brazilian cinema, it increasingly seems, is that every film reminds us of City of God while none measures up to it.
Hunt's lovely voice, pitched in that diurnal-dizzy limbo between mezzo and soprano, is perfect for mid-life crisis. So is her gawky, strung-out, tragicomical body language.
The Hollywood comedy Tropic Thunder comes at us like a mad army cresting a hill, intent on audience massacre. My advice: shoot first and don't wait for the whites of their eyes.

Scratchy? But why not? Scratchy sounds human. In Unrelated we almost hear the charcoal on the paper as the group portrait takes shape, filled with unknown actors helping to cross-hatch their own characters.
The eerie haze of the visuals, the half-babble of music and the toneless, teasing dialogue dance attendance on the strangest ghost of all: Galina Vishnevskaya.
As a mood-piece the film sits on a pedestal, rather, waiting to be admired.
The movie goes nowhere and takes 100 minutes to do so. It should have cut its losses, gone for comedy and called itself Grumpy Old Cops.
Taken is batty but briskly paced.
The Mamet rhythms are pleasingly in place: the repetition-rich dialogue, the head-butting close-ups as men go ego to ego.
Hayseed nonsense, folksily scripted. Whenever it becomes too much - or too little - close your eyes and think of Frank Capra.
Lovely if you have the time. But if you have the time you may, I feel, be living in the wrong time.
In spite of a title, and much dialogue, likely to send Aunt Edna into convulsions, Good Dick is the week's best film.

The Austrian miserablist who gave us Dog Days - sharper and more mischievous in its portrait of exurbia's human excreta - delivers an essay in symmetrical despondence that seems both tidy and empty, like a trash can after street-cleaning.
They should have called it Carry on Columnist and incorporated digitised cameos from the late Sid James and Kenneth Williams. Come to think of it, that might have made it funny.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The style is monochrome and minimalist: dots and dashes, sudden shadows and scary silhouettes, like a morse code of the unconscious.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The remorseless, glamourless scenes - their businesslike realism, their shrugging fatalism, their workaday brutality - come closer than most films to identifying and depicting the "banality of evil".

Some credit for this stylish screamer goes to Sutherland, forming his doughy-handsome features into an emotional punchbag. More credit goes to Nemec, sowing a harvest of dark invention in the vast spaces.
When the ridiculous and the sublime come within kissing distance like this, you know that, script or no script, Hollywood has found a way to have a wonderful time.
But wait. Didn't screwball farce go out 70 years ago? Around the time of Harry Cohn? Aren't we watching necromancy in action? Yes, yes and yes.
The film is untidy, cheery, sometimes amiable. If only it were funny too.
The theoretically fail-safe team of the writer/actor Seth Rogen and co-writer/ producer Judd Apatow - the Knocked Up duo - deliver a funnybone- clobbering spree with more energy than wit.
The plot's twists and turns are less to the point, or less to be prized, than the whey-faced humour, the solid humanity, the feel for the epiphanic in the everyday.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A laboured romp.
Hannah Takes the Stairs, the latest comedy of mannerisms in the "mumblecore" style, is maddening for 60 of its 83 minutes.
The platitude-intensive script by Robert Siegel would have been laughed off the screen without Rourke's dogged grandeur.
A Christmas Tale is a compelling domestic drama, a French art gem to inaugurate 2009.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film remains dour, truthful, grimly droll.
Seven Pounds compounds the schmaltz in a tale of goody-goody benefaction and glutinous redemption, whose plot the distributors mercifully injunct us from revealing.
Add Penn's uncannily three-dimensional performance, his best yet, and Milk is a masterclass on how a political biopic can become rich, humane, encompassing cinema.

Director Ron Howard, less an artist of film like Van Sant, more a resourceful pro, lays his cloak down for the miraculous script and makes sure everyone can walk with dry feet towards the awards ceremonies.

Valkyrie seems more like history by Nintendo: a slickly devised exercise in action drama whose entire research and development budget went into the external details of the plot, leaving none for the inner realism of its participants.

The film, like the shindig, ends up dissolving in a schmaltzy brew of make-do-and-mend, complete with a sari-clad wedding accompanied by multi-ethnic music, whose PC touchy-feeliness one hopes is a joke but fears is not.
Hopkins has a singularity of style worth watching and the courage not to flinch in putting it on screen.
Winslet gives Revolutionary Road its depth and heft. That face still gazes at us, with its seraphic blend of beauty and horror, minutes, even hours, after we have left the theatre.
A touching and acerbic Japanese drama.
Witty in bits, noisy in others.
Tinny teens dragged through mirth-free misadventures one New York night.
A Babel cast in a piece of free-associative gothic babble.
It often catches the Fitzgerald mood of elegy and might-have-been: that subtle rapture of remembrance that can make us prize the lost past or future over the gift-wrapped immediacies of the present.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The erotic roundelays are so witty - Marivaux with sex - that I am now afraid to see a future Allen film. It will either be bad, returning us to the natural order of things, or good like this, demanding a rethink of the universe.

The dialogue is vitamin-rich. "Where's your compassion, Sister?" appeals Hoffman. "Nowhere you can reach it," ripostes Streep. The actress shows so much culinary art in her line-readings that an Oscar nomination seems less appropriate than a Michelin star
Could Bolt 3D be better animated? No. Could it be funnier? A bit. Did it need the 3D? Not really.
We get too little Sid here - not a smidgeon of his great rendering of "My way" - and too many partial "witnesses" who insist Sid couldn't have done the crime.
Game, set and match. We barely see the ball pass us before it hits the baseline, but Gran Torino has proved itself another effortless Eastwood Grand Slam victory.
A stirring story ends up being lost in a stir of clichés and designer desultoriness.
Gags crash, timings tailspin, and celebrity guest stars (Bruce Willis, Sean Penn) wear the look that says, "I think we've come to the wrong party."
Neither film wins a prize for visual style. Each deserves one for clever gags and zanily zig-zagging dialogue.

Don't worry about suspending disbelief: for an hour or so Boyle will do it for you. The film's visual panache is strong enough to ambush doubters, whose scepticism will stumble into hidden nets and be hoisted high into the firmament.
Demi Moore will do as the ghost of Hollywood past, rattling her jewelled accessories like a drag-queen Jacob Marley.
Weaver's still unresolved grief, subtly hits every note that Changeling plinked or plonked like a honky-tonk hokum artist.
Steams ahead with express-train determination, scooping on to its cow-catcher any cinemagoer hoping he can outrun yet another true-life drama about black sportsmen overcoming bygone bigotry.
Unfortunately the Cassevetes-style film needed Cassavetes to make it. Zonca, essaying a pell-mell verismo, produces something resembling Gloria mugged by A Woman Under the Influence.
But this cop, played with wicked finesse by Jackson while the script allows, deserves the chance to strut his hour in the smoke-free sun.
It is not so much a wig, more a man-eating bird's nest. And not just an actor becomes lost beneath it but an entire film.
A god-awful chick flick about black women bonding in a sugary, never-never South. It should be renamed How to Make an American Wilt (and any other viewer).
Later, unfortunately, the film's energy drains like the waters, leaving a wrack of tired folk wisdoms and ear-injuring rap songs.

Much is wrong in Philip Stölzl's film. But in this column you don't get the highest recommendation for perfection (if there is such a thing). You get it for touching greatness. You get it for haling the heart out of a viewer.
You will find the film either desperately depressing or perversely hypnotic. Or you might find it both simultaneously.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Riklis seems never to have heard the words "Meir" or "Thatcher". Nor, in a film parlaying its message in a series of humdrum tableaux naïfs, the word "cinematic".

In Dean Spanley Peter O'Toole, luminous of eye and loopy of intonation, acts as if he should be locked up. You have to admire the cut of his lunacy. He brings what little style there is to this winsome tale adapted from Lord Dunsany.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is sexual-Gothic tripe of a high order. I am looking forward to the second instalment.
Thompson must be looking down, or up, from his afterworld thinking: "The worst success is a failure to keep alive the spirit of offendedness and outrage."
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film is full of charm, wit and pictorial panache.
It is pretty ghastly. I left after Act Two, at which point the opera descends into the terminally maudlin.

The still, sad music of humanity - surely that should have been The Reader's score. We hear it in Winslet's performance at least, at once contained and tremendous, at once filigree in touch and fully wrought in thought and being.
Che is a heroic guerrilla project in its way. It's just that these guerrillas get lost in a mist of opaque purpose and ill-defined movie mission.
The photography is a knockout. All Australia needed was a script with a sustained story and a stronger sense of where, and how, tragic drama should take over from camp seriocomedy.
In Bedtime Stories Adam Sandler gives his most bearable performance yet.

Yes Man founders on a weak script and the rock of Carrey's alarmingly subdued shtick. What has happened to the man who used to combine the verbal surrealism of James Joyce with the body movements of St Vitus?
The wonderful Jane Lynch (40-Year-Old Virgin) steals each of her scenes as the charity project leader, a reformed cokehead singing from the right-on community care hymnsheet.
Bitterly funny, uproariously sad, irresistibly human.

The film is breathless, big-canvased and scored for big emotions: a pavilion of the heart and senses threatened only when characters open a flap to let in anachronistic dialogue or the giveaways of cross-culture casting.

The film's flimsy fabric of historical reimagining - a death camp with no watchtower and an out-of-sight corner for illicit pow-wows and tunnel-digging - makes the notionally harrowing ending seem a smash-and-grab raid on our susceptibilities.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Don't think of it as film. Think of it as a series of paintings that talk to each other, raptly and quietly.
I am against the exploitation of women for sentimental screen purposes (Steel Magnolias, Crimes of the Heart). But what can you do? Here they moon and croon across a time divide.
Kenneth Branagh is in danger of becoming the next Kenneth Branagh, in a career of serial self-replication as our last unstoppable screen Shakespearean.
I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry is a comedy of masquerade that Shakespeare might have written if he were pea-brained and talentless and had been commissioned to script an Adam Sandler movie.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A neat metaphysical thriller.
The film ends, as it begins and largely unfolds, in a blaze of affectlessness. This is anomie as art.
The film is sweet, simplified and a bit syrupy on the soundtrack.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The whirring sound you hear is that of Neil Simon, screenwriter of the 1972 film on which this is louchely based, spinning in his retirement.
Macho lunacy.
If Raymond Carver had ever filed a last story collection from the Sunny Valley Lobotomy Clinic, it would be just like this.

Purveys huge charm, enough to make you fall in love with the rat species and enough, with its array of screen dishes, to make America forgive France, re-dub freedom fries as French fries, and fall sobbing on the country's cordon bleu shoulders.
But satire and emotional drama do not mix. When we giggle at the selfish enormities of this family's lifestyle, we cannot be expected to weep for Johansson's lonely hearted childminder.
Ruzowitsky's film, austerely shot and scripted with terse wit, grants itself a licence to make art in exchange for entertaining us with a gripping story.
Good, camp fun.
Kevin Costner as a schizophrenic serial killer? Demi Moore as a hardboiled police detective? No, we don't think so.
Zodiac is that marvel and rarity, an adult Hollywood murder thriller.
A dream movie.
Lame exercise in proscenium dialectics.
Sweet human comedy.
Dire and dunderheaded.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Peters out in mass murder and visual gross-out.
This blend of girlie action flick with retro car-chase movie scores nought out of 10 for artistic expression but four for amiable delinquency.
Length does not add substance to the drama, even where reality adds weight to the argument.
The film opts to depict a single but reverberant tragedy and does so with force, skill and a memorable central performance.
The story came from Get Carter's source author, English crime writer Ted Lewis, but the venomous sophistication and serpentine inner logic are French.

It's the triumph of this documentary that we feel, after learning so much about a game-changed yet weirdly unchangeable street messiah, who we're told still lives in his demi-hovel, that there is more to learn yet.

A series that was in danger of becoming an adventure playground for digital trickery - "not another miraculous monster or flying thingummybob", we protest - exhibits, for once, a strong plot with a satirical edge.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A two-dimensional landscape.
A picture of cultural displacement and Anglo-Indian rapprochement almost worthy of EM Forster.
A long-distance trek with refreshment breaks.
Don't expect a family-business masterpiece
Beyond Heaven's help.
You need a hard stomach sometimes in American romcoms. Equally, though, you'd need a hard heart not to love the good humour, good intentions and grace-of-style of Adrienne Shelly's farewell film.
The Walker seems the work of a straight movie artist trying to "do" gay. There is no reality humanising the caricatural extremes.
A happy 85 minutes, although it might have been a teensy bit happier, banishing all hint of repetition, at 75.
When not hyperkinetic, the film is stone-cold dull.
None but the mad will want to see Rush Hour 3.
The best French film of recent memory.
Very funny for an hour, Judd Apatow's script and direction are finally mugged by a gang worse than any of these. The feelgood moralists, who terrorise all parts of Tinseltown.

As the story self-destructs, we are left with the majestic scenery, photographed by John Toll, and the pleasure of two good actors from one side of the Atlantic stretching themselves to seem convincing on the other.
Scenery apart, the film is penitence at 24 frames per second.
Dominic Leyton's script from his play starts as a flicker of fancy words and ends as a verbose fireball consuming all reality.
New Zealand's Russell Crowe and Britain's Christian Bale, donning the hats and accents to play outlaw and escort with grizzled assurance.
The last act, which freewheels towards denouement like a driverless bus.
The film proves only that a Hollywood fixated on the slapstick potential of teenage growing pains is finding it harder than ever to say, "Bye, bye, American Pie".
The film is so fast it is over almost before it begins and so empty-headed it demands little but your inertia. On the way there are moments of weird charm, conjured by the movie's velocity.
Take along a good book - possibly Ted Lewis's The Serpent - and read it by the light of the effulgent clichés.
Eden Lake: pursuit, persecution, violent death.
The bloodiest 12A (UK) rating in memory.
Spare an evening, if you feel adventurous.
movie_title: I Don't Want to Sleep Alone (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The hero's iconic inertia is photographed against molten skies or Judgment Day sunsets, providing moments of mythic repose between the pell-mell battle scenes.
A script with terminal shortcomings - wincingly winsome, ferally fey - is negotiated by brave actors picking their way through the minefield.
Think of Saw and multiply it by Seven.
Nasty, brutish and at 89 minutes just the right length.

There is such a thing as binge pessimism. It happens when one living disaster area, considered insufficient in a story, is served up with several others, causing audience braincells to swirl, stagger and collide against thalamic lampposts.
The script and story are what matter. They are as neat and interlocked as nail scissors. They are also grimly funny.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Very unpleasant, though skilfully put together by director Gregory Hoblit and acted with beyond-the-call empathy by Ms Lane.
While other countries do state-of-the-art schadenfreude, we are stuck in the steam age. We feed coal into the engines of old-fashioned heist thrillers.
It is delicious for 30 minutes. Then the plot starts.
If this epistolary documentary - voiced aloud with pictures to the photographer/film-maker's favourite pup and co-canines - meandered any more than it does, it could be arrested for vagrancy.
Lots of bruised humour, quiet virtuosity - watch for the slow-motion montage of disaster - and doggy-eyed optimism.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Funny in fits and starts, though the fits are a little convulsive and the starts seldom come with a convincing ending or pay-off.
A plot dug out of the serial-killer deep freeze.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lucy Walker's documentary Blindsight is breathtaking twice over. It leaves the audience gasping like a landed guppy at views of snow-coddled Himalayan peaks under ice-blue skies.
Elegy makes us question again the cinema's ability, without loss of heat and light, to translate Roth's subtle, high-voltage prose from page to screen.
Padilha's style, honed in his hijack documentary Bus 174, is verismo with a vengeance. For two hours the viewer feels as hand-held as the camera, hauled about by the neck.
There seems no other reason to tell this rambling, glutinous tale - other than for us to go "ooh, aah" at the scenery, the seasons and the melting-eyed close-ups of Reynard the heart-throb.
I start to think there should be a charity called Amnesia International, which compels forgetfulness in former hangers-out with Andy Warhol.
The film is about as funny as a 3am cold call, and if you are a critic you cannot slam down the phone before you have heard it out.
If Somers Town were any more unassuming, it would risk disappearing completely. Seventy-two minutes long, in black and white, with a cast as starless as a cloudy night, it is a British triumph.
It is magnificent eye candy. Forget the plot (which you will be hard-pressed to understand) and store in your memory for later use the dialogue's Zen Buddhist proverbs.
100 minutes of sweet-natured idiocy.
The film is full of fabrics and shimmer and embroiderings of light and colour, giving a slender story the shy blush of art.
Quietly mesmerising.
first-time feature director Francis Lawrence deserves an ovation for his scene-setting and early scare count.
Characters make love, make meals, make conversation - though not much - and in moments of transcendence remake the world according to their fantasies and longings.
A twittering soap opera about five Californian women using Jane as an agony aunt for their love problems.
Think Fatal Attraction gone French and gone wrong.

Affleck and Pitt have prime charge of the tale's humanity and vitality. The first has nervous headlamp eyes and a wheedling, accosting intensity: he is like a homeless pet you would feel sorry for up to the moment it bit you.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film is fresh, spectacular and unafraid to be called philistine.
How good to see gong-givers recognise that good acting can be covert, not overt, and that in the right artistic acoustic a performer doesn't need to shout to be heard.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It is beguilingly cuckoo, though as primitive visually as The Twilight Zone - it was shot in 22 days - and about as profound.
A strong wire netting will keep out unwanted super-soaps such as the first, in which a black family in LA proves that being Afro-American is no inoculation against outbreaks of schmaltz and piety.
An archly mirthless comedy.
Hypnotic, so real-yet-otherworldly, that the filmgoer has a virtual out-of-body experience.
Almost nothing remains at the end - not a glimmer of mystical inquisition, not a teasing loose-end of space-time speculation - to lure a Pullmanite towards a sequel.
Whether this is a demented B-movie or a comment on demented B-movies is hard to say. It is horribly fascinating, if not for the full 150 minutes.
Ben Kingsley brings a batty, basilisk wit to You Kill Me, a black comedy about a dipsomaniacal hitman.
They ought to send the whole of The Killing of John Lennon up in flames.
The best we can award is bee minus.
The comic possibilities, once floated, eventually capsize.
No wise child, let alone grown-up, will touch this with a turkey baster.
The script is dapper and the story slick. But it is Huppert who gives it heft, style and star power.
Offers little that Scorsese doesn't offer with more élan and wit.
One is unsure what the menu is meant to be in this satire/drama/melodrama.

The measured mise-en-scène is fine for the boyhood scenes. Character-building alternates with brief bursts of image music, such as the kite-flying contest that fills the Kabul sky with darting, colourful fabric-birds.
Transposed from a novel by Blake Nelson, the boy is played by newcomer Gabe Nevins with all the complexity and three-dimensionality of a magazine centrefold.
This film is stronger than the first. The pale, sepulchral tones give a ritualistic eeriness to the long pursuit scenes.

How could anyone not love Laurent Cantet's The Class (Entre les murs)? Last year's Golden Palm winner is the best film about schoolteaching I have seen: a wise, funny cry of helplessness before the tsunami of anarchy that can be school-age adolescence.
The action is often crass, the location-hopping mere crisis tourism. But the acting and dialogue deliver.
The film starts hopefully, drifts into the desert, ends up starved of point, pith and pattern.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A gangsta farrago, convincing neither as street-tough crime drama nor soul-motorised rap show. The performers go through the motions, and emotions, as if reading cue cards.
A film of subtle savagery and mordantly encompassing vision.
Roland Emmerich is an apocalypse chef. In 2012 he cooks America till it boils, adding live meat to the process at judicious intervals.

The youthful villain demographic, plus the prompts to our indignation, come straight from the UK tabloids. But before it spins into terminal hokum, Barber's feature debut has moments of power and menace.
The film is irresistibly human and funny, and properly momentous when calamity strikes.
Another bizarre, bewitching tale from those that make up life in, on and around the worldwide web.
A damp squib, thrown fizzling into the memory arena of the world's pioneer rock festival.
Paranormal Activity shows how little it takes for inventive filmmakers to do a lot.
When reality melts and major US cities become porous, we need some of the mad panache recently demonstrated by Roland Emmerich in 2012.
Moreau's stellar performance and the astral intensity of the paintings keep taking us where this story belongs, up into the skies.
A buddy-based road movie with fetching cut-out sets foregrounded by non-fetching cardboard characters.
Agay romantic comedy that earns 10 points for PC outreach work and one for wit.
An overzealous, sentimental kidcom.
Look at Mackay. Look at the handsome-pudgy features, listen to the rolling bass voice, appraise the twinkling eye, marvel at the offhand flourishes of the titanic frame. This is Welles.

A lot of stuff about Nasa, Mars exploration and amateur theatre - Sartre's Huis Clos and its glowing chestnut adages ("Hell is other people") - add to the film's richness or, depending on opinion, its overcooked confusion.
This is tragic inevitability at one mile per hour, extending into a slow, sunbaked danse macabre the drama's heartbreak and the guilt, anguish and wrath.
Keaton is good, McDonald with her spooky equanimity and still-waters profundity even better. Sartre's Huis Clos? Forget that. This is hell, as moodily atmospheric as low-budget screen infernos get.
Good fun if you can put up with the pastel colours and plasticky textures, which show that in modern fantasy animation all that pixellates isn't Pixar.

You have to take sides. Go see the film, go judge. Either this is plotless rubbish designed to inflame tabloid newspapers. Or it is the future of cinema, and Jarmusch has got there before the rest of us.

Shouldn't therapy, at least in art for or about childhood, be fun? The book was entrancing. The book deserved better. Happily there is still time, before the world ends, for someone else to film it. For now: return to Sendak.
Dickens purists can stay away. Others can feel free to sample the rollicking aerial views of Victorian London, the droll and scary elasticity of Carrey.
Human feeling dares to outstare, for a mini-moment, the world of accounting, commodification, ecstasy-management.
Shocking, enthralling, educative. It proves that falling in love with cinema can be, for some who pick it as a career, the most health-endangering thing of all.
Steadfastness, truth and a simple, blazing, incandescent humanity. This is a literary life story in which life, for once, is the meaningful word.
Potentially poignant stories are presented with the same caricatural brusqueness or dispassion as the stories of people who are plain stupid.
Bechis bequeaths us a landscape scattered with enigmas, jigsaw pieces for us to complete our own picture.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Revolution is always with us: this week's guerrilla documentary, watchable and well-researched, is Chevolution.
A sleek, if superfluous, remake.
The film continues in meal-monsoon mode for 90 minutes with scant variation.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The idea is misconceived, the execution gets closer and closer to the danger zone of embarrassment.
A loose-leaf diary in which the pages are shuffled by instinct, wit and surreal art.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Grave, heartfelt, medium-engrossing, it still feels like every resistance movie you have ever seen, rolled into a ball of historical revisionism.
The laughs rain down early on; later - Messiah moment apart - they thin to a drizzle, deprived of variation.
Action mayhem full of gibbering hominoids, hanging corpses and a few live stars.
Think of Shirley Valentine and take away charm, wit, realism and Pauline Collins.
Everything Up does with quiet, time-bestriding imagination is a triumph.
Frothy and forgettable, and, like any black comedy, funny even, or especially, when it shouldn't be.
An overdone blow-out of a modern fairy tale.
Once on course, he is uncontrollable. I don't mean the hero, I mean the director. Park's gallows wit and visual inventiveness keep us alert for an hour amid the ramshackle story structuring.
The film has about as much sense of structure as - well, as Thirst, but I laughed a fair bit.
Rackingly involving and, as corpses multiply, fearless of appearing penny-dreadful. Smith also made the loopy shocker Severance. This is becoming a body of work to watch.

Bruce McDonald directs a tiptop cast. Tony Burgess, scripting from his own novel, clearly saw the grand guignol potential in the computer virus, in the way great plagues can be planted in tiny units of understanding.
Mulligan has a sit-up-and-watch talent.
The tone elsewhere is too often hectoring and self-righteous: a team of salesmen exhorting us not to listen to salesmen.
There are no sharp instruments, just gentle barbs and pokes. Mungiu suggests that Romania under dictatorship was at worst a comically fearful bureaucracy.

The film becomes more bewitching the more it loses direction. Yi stops questioning strangers and starts questioning herself. She also interrogates the ability, or inability, of cinema to follow love into its deepest mazes.

Greek Pete proves what we had long suspected. Life imitates Mike Leigh films, at least in Britain. So do many aspiring filmmakers when trying to look with wit and forlorn truthfulness at the reality of Britain
The villains are mostly out of pantomime; much of the dialogue needs a stretcher; and the save-the-rainforest plot is a pain. Just take your eyes to the film. Leave all other faculties at home.

The script here is a pretext for fatuous action pyrotechnics, misfiring comedy, the inevitable star from Central Crumpet Casting and CG jiggery-pokery evoking Ye Olde London. In short: Doc, Sh'lock and Every Scraped Barrel.
De Niro alone is worth watching, even if one suspects the pain on his face comes from the script he must speak rather than the story he must enact.

The monotony is crowned by a predictable plot twist. Producer Luc Besson, maker of the similar but superior Nikita, conceived the original story. It should, like most of its characters, have been killed on sight.
You cannot believe the dreadfulness of Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland - gifted director takes on gaga script - until you see it. Enchantment has gone thataway.
I haven't had more fun since Eight Legged Freaks.
Kinky, captivating, even downright Continental: a Godard or Bertolucci plot given European-standard subtlety from Moore.
With any Jordan film there are a few moments of poetry, wit and transcendence. But you need a large net to catch them here.
This is mutt mush, pure and simple-minded, for those in the mood.
Competent, vivid and more than tokenistically controversial in theme.
This is a deadpan-rollicking film, helped by fizzy editing and funky visuals.
Since Scorsese is a stylist, the film is enjoyable. It would be more so if you could take out your brain and experience it only with eyes and ears.
The shlock-therapy emotional buttons are pushed one after another.

It is more stolid, more Swedish, but moves along cleverly. And there is a compelling incongruity - like Judge Brack trying to comprehend Hedda Gabler - in the plainness of Niels Arden Oplev's direction, contemplating the infinite wheels of human darkness.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The cons and the crimes misfire on screen.
The setting is a seaside caravan site where the acting and directing do not measure up to the script.
There cannot be many of these back-of-the-envelope-cutesy ideas for rom-coms left.
The pay-off is a little far-fetched, but by then we have had our emotional workout.
This film is both good and powerful. It saves the God debate, still intact, for another round. It is as magically, richly ambivalent as life itself.
Shows that America, for all its loudhailed Christianity, doesn't really need God at all. It just needs Sandra Bullock and her like.
We spend two hours ankle-deep in slapstick, magic and what the farmyard-repelled posh boy calls "poo."
There is a vertiginous sense that Freeman could, after all, have been a contender, if not in the Laughton weight class.
Ghobadi's yarn is loosely ravelled, but the songs are likable.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A film that has belaboured our funnybones for 100 minutes makes a charge for our tear ducts. Neither we nor the landmine victims deserved this facile flipping of agenda.
Bitty and frequently batty, Nine doesn't have the sultry cogency or louche mellifluousness of Chicago. But it will do for Christmas '09.
The film is good fun. Perhaps we have seen it all before, but you could say that of a sunrise. Every sunrise is different and Moore's are usually worth getting out of bed for.
Digitisation reigns - spectacular visual effects - while the dialogue drizzles and sploshes.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The late teenage years of John Lennon, put through the biopic wringer by screenwriter Matt Greenhalgh, come out as flat and lifeless as yesterday's "We Love the Beatles" T-shirt.
The questions are piquant, the answers droll and surprising.

The movie is a mite overstretched - how much florid anarchy can an audience take at one sitting? - but it makes last month's rock biopic, the Lennonographic Nowhere Boy, seem the essay in decorous torpor it was.
Even for me, a rock illiterate, this is interesting.
We come out humming the film's acting and production design, while wishing we could stop humming Nick Cave's music, which pulls out all the stops marked "Miserere mei (popcorn version)".
It's Complicated is another Streepshow, like Mamma Mia, that illustrates the power and willingness of Hollywood's best actress to slough inhibitions like Salome's veils.
Harrowing, unsparing, incensing and often, as an example of courage beyond the call, inspiring.
A brilliantly accomplished feat of self-contradiction. We have our cake, or candy box, and eat it.
Limpidly shot, translucently acted, Still Walking steals up on you quietly and stays with you forever.
Welcome to the new sub-genre: neo-gangsterism. Think of neoclassicism or neo-Nazism, then think of them both combined.

Few of these films ever take solid, substantive slices of truth or attestation from both sides. They are always partial, which vitiates the eagerness with which we would, if we could, espouse the cause of downtrodden.
Bad enough to be an end-of-genre movie... The script is a calamity, the direction worse.
This is a moral movie set in an immoral world, one of those circle-squaring feats at which French drama and cinema so darkly excel.
Like Cry Freedom without the laughs. Morgan Freeman plays Nelson Mandela in a pious, bromidic, wet-all-over film that slops from triumph to set-piece triumph.
The characters and story drive the comedy; the dialogue brings the nuanced grace notes.
Sci-fi digimation, whirling round the screen like the furniture in a drunkard's bedroom, whisks up the characters in its tornado.

The performances have a gruff splendour, the scenery is powerful. But Louguine lacks the talent, or Tarkovskian vision, to pack the screen with the kind of visual transcendentalism the story and dialogue peddle.
It's a back-of-the-envelope idea with a couple of good scenes. Ideally it needed another six months' story development.
Ford is good, even innovative, in those scenes where he near-subliminally varies colour, tone and texture from shot to shot, in subtle correspondence with the changing emotions.
Digital delirium makes up for lack of plot novelty.
Absurdly delightful, a prestidigitation of line and colour.
Your riddle of the week. Why is Valentine's Day like outer space? Because it's a big nothing filled with stars.
Once or twice - making it all worthwhile - an interviewee touchingly chokes up at his own memories, and brims with sudden tears.
A small Polish charmer that seems lost in the wake of time.
You never saw so much ducking and weaving, or heard such gasps of happy horror, outside a funfair.
Any film that boasts two jokes about Roland Barthes and one scene - surreal, deadpan, inspired - of superannuated cross-dressing will take its place, for some, near the front of the must-see queue.
It may have been a good stage play: people say it was. But its author, the late C.P. Taylor, was not around to stop it becoming a lousy film.
One wallow does not make a summer, but the combined forces of Ludwig's music and a chorus of celebrity erudition should help to take your mind off the April cacophony elsewhere.
This - Iannucci's large-screen lampoon on the corridors of power and PR - is a rabbit version of The Thick of It. It scurries about for two hours with bared but biteless teeth.
Ron Howard directs a pell-mell script (David Koepp, Akiva Goldman) with more agility than he showed in Code. Though the story suffers intermittent daftness.
The controlled romantic madness of Kaufman's best work becomes a world of symbolic and thematic promiscuity at once lifeless and inchoate. Too many ideas interbreed as wit goes to the wall.

The acting is as subtly, drolly bad as it needs to be. The hairpieces and cheesy background muzak compete for the honour of perfect finishing touch. At two hours Viva is a mite too long. But summer is here: give genius its leash.
Koppel's film transcends the pedagogic to touch the celebratory, the holistic, the mystical.
The best ladies' final to be seen this side of the French Open.
Skip the cop rot - it will damage your brain.
Sugar is dazzlingly free of message creep. We are perplexed, yet fully persuaded.
Last Chance Harvey is the week's six-hankie offering. Imagine Richard Curtis remaking An Affair to Remember: maudlin amiability is the game's name.
Time stands all but motionless. Wilby keeps plinking Träumerei on the Bechstein. And there is, no doubt, honey still for tea. Two stars for comfort, one star for originality.
French thriller Anything for Her has a livelier way with predictability.
Underscripted, under-energised, a triumph of formula over flair, it stomps on for two hours in a nightmare of self-important inconsequence.
Red Cliff gets everything right - sensationally right - except this one vital pulse of engagement.
Something conjured from the high, fey ethers of wish-fulfilment whimsy.

Are we allowed to love what we plan to kill and eat? Perhaps we are. Or perhaps it is the cunning sentimentality of the filmmaker, hooking the viewer in with heartwarming pictures before throwing him into the good-causes basket.
Daft but fun.
Nasty but sometimes effective.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Laugh? Well, at least, on a tough Tuesday in Tube-meltdown London, one chuckled.
Check out 17 Again, an age-swap comedy co-starring Matthew Perry, only if you have daughters who will kill for a sight of heartthrob Zac Efron.
Katyn is solidly, skilfully told. But away from these living-graveside scenes, Wajda's own artistic bones seem too well-upholstered at 83.
Run a mile in any direction from Dragonball Evolution.
Nothing new is said but everything said is shouted, as if to convince us that yesterday's headlines are still today's hot news.
It takes a quarter of the movie's duration to start detecting its drift, another quarter to start caring. The fantastications have a stronger wallop than the realism.
Like all great films noirs, this 1949 lovers-on-the-run thriller, directed by cultists' darling Joseph H. Lewis (The Big Combo), is lean, mean and delirious.
So what is missing? A little of the original's madness and a lot of its aesthetic high-wire walking.

The history is by Mills & Boon, the visuals are wall-to-wall frou-frou. Add the banality-packed dialogue ("Even a palace can be a prison") and some substandard mise-en-scène, and we feel like crying, "Call back Merchant Ivory!"

The scenes are shot in a clever range of styles, the dialogue is as sharp as a Stanley knife. The atmosphere in the cop shop, where the film closes in for the teased-out development before the recapitulation and surprise coda, is irresistibly seedy.
Sensible people will see the film for what it is: Waiting for Dogot without Beckett... But you cannot argue with dog lovers: they see in a vacuum of nothingness an existential nirvana.
It is medium-mesmerising, even if we are gnawed by secret shame at watching a glorified reality TV show.
Ole Christian Madsen directs with crisp conviction, however, and strong crescendi. And a truth-based story always helps.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Morgan, scanning the book and deciding (perhaps shrewdly) to lighten it up, has fashioned for Michael Sheen, the actor formerly known as Tony Blair and David Frost, his best comic role yet.

Like Raging Bull, like On the Waterfront, even like Woyzeck (the granddaddy of lumpenprole tragic drama), Toback's portrait asks us to ransack the human animal to see if there is a soul inside - and if so, of precisely what kind?
But good acting transcends motivational lesions. Before Phoenix, especially, and his raw, real, fumbling neediness we simply say "Yes, we believe".
Join up the dots in Michael Winterbottom's new film and you get the outline of a shaggy dog. But if Genova meanders, it has an ensorcelling, even zodiacal charm.
The slam-bang set pieces deliver. So, with his spooked features and breathy-orotund voice, does Cage.
Havana Marking's uproarious, awareness-raising documentary tells us more about the title country than a month of newscasts.
A woebegone crew of comedy turns worthy of a bad Carry On film.
The serious food for thought gets lost amid the one-stop snacking.
Progress has always been cruel, modernity murderous. But that brute reality doesn't mean we cannot pause, with Depardon, to mourn and commemorate.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If she doesn't quite go the distance - resonance needs richer characterisation, origami finer scissors - Cherry Blossoms is still a touching, tangibly personal chamber movie.
This Easter digimation romp is big on action and slapstick, small on charm, tiny on wit and endurability; unless you are nine, when anything goes.
The brilliantly eerie Let the Right One In is the European Angst Zone's answer to Hollywood's Twilight.
Writer-director Pablo Larraín keeps the uneasy laughter coming, and the nervous shocks, as light entertainment. Latin style has its darkest hour.
Run a mile in any direction from Fast and Furious.
By the film's end we feel we have had too much of a good thing - but since that is what the hero died of, it seems an appropriate sensation to leave us with.
The film obviously got a grant from Cool Aid, the endowment fund targeted at US filmmakers with nothing to say but a million airheaded ways to say it.
The digital effects are mind-boggling, assuming, after extensive pulverisation, that you have a mind left to boggle.

The film could be cleverer, funnier, better-timed. Où sont les Tatis d'antan? But Gordon and Abel - she an anorexic Tilda Swinton, he a slightly squashed version of John Gordon Sinclair (Gregory's Girl) - are appealing comic presences.
Will Ferrell capers earnestly through a Journey to the Center of the Earth-style comic romp witless of script, wan of invention and pasty of imagery.

Cassel's Jacques Mesrine is pieced together from gritty shards of believability, a street-real mosaic no one tries to smooth and polish. For that reason he and it have the sharp edges and septic menace of life.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There is an inertia born of ceaseless, stupefying animation.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the age of neurotic screen hygiene each film must have an anti-Messiah who takes on the dirt of all. Elsewhere, wit-free dialogue combines with dust-free scenery and foible-free characters.

The film, though brave, gonzo and often funny, raises the bar on the debate provoked by Michael Moore and Sacha Baron Cohen. How cruel does satire have to be - to innocent and guilty alike - to accomplish its missions?
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: That director Jaume Collet-Serra made House of Wax, the Paris Hilton remake, does not bode well. But stars Vera Farmiga and Peter Saarsgard, as mum and dad, find a few frail pegs of humanity to hang their characters on.
Everyone dallies and dithers and radiates well-meaningly. This is mental illness served up for romcom pathos and sentimentality.
[An] exquisite, coralled miniature.
The movie never quite determines if it is docudrama or melodrama, though each, at times, shines strongly.
Like two hours on the Burma railway, heaving away at time/space conundrums, arch-to-soppy dialogue and tail-chasing plotting under the lash of distributors who put us in a crowded, no-escape cinema.
The scenery is fabulous, the script less so, the final action sequences a headlong plunge into hokum and bathos.
Very winsome and very long.

Whirled around the floor of a story that goes absolutely nowhere, contains no human verities, has no significant heft as historical drama, yet still proves, now and then, an entertaining piece of Pop Disco Art from the cinema's most talented tease.
This is a major debut. A dystopic vision, yes; but in comparison with the usual school high-jinks from US cinema - fiercely fresh and corrosively memorable.

The handsomely grungy photography, the moments of grislier-than-usual violence and the producing participation of film-maker Fatih Akin fail to rescue this moody thug epic from being a cross-Channel cousin to the UK's mod gangster genre.
From whirling mini-UFOs to giant animated nose bogeys, the screen is never still and the script never smart or engaging.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film sweats out its truth from its central character.
Can Pedro Almodóvar make a bad film? The answer seems to be no, even when he might be accused of trying. Broken Embraces has a mazy plot in which a poor director would lose himself fast.
Sandler has gained dramatic weight and variety. But if I want to see him play Hamlet, I'd rather have Shakespeare as the scriptwriter.
All the world loves an outlaw. But how cheaply is that love won if all his partners and opponents have been drafted in from Dullsville-sur-Seine?
Maybe for today's computer-gaming sprogs, speed, violence and animation (in all senses) are enough.
Audrey Tautou is nice in the main role, if you like a face as pretty as a pain au raisin with an expression playing limited but appealing variants on waif-like ingratiation.
If you like Scott you can argue that too much is better than too little. This movie has a vision and sticks to it.
This combination of documentary of literary travelogue has no pretensions at all, merely a mad, endearing, Dickensian innocence.
Public Enemies is original because everyone, outlaw and enforcer, criminal and cop, looks and behaves the same.

Even the little boy in the second row, dragged along by a parent for a treat, was frozen in silence, victim of that cyclical ice age that affects audiences powerless to fend off the cryogenic effect of a sub-zero digimation romp.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Am I Black Enough for You is a brain-curdling essay in docu-sycophancy.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Embodiment of Evil is Brazilian torture porn, dragged from the dungeons of oblivion only because there is a summer "J" in the month and everyone is too hot or de-energised to resist.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A superb Cuban film from 1993, a little classic about gay freedom and its aspirations versus Fidel Castro and his Marxist straitjacketing.
Rudo and Cursi has enough vitality to transcend its air of formula.
A goodhearted, sometimes funny spoof of early human history.
The plot dithers and zigzags but only because human credibility, helped by excellent acting, has been allowed to prevail over Sundance-institutionalised designer whimsy.

By the end we are screaming to yank our engines away from the forecourt as fuel spills - all that piano music, that gilded lighting, those glycerine tears - threatening a pyre of sense, sensibility and supersensitive subject choice.
Cohen's new one-star show is appalling and funny and sometimes both simultaneously.
One of those issue-of-the-month co-productions by which Europe, between golden ages, makes a living.
A brittle, sometimes funny study in fragmentation.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ali motormouth footage left over from When We Were Kings. Actually, this whole film was made from WWWK leftovers, we learn. But we manage to forget that detail whenever the music soars.

Anders Ostergaard's documentary mixes a small amount of re-enactment - scenes of the Thai-based boss co-ordinating action by phone - with large amounts of scary, shocking or in some cases infamously celebrated footage.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Dear me, what a dull fight this has become. At points in Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince I feared slipping into a persistent vegetative state.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Bret Easton Ellis pens a mean tale, in all adjectival senses. His prose is artfully maleficent; he is a laid-back Severus Snape of the sex-and-drugs generation. You need a smarter directing hand, though, than Gregor Jordan's.
Early scenes have a raddled power. Later ones slip into a Chistmastide slush of contrivance and redemption.
Psychedelic sci-fi? Glam rock goes off-world? No: wordy and overwrought like a radio play in space.

Antichrist is a fairground ride through the brain of a genius, both nightmarish and apocalyptic. Trier's head is the most dangerous place in modern cinema, its multiple caverns mysteriously structured and weirdly laid out.
A dull, stiltedly scripted potter through re-warmed liberal indignation and heart-on-sleeve emotion.
Just Another Love Story, directed by Ole Bornedal, has a style like play-school Ingmar Bergman.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: So keen to be cute it curdles our stomachs and so anxious to be funny it jellifies our funny bones.

Ingrid Caven (ex-Fassbinder diva) turns kitchen-sink realism to kitsch and surrealism Europudding-style. Credits reveal that the film had German co-funding. Sometimes money talks and the language is Gobbledegook.
The dishes stream past our eyes and noses, exposing one of the film's two deficiencies. We need scratch'n'taste cards for all this, don't we?
The acting is good, the true-story imprimatur a help. The movie ends with clasped hands, brimming tears and inspirational music pedalling the end credits. I surrender. Pass me another hankie.
It is like delirium tremens, only less fun.

The movie grows into an epic in the Altman mode: a 163-minute celebration of the heightened ordinary, a dressed-down yet hopped-up Nashville, baring the lives and dreams of its characters as they bump or bang up against the everyday.
With mystical exposition and cod philosophising growing by the minute, our senses are gratefully rescued by flashy fits of special effects.
It's 'Tis Pity She's a Whore translated to a present-day world of trash wealth, fickle love and Damien Hirst terror mortis. And it's pretty damn good.
In its low-key lyricism with glimpses into the epiphanic, this is a beautifully controlled movie.

It's a by-the-cliché love-and-war romp anxious to invoke Casablanca yet directed with pastel-toned inertia, going on paralysis, by an ex-Roger Rabbit director who seems caught in the headlights of a new, if hardly challenging (you'd think), challenge.

There could be umpteen charges of kitsch, political incorrectness and mongrelised cultural history. Yet this South Seas hurricane of a film blows us away, scattering our faculties and effects and substituting its own.

Partiality is the heel in this Achilles film; though to this Achilles film's credit, it also outruns, as storytelling, the tortoise forebodings we might have had about a true-life plot so cerebral and cyber-centric.
Often it looks dingy and cheap. Speed of action ought to compensate. But when the action is standardised chases-through-space, turgid and repetitive, that doesn't compensate for anything.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Why Him? may be the funniest new film you'll see this or any other Christmas.
Once or twice Passengers seems like Antonioni in space -- no higher compliment.
Paterson finds its true nirvana when it sits still and becomes Jarmuschian.
Operation Chromite so bad it's almost spellbinding.
It's spectacular at best; watchable even at worst.
Aaron Brookner's documentary Uncle Howard has a lovely scraps-and-cuttings style.
Mostly the film's aesthetic -- post-ironic Bresson with tableau vivant stylings -- has a captivating, even kidnapping charm.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If this isn't the first work of a major filmmaker I'll eat my review. And I'll film it for you on YouTube.
I Am Not a Serial Killer is Dostoevsky in Minnesota. Spiritually if not literally.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's a rough and ready enchantment -- a magic of mood and landscape -- in the prizewinning Nepalese film The Black Hen.
Life, Animated, directed by Roger Ross Williams, is a touching documentary about autism.
Soapbox didacticism and complex drama can never coexist.
It's a mess. But it makes an impression. Chi-Raq has the force of topical-art inevitability. If it didn't exist, you feel, someone would have had to invent it.
The movie goes nowhere, you might adjudge by the end, if you're harsh. But it has a lot of informed and informative fun going nowhere.
It's a little winner.

The scenery and cinematography are eye-boggling. New Mexico is the go-to location for primal sunsets, majestically pillared cliffs and a light that leads to eternity. When your eyes stray to the battles and shoot-outs, they're pretty good too.
The Clan is a diabolical movie ride, at once compelling and repelling.
It's a pell-mell plot, wonderfully acted. Its human moments, of vulnerability, gauche tenderness and the first stings of fateful love, are as powerful as its hellish ones.
Thoughtful, moving, quietly powerful. For 90 minutes it's like a firecracker waiting to explode. Then comes the explosion.
For someone humming much the same tune from film to film, Linklater has an amazing versatility.
Most of this film is a joy. It's Plain Jane compared to some, but its deadpan wit and poker-faced comic naturalism come to seem the ideal to which all Austen cinema should aspire.

It's an amazing film. Life and death; mundanity and mortality; growing up and growing old; family and country; conflict and concord. Each is made more vivid, more complex, more intricately human, by its interaction with the other.
"Ye gods" is a line you're more likely to hear from the audience than from the screen in Gods of Egypt.
Garrone recognises the anarchy and delirium in the fairy-tale tradition, and that anarchy and delirium, properly orchestrated, can do us good.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The "so bad it's good" factor occasionally kicks in. But even with those ascents from base camp to high camp, this noisy, assaultive, stunt-oriented film leaves us clawing for the oxygen of human and dramatic interest.
The film is sometimes funny. It's a must for junkies of the TV series. But the script and story keep collapsing like the heroines.
The movie is either a sick dark joke or a multicoloured hoot, depending on your opinion. The only certainty: when in doubt Refn will have a character vomit up an eyeball.
It's a scary, discomfiting, clever film, hard to rid from your head once you've seen it.
When in doubt, clobber the audience with a special-effects mardi gras.
Five stars for good intentions; two for the path to cinematic platitude they pave.
There are few dud jokes, if any, in a script directed with vaudevillian verve by Andrew Stanton, the human pilot fish behind Nemo and Wall-E who also wrote Toy Stories one to three and Monsters, Inc.
The film's own bitter beauty is that the four characters, or character sets, are really one, and are really us. We're watching the ages of Every(wo)man.
Another day; another comic-book pandemonium.
Every character is booked through to hell or purgatory. But we gasp at the inventiveness, ferocity and cuckoo anarchy with which these rockers prepared their route to destruction or damnation.
Gulp your doubts and follow the imperilled girl into adversities that turn this summer shark dish, if not into Jaws, then into a twisting, biting, exciting loner-in-crisis drama.
Just feel the pell-mell editing - at its most bravura in a car chase along the Vegas Strip - and the weary grace that Matt Damon, 45, brings to his role.
Sharp-honed irony is mixed with assaultive power. The last of four sections is like a Shostakovich scherzo come to life: manic, martial, sarcastic.
If we must have works of comedy-drama fluff from this once great filmmaker - and these years it seems we must - they might as well ravish the senses.
This film teases and eludes. It's Continental drift. But few films so make us want to drift with them.
Did we need 150 minutes to watch slyly crafted revisionism turn to special-effects kitsch and rampage?
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The cast of social outcasts, immigrant victims and fitful Samaritans is very Dardennesque. Missing are the spark and sense of truth that make such components drama.
The glove drama grand guignol comes straight from grandma's kitchen -- hot-chestnut hokum, sizzling clichés.

In High-Rise the fitfully brilliant Briton Ben Wheatley, with writing partner Amy Jump, seizes what seems a perfect-fitting text -- JG Ballard's dystopian novel High-Rise -- and makes an omnishambles of it.
It works best whenever Goodman swaggers into frame, a slack-jawed psycho with a cuddly side.
The heavens keep splitting to deliver forked tinsel masquerading as sci-fi lightning.
The film's semblance of casualness is winning. It seems to make itself up as it goes along. But this fly on this wall has keen eyes, keen hearing, a keen intelligence.

There is so much food, music, dancing and crying that you want to come out, at the end, and find a quiet place to watch paint dry. Unless, of course, you loved MBFGW1 and have spent 14 years waiting for MBFGW2.
In this zero-sum drama, despair is catching. But so is the fascination of watching a gifted filmmaker dissect the emotions and motivations of the sinned and sinned-against.
This documentary holds every card in the pack, from geology to anthropology to the history of tribes and tyrants, and plays them like a master.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You don't want to see Rock the Kasbah. If you do, you're reading the wrong newspaper.
Sour Grapes is a tasty wine documentary with a hint of impertinence.
The songs are still great. The foursome's waggish chemistry is still a wonder. But there's a lot of old ground, even old grind.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Gibney's new cyber-war documentary brilliantly unpacks the story behind the Stuxnet virus, created by the CIA and US government to sabotage the Iran nuclear programme.
Adapted from Shūsaku Endō's acclaimed 1966 novel, the 161-minute story starts and ends with passionate ferocity.
Neeson and Felicity Jones (as mum) anchor, in emotional reality, the fable's life lessons about growing up.
The script makes variable sense, but so does life.
Up the pole, out to lunch and off the grid. It is mad, mannerist and unmanageable.
