A gross-out fright movie.

An inexperienced cast don't always make the most of a slippery, unsettling script by Al Wilson, but Amy Harvey's nuanced portrayal of tomboy Leanne - all braces and bolshie attitude up front, yet shy and vulnerable underneath - is a stand-out.
The magic ingredient here is Dan Schaffer's sly script, which constantly undercuts the film's inherently sexist premise.

Dennis Iliadis's remake retains its ferocious power and provocative themes, and thanks to a focused script that unfolds in real time, it ratchets up the suspense and sucks us into a remorseless cycle of violence and revenge.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'Shrooms' director Paddy Breathnach still hasn't the foggiest idea of how to make a horror.
This wickedly entertaining, if slightly over-stretched, variation on the familiar 'evil child' scenario displays an unusually complex grasp of twisted psychology.
David Twohy's taut, palm-sweating thriller has two things going for it: it keeps you guessing and it doesn't insult your intelligence.
A crude, crass, virtually laugh-free sex comedy.
A modern horror movie featuring a non-ironic shower scene is far less knowing than it pretends to be.
Love seems happier with his affectionate re-creation of the early '80s than with exploring the contradictions at the heart of this subculture.
John Frizzel's over-worked soundtrack keeps telling us how exciting everything is, but it feels as if we're frozen in time. Not so much a white-out as wipe-out.
'Franklyn' has conceptual boldness and visual imagination that set it apart from the pack.

'Oh God, now I've got brains spattered all over me,' exclaims The Punisher's slippery inside man, Detective Soap. You may feel the same at the end of this messy, sadistic reboot of the Marvel comic-book series.
The digital video images are blurry, the fight scenes messy, the editing jerky, and the derivative plot absurdly overwrought.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is why 3D was invented.
Lazy plotting, so-so performances and squandered ideas lead to only one diagnosis: there is no compelling reason to keep this moribund formula on a life-support machine.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Guillermo del Toro's Fabergé egg of a fairytale is not so much a sequel as a fusion of the fabulist imagination of 'Pan's Labyrinth' with the witty, irreverent comic-book action of his own 'Hellboy'.
Unfortunately, a 'Matrix'-style shoot-out offers a glib, violent solution to what is otherwise an intriguing emotional conflict.

This suspense film by first-time writer-director Bryan Bertino initially squeezes some surprisingly effective scares out of familiar elements. Sadly, the scenario quickly becomes attenuated and unbelievable.

The film's one major fault is that Reilly's character repeatedly acts in ways that serve the plot, but which run contrary to rational human behaviour. By contrast, the shattering downbeat ending is well earned and genuinely shocking.

It's brainless fun, but while Anderson's brilliant staging of the flesh-ripping stunts surpasses Bartel's cheap thrills, this update lacks the sardonic wit and satirical bite of the Corman-produced version.

Director Pierre Morel's directing style is ruthlessly efficient, but leaves no time to ponder the plot holes or the borderline racist portrayal of vicious Albanian gangsters and sleazy Arab businessmen.
One can't turn a blind eye to such conspicuous failings.
This seriously entertaining film celebrates the idea that, despite their elders' complacency, the young will find the strength to imagine a better future for themselves.
Even the most die-hard of Saw fans won't credit how tedious, lame and pointless this fourth sequel manages to be.
The film hurtles towards the final 'revelation moment' like runaway train. If only it had stopped to take on board some of Barker's heavy mythical dread.
To make a 3-D 'torture porn' movie is at best opportunist; to make one with flat, boring torture scenes is unforgivable.

John Moore directs the hell out of the action, while Jonathan Sela's glistening photography captures the snow and rain that fall on these bloody New York streets. But you'd have to be on crack not to guess the 'surprise' finale.

An American remake of the Spanish horror movie '[Rec]' that adopts the same basic recipe, but removes any hint of flavour or texture, reducing cutting-edge Catalan cuisine to bland, bite-sized McNuggets.
Shankland's approach is oblique rather than graphic, but these icy chills will send shivers down your spine.
Gordon has directed drama, such as Mamet's 'Edmond', but also visceral horror movies like 'Re-Animator'. Elements of both are evident in this taut psychological thriller.
This is without question the dumbest horror movie of recent years. There is simply no way to piece together its fractured shards.
A painful reminder of what fantasy cinema was like before the Lord of the Rings trilogy re-wrote the rules.
The kind of film which inspires awe, even in an atheist.
movie_title: Un condamné à mort s'est échappé ou Le vent souffle où il veut (A Man Escaped) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Steeped in religion yet shot through with moral ambiguity, this disturbing psychological thriller breathes new life into the moribund serial killer movie.
A poignant study of the searing pain caused by loss, this all-too-human horror film provokes tears as well as fears.
This has all the appeal of reheated, congealed blood.

Short on plausibility but preserving the psycho-sexual ambiguities throughout, Bigelow's seductively stylish, wildy fetishistic thriller is proof that a woman can enter a traditionally male world and, like Megan, beat men at their own game.
This tedious sequel casts the producer's uncharismatic son (Bateman) as Fox's similarly afflicted cousin Todd, but offers only a faint echo of its predecessor.
Roald Dahl's implausible script is padded out with the usual exotic locations, stunts, and trickery.
There's plenty of scatological humour and knockabout fun to get one through the slower passages.
Ford's purest and most sustained expression of the familiar themes of the passing of the Old West, the conflict between the untamed wilderness and the cultivated garden, and the power of myth.
movie_title: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (1962)

movie_review_blurb: The movie references may strike some as in-jokey, but Guest's likeable film has enough jaundiced sideswipes and lighter chuckles to see it through its slacker spells.
Craven's cold, flat style of filming emphasises the fact that the violence dehumanises not only the victims but the aggressors.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (1972)

movie_review_blurb: More of the same from the wackiest police force on the streets, and their newly recruited civilian helpers.
The earnest plot is nothing to write home about, but the effective use of documentary-style location shooting and deep-focus photography was innovatory for its day.
The film uses an intimate knowledge of teen-movie clichés to subvert their debased values from the inside.
Directed with a cavalier disregard for intelligibility, this has to be one of the most anaemic vampire flicks ever made.
This expensively empty action comedy is as much fun as a car crash.
This is nothing but trailer moments. Ex-pop video director McG couldn't organise a pillow fight in a bedding factory.
A gritty human drama evoking the residual vibrancy of a threatened culture.
What makes this shoot-'em-up nonsense surprisingly watchable is Randy Feldman's rapid-fire dialogue, which constantly undercuts the macho posturings while parodying Stallone's screen image.
A hi-tech thriller with a human heart.
Delirious, demented and diabolically funny.
Love's second movie about hooligans marks a quantum leap forward from the messy, senseless violence of 'The Football Factory'.
The resulting fragmented mess will no doubt keep some in stitches, but it is definitely less than the sum of its body parts.
This smart, involving sci-fi picture, set in an Ohio high school, pays homage to several genre faves, notably Invasion of the Body Snatchers and The Thing.
A classic piece of pared-down genre film-making is lent extra depth by an emotional subtext stressing Kidman's transition from dependent wife to resourceful individual.
At times the relentless special effects and tangled plotting veer towards visual and narrative overkill, but the final tonal swerve is shocking and effective.
A subtle study in the seductiveness of evil and a terrifying ride to the edge of darkness.
In contrast to his short, sharp fighting style, Seagal's presentation of the human conflicts and underlying issues consists of vague, sweeping gestures.
Chuckle, if you can, during the first few minutes; because after that laughter catches in the throat as the clammy hand of terror tightens its grip.
Fassbinder uses dramatic and visual excess to push everyday events to extremes, achieving a degree of political and psychological truth not accessible through mere social realism.
movie_title: Angst Essen Seele auf (Ali: Fear Eats the Soul) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Plenty of pillaging, axe-throwing, hearty quaffing of ale, storming of castles, heroic jumping into wolf pits, and manly talk about the glories of entering Valhalla with sword in hand.

An intense psychological drama which confronts [Cronenberg's] familiar preoccupations -- fear of physical and mental disintegration, mortality, the power struggle between the sexes -- without the paradoxical protection of visceral disgust.
Misjudged, compromised Hollywood remake.
Travolta, it seems, had wanted to star in a film of Battlefield Earth since first reading the novel in 1982. Only the all-seeing L Ron knows why.
Teague, meanwhile, is far too busy orchestrating the large-scale action sequences to make anything of the cardboard characters, episodic plotting, or clunking dialogue.
The animated hand, creepy piano music, and Lorre's eye-popping performance are all memorable.
An unsatisfactory mix of low-key heroics, buddy-buddy humour, and anti-war sentiment ..
More generous observers might cite the parallel with bad taste guru John Waters; but compared to this shallow crap, even the Baltimore Bard's offerings run deep.
French director Christophe Gans's adaptation of the Silent Hill computer game is visually inspired and thematically ambitious, yet ultimately uninvolving.

This allegedly true tale of demonic possession is weighed down by period detail and ponderous storytelling, which soon get the better of its Exorcist-inspired levitations, flying crucifixes and noisy poltergeist activity.
There are a few push-button frights, but a total dearth of mind-disturbing terror; the humour, too, is broad, crowd-pleasing stuff.
The effect is relentless and cumulative.
McNaughton's compelling study of a blithe sociopath makes the flesh crawl and the mind reel.
movie_title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)

movie_review_blurb: Hardly worth the four-year wait.
Derivative, adolescent tosh.
Sadly, as with [director Eli] Roth's promising but flawed debut feature, its central conceit is more compelling than what ended up on screen.
Gratifyingly downbeat and far more coherent than the Japanese anime movies to which it also owes a debt, Renaissance intelligently explores the ethical complexities of genetic manipulation.
The massaged script is now a little too knowing and calculated, nudging the audience in anticipation of each snake attack or corny gag.
Blending fierce horror and sly humour, Christopher Smith's confident follow-up to the more generic Creep marks a quantum leap forward for the young British filmmaker.
The plot dawdles along, intrigue gives way to risible melodrama, and [director] Patrick Stettner fails to get to grips with the issues.
Neil LaBute's utterly misconceived remake of Robin Hardy's 1973 cult horror film is a boring, fright-free catastrophe.
As the ghosts suck the life out of their victims, the audience suffers the same fate.
Oddball futuristic fun with a serious, if confused, message.
Quietly devastating and unbearably moving, this is a soul-searching classic.
The second Saw sequel develops the mythology of sadistic puppet-master Jigsaw in ambitious, gruesome but ultimately self-defeating ways.
Embracing every level of French society, from the aristocratic hosts to a poacher turned servant, the film presents a hilarious yet melancholic picture of a nation riven by petty class distinctions.
movie_title: The Rules of the Game (La règle du jeu) (1939)

movie_review_blurb: An engrossing thriller - and one sparkling with intelligence, with the surprising twists grounded in credible human behaviour.
A disastrously miscast remake of the 1976 horror classic, which retains the apocalyptic themes of David Seltzer's original script but renders them dull and fright-free.
Marvellous stuff.
The psychological mind-games are played to the hilt, the pressurised cabin air increases the edge-of-the-seat tension and the 85-minute flight time is gratifyingly short.
Gilliam fills the screen with bizarre images, and directs with a breathless ingenuity.
The key words here are lazy and contrived.
Regrettably, an overblown finale and redundant trick ending undercut the mild subversiveness of what's gone before.
An attempt to redefine cutting edge horror, this techno-vampire pic is spoiled by the same weak storytelling and flashy, computer game visuals.
As a stand-alone film, this doesn't work; but viewed through the prism of the original, it offers some twisted, self-conscious pleasures.
Irredeemably dire.
movie_title: I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Flying scenes, frat-boy face-offs and pyrotechnic punch-ups are punctuated by excruciating expository dialogue.

Diaz, clad mostly in a one-piece yellow swimsuit, is left floundering in the shallows of a script which relies on ludicrous human behaviour and mechanical plot twists, the latter signposted by an over-emphatic score.
It has its slack spells, but Rafelson's sure feel for the inexpressible subtleties of emotional relationships is evident throughout.
The finale, in which Lionel reduces a horde of flesh-eaters to a mulch of blood, flesh and offal with the aid of a flymo, is probably the goriest scene ever.
Stone's eye-blistering images possess an awesome power, which sets the senses reeling and leaves the mind disturbed.
It seems more like an expectorant for Edwards' bile than an entertainment aimed at an audience.
Only Louise Lasser, as the vivacious owner of the Nouveau Woodstock vegetarian restaurant, gives any hint of what might have been achieved with a little imagination.
If you've seen either Black Christmas or Halloween, there's nothing new here: the hyped-up score keeps telling us we ought to be scared, but the suspense feels mechanical and fake.
The tedious storytelling sucks the life and soul out of the characters far more effectively than Satan ever manages.
Why see Saw? Because it has teeth and it cuts to the bone.

If writer Paul Tanter's voiceover and dialogue had been delivered with any conviction, it might have distracted us from the dull visuals, over-complicated flash-back/flash-forward structure and TV soap opera-style acting.
This haunted house movie achieves a frightening intensity with limited means, but also feels under-characterised and overstretched.

Talky and claustrophobic, Pontypool is a mash-up of Orson Welles' notorious The War of the Worlds radio broadcast and George A. Romero's Night of the Living Dead, with a tone and cast that's reminiscent of John Carpenter's Assault on Precinct 13.
This Zimmer-zomcom is as subtle as a brick in the gob, but it's also a laugh riot.
No amount of shaky-cam footage or imaginative sound design can lend coherence to these improvised scenes, which were shot on location before being patched together in the editing room.
A film that not even the formidable Gary Lewis can save is a scary thing indeed.
It's like a twisted balloon animal filled with blood and guts, waiting to burst.
An overripe mélange of Cronenbergian 'body horror' and alienated Lynchian weirdness.
Eastwood and Adams do the best they can with the cornball sentimentality and cheesy dialogue, but first-time director Robert Lorenz merely photographs the on- and off-field action. Give it a pass.
In the end, Bayona's film is more frustrating and exhausting than inspiring.
As pointless as one feared it might be.

Once in a while, a mould-breaking horror movie signals the arrival of a unique talent: doubly so in this case, since this bracingly perverse 'body modification' tale was made by Canadian twins Jen and Sylvia Soska, aka the Twisted Sisters.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The post-'Blair Witch' shaky-cam horror movie, already teetering on the edge of oblivion, drops off a cliff with this micro-budget British effort ...
'Antiviral' never wholly succeeds as either a surgical satire or a medical conspiracy thriller, and its tedious last third is like a diseased body dragging itself slowly to the grave.
By splitting the action between several different characters and locations, the plot dissipates the suspense and lacks focus, as if it has been bolted together from disparate, ill-fitting pieces.
More coherent and thought-provoking than most 'found-footage' horror movies, this should appeal to genre fans and eco-activists alike.

For all its gleeful limb-severing, offal-scoffing and chainsaw-wielding, this disco mirrorball of a movie scatters ideas in all directions, rather than focusing the spotlight on what counts - the scares.
Despite its stumbling storyline, lack of logic and sparse comedy, this ZomRomCom has a beating romantic heart.
Feels like the germ of an idea with stuff lifted from 'Alien' et al and bolted on.
Essentially a lot of balls.
The powerful performances and sharp script augment this revealing human drama.
movie_title: Evil Angels (A Cry in the Dark) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Crude, cheap and pointless, this surely drives a stake through the heart of the 'Underworld' franchise.
As these parallel supernatural mysteries begin to meld into one another, all semblance of credibility dissolves, leaving behind an impenetrable and frustrating fog of unanswered questions.
Quote not available.
Supernatural fantasy movies often work best when the film-maker's tongue is planted firmly in the cheek.
Quote not available.

While director Espinosa hones in on the ambiguous battle between Weston's idealism and Frost's cynicism, British cinematographer Oliver Wood - who filmed the last two Bourne movies - shoots the hell out of everything.
You know you're in trouble when not even the improvised scenes and fluffed out-takes are funny.
It's the naturalistic intensity of Rapace's performance that stays with us.
Filmmakers Chris Kentis and Laura Lau ('Open Water') should have plugged the original's plot holes and straightened out its logic.
The 'Evil Dead' and Romero nods are fun, but characters appear for no reason and are bumped off without warning; there's just not enough flesh on these funny bones.
Quote not available.
Even the gore is sporadic, poorly staged and unimaginative: as a result, this is neither fish nor foul.
Once the annoying, two-dimensional characters start getting bumped off one by one, it's just a relief that the actors have stopped improvising their own banal dialogue.
[Its] cynical hedging of its psychological/supernatural bets seems mostly designed to breed sequels.
A mash-up of old-school heroism, pantomime villainy, starstruck lovers and post-'Shrek' archness, it's more exhausting than exhilarating.
An engaging portrait of a lovable, shambolic music fan turned reluctant impresario.
Despite much old-school splatter, it's seldom frightening and oddly unfunny.
Despite its stodgy storytelling, this respectful cinematic version of ex-POW Eric Lomax's true story succeeds because of Colin Firth's perfect, understated performance.
A funny, touching and surprisingly fleet-footed comedy about a quartet of 60-plus male friends who are determined to grow old (dis)gracefully.
Authentic military detail, generic storytelling and manly patriotism battle it out in a gut-wrenching war movie that celebrates heroism under fire.
It's dystopia all over again, in an under-funded Terry Gilliam film stuffed with over-familiar ideas and trapped in a claustrophobic, ecclesiastical set.
If you make it as far as the obvious, disappointing denouement, you might be left asking yourself if the filmmakers' abstract style is better suited to short films.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious, old fashioned, ideas-driven science fiction film that is never as mind-expanding as its futuristic images and topical, dystopian ideas seem to promise.
There are satisfying echoes of Stephen King's sly black humour in this deliciously nasty comedy thriller.
An impressively staged climactic exorcism compensates in part for the random, far-fetched storytelling that precedes it.
This rural 'home invasion' movie is gussied up with topical nods to the Scottish independence debate - but horror fans on both sides of the border are likely to vote no.
Leslie and Treadaway extract plenty of existential doubt and distressing emotion from what is essentially a claustrophobic two-hander.
Pared down images and intense, polemical dialogue capture a young girl's struggle to reconcile her personal belief in God with her community's blinkered religious values.
The inspiring story of Thor Heyerdahl's Kon-Tiki expedition makes for an exciting, if slightly old fashioned, maritime adventure movie.
Its nihilism feels cynical rather than authentically bleak, and the increasingly histrionic scenes start to resemble an indulgent actors' workshop that has spun out of control.
Forget the disastrous Hellbound: Hellraiser II; this is adult horror to die for.
Alvart achieves a strong sense of scale, but characters and ideas are lost amid a mess of fight scenes that, oddly, look like outtakes from 'The Descent'.
Think a Sly Stallone-scripted action movie starring The Stath is a sure-fire winner? Think again.
Delivering on the promise of 2010's 'Rabies', this is a bleakly funny mash-up comedy about child murder, corruption, torture and the siege mentality
In this tale of sexual awakening, the adolescent Isabelle is often naked and exposed; but we never once get under her skin.
Grips like a 4x4, even as the escalating tension threatens to spin out of control.
Gives a sense of horror movie making learned by rote - at a boy's school where girls have been admitted under sufferance.
A lifeless attempt to fuse a taut crime thriller and a complex psychological drama.
Like all over-ambitious B-movies, this features solid performances by a mix of seasoned talent and promising young actors, all of whom deserve better.
A provocative political thriller which, despite Riz Ahmed's electrifying central performance, is too uneven and over-stated to realise its dramatic and polemical ambitions.
The film's would-be subversive ideas about the kneejerk appeal of social violence get lost in the mix.

By the time the kamikaze crows start dive-bombing the church windows, and the shape-shifting demon appears in a hoody and a Venetian carnival mask, the whole thing has degenerated into a mumbo jumbo gumbo.
The film's downbeat switchback ending is neither convincing nor earned.

Cahill's visually inconsistent first feature tries to beam epic sci-fi concepts into a micro-human drama, refracting its thought-provoking ideas through the prism of the central emotional relationship.
Softley negotiates layers of deceit with skill, but an uncharacteristic visual and narrative tightness leaves one wondering what might have been.
Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg are perfectly matched as mis-matched buddies in a violent, funny and entertaining action-comedy.
Stripped-down survivalist sci-fi showcases Vin Diesel's laconic anti-hero, retina-scorching planetary vistas and fearsome creature designs.
An eye-ravishing meditation on first love, squandered talent, the eternal beauty of Rome and a life wasted on hedonistic excess.
For all but the most forgiving horror fans, this is a lazy, stupid and incoherent failure.
A patchy attempt to wrangle quirky, other-worldly comic-book mythology into a mainstream 3D blockbuster format, but one which lacks the oddball imagination to pull it off.
A disturbing crime thriller, elevated by subtle storytelling, challenging ideas and fine performances, but let down by some lazy generic tropes and jarring implausibilities.
Like WikiLeaks itself, The Fifth Estate collapses under the sheer weight of information and political import bearing down upon it, its human drama crushed by documentary data overload.
Engagingly acted character comedy takes precedence over the nominal action-comedy plot, which involves the usual mysterious crime kingpin and the whereabouts of a big shipment of drugs.

Budgetary limitations, a plodding script, ropey visual effects and an excruciating score undercut a heartfelt cautionary tale about a confused teenager wrestling with his religious faith and the dogmatism of his overzealous elders.
Shares crucial DNA with the earlier films but is drawn from the shallower end of the gene pool.
A well-acted but ramshackle mess.
The breathtaking digital photography and an atmospheric electronic score sustain the mood, and for those who see this savage journey through to the end, there are riches aplenty.
Every now and then a small, intelligent, quietly thought-provoking film slips through the Hollywood studios' net and prompts the thought, How did this ever get made?
This is the worst yet from Michael Bay's horror production company Platinum Dunes, which also brought you rubbish re-makes of Halloween and Friday the 13th.
[A] pitifully unfunny 'hommage' to '80s action comedies.
Ridley's coup de grace is a quiet, emotionally charged ending as surprising as it is bold.
This is the worst yet from Michael Bay's horror production company Platinum Dunes, which also brought you rubbish re-makes of Halloween and Friday the 13th.
Despite a few neat surprises, [Rec] 2 mainly expands on familiar images and ideas.
This is bracing, often brutal stuff, set in a world where, as Ulric says, 'God has slipped over the horizon.'

This is the sequel that John McTiernan and Arnold Schwarzenegger's 1987 original deserved, as director Nimrod Antal delivers enough hard core sci-fi, explosive action and monster mayhem to justify its belated arrival.
An enjoyable if slightly innocuous biopic based on the brief life and short-lived fame of teen rock'n'roll idol Richie Valens
This Cronenbergian exploration of the perils of inter-species gene-splicing wrestles with some topical and disturbing ideas, but never quite pins them down.
One is bored and stupefied by what seems like an eternity of vacuous spectacle, cod-Buddhist tosh and clunking dialogue.
Aja serves up the tongue-in-cheek thrills, CGI-enhanced gore and gratuitous nudity with such unabashed relish that this may prove to be the summer's break-out horror hit.
This latest example of the French new wave of horror does at least have the Romero-like guts to address a topical social problem.
Vapid, Disneyfied post-teen comedy lacks a mean (girl) streak.
No amount of relentless forward momentum, head-smacking violence or CGI-enhanced blood-letting can disguise the anaemic characterisation and obvious contrivances.
A supple, amusing, lightweight entertainment graced with likeable performances and an effective, unobtrusive score.
Despite some cracking comic dialogue and memorable characters, some parts of the storyline are over-cooked, while others remain underdone.
Marshall's adrenalin-fuelled skill and enthusiasm propel the action forward with reckless abandon.
This cerebral horror movie plays Scrabble with the genre's cinematic lingo.
Melissa George's fearless, credible performance grounds the madness in a moving emotional reality, even as her sanity is lost at sea.
Rupert Glasson's persuasive psychological thriller offers an interesting variation on the sociopathic 'stalker' plot.
This overlong, non-frightening debut features ugly digital images that are either over-saturated or absurdly badly lit, and its attempts at leavening humour all fall flat.
By tapping in to the same vein of 'hormonal horror' as the excellent 'Ginger Snaps', this offers a witty, subversive look at the darker side of teen friendship.
Osunsanmi's tricksy formal device simply reinforces our disbelief and invites ridicule.
It's this feeling of vulnerability that Peli's slow-burning supernatural chiller so effectively exploits, fashioning heart-stopping scares out of almost nothing.

While it concerns itself with the gruesome logistics of finding bodies to be ritually sacrificed and chopped into bite-size pieces, Grau's hybrid film achieves a morbid fascination that is reinforced by Santiago Sanchez's artfully scuzzy cinematography.
Sadly, there's nothing here but bloody off-cuts from 'Death Wish', 'Saw' and 'The Silence of the Lambs', in roughly that order.
This thoughtful, low-key exploration of our darker survival instincts is too conventional and unfocused to fully engage our emotions.

Not so much a contemporary re-make of Joseph Ruben's 1987 psychological thriller as a lobotomised bastard step-child: over-plotted, over-long, and stripped of the original's sharp, satirical subversion of suburban family values.
An ambitious premise about a future world ruled by corporate vampires is explored with some intelligence, sly humour and blood-splattering brio by the Spierig brothers.
Plot twists, lighting changes and shifts of tone work hard to sustain our attention, but the script sometimes becomes too involved in solving the structural challenges it has set itself.
With its mist-shrouded sets, gruesome slaughter and copious CGI, this is a surprisingly respectful updating of the 1941 Universal original.

A monstrously entertaining action-adventure... the film's epic vision bears comparison with the 'Lord of the Rings' trilogy, its imaginative supernatural elements confidently fused with a savage reality.
This is horror hokum of the cheesiest kind. Rent 'Orphan' instead.
Harris's direction is messy, favouring confusing set-piece scares over the all-important group dynamics.
For all the film's bleak ironies, Lai-sheung's brutal asphyxiation of a pregnant woman, who aborts her child while dying, destroys any residual empathy.
Celestial tosh of less than Biblical proportions.
A seamless blending of romance, road movie and monster flick.

Distinguishes itself from other ill-conceived reboots in general, and from Tim Burton's disastrous 2001 remake in particular, by looking with fresh, simian eyes at its core conflict between human and primates.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It sticks to gimmicky scenes in which twentysomethings are dispatched in ingenious ways, but first-time director Steven Quayle delivers cheap fun that will keep fans happy.
A boring revamp, with dull 3D effects, insipid teenage protagonists and only sporadically scary outbursts of neck-biting, crucifix-wielding and staking through the heart.
Given that the cast improvised all the scenes live on set, the dialogue has a surprising ring of truth, and is shot through with an unexpected, often unsettling, humour.
The film's relentless momentum, coupled with Ali Asad's breathtaking location photography, distract us from the often two-dimensional supporting characters.
There is so much here that one admires, one wishes that there was more to love.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One for all and all for nowt.
In stark contrast to the original's cool, clinical horror, Martin's cack-handed creation of the arse-to-mouth creature is played for cheap, sick slapstick laughs.
A ridiculous revelation and a redundant sexual assault undercut all good sense, as fierce rationality gives way to absurd contrivance and hysteria.
'Snowtown' is an uncomfortable film to watch, but its sickening suburban horror is made bearable by Kurzel's rigorous restraint...
At first, a great deal happens, then nothing much happens for quite some time, then something so underwhelming happens that one is left wondering, 'Did that really just happen?'
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
This is like a well-worn vintage dress: comfortable but a little threadbare.
This gleefully excessive pastiche of an exploitation picture delivers everything promised by its own faux trailer.
Jeff Grace's melancholy music underscores the atmosphere of bleak dystopian despair, leavened by flashes of humour and hope.
Your head hurts like hell, the whole thing feels horribly familiar, and it's just not funny any more. Can this really be happening again?
A sordid welter of sexual sadism, incestuous necrophilia and 'snuff movie' nihilism.
Despite a running time of less than 70 minutes (minus the credits), still outstays its welcome.

By honing the jagged edges of Meir Zarchi's cheap and nasty rape-revenge shocker into slick entertainment, this unwelcome remake improves technically on the 1978 original, while retaining all that was sleazy and repellent...
Even in this dim light, one can see every plot development coming a mile off.
This is a dreary metaphysical drama dressed in the vestments of a religious horror movie.
One has to admire the spirit of this independent production, which aims for the sweeping spectacle of 'El Cid', but it falls way short of its epic ambitions.

The weak link is Christopher Bertolini's script, which lumbers the flat military characters with hackneyed dialogue and corny sentimentality. Not even Eckhart can survive such banality, and kick-ass specialist Michelle Rodriguez is wasted.
Swank is typically credible as a confident yet vulnerable professional woman, and Morgan is subtly convincing as the insinuating Max.

For all its pre-Christian paganism, demon child imagery, blood and guts, David Keating's rural horror movie is at heart an involving portrait of a young couple struggling to come to terms with the death of a daughter.

Ripley's intricate script and Jones's brisk direction invite us to climb aboard and enjoy the ride. But if you want to dig deeper, there is some serious stuff about a guy lost in fragments of time, groping towards a sense of his own identity.
Snyder pulverises our senses with derivative digital images and obvious musical choices. But his failure to delineate the levels of 'reality' is confusing and self-defeating.
Cranks up the tension with fluid, choreographed camera moves and unnerving off-screen sounds.
Not so much insidious as inexcusable.
A remorseless catalogue of calculated violence, casual cannibalism and sexual sadism, this inflicts over two hours of suffering on the audience...
Aims for intricate, Hitchcockian suspense, embellished with ornate visual flourishes that recall Dario Argento's early giallo movies.
Quote not available.

Can the trio use their ninja secrets to escape? Will granddad defeat the gun-runner in hand-to-hand combat? If you can't guess the answers to these questions you are under 11 and will absolutely love this film.
Director Campbell keeps matters bowling along and even manages to recapture something of the look of the earlier films.
Skyfall is the smartest Bond film for many years, and though aficionados will enjoy the many nods to past films, this is a film that sets out a future path for Bond.
The humanity Sachs and his actors depict is profound and leaves a mark.

The problem for The Intervention lies in its misjudgment of tone. It's played for feelgood laughs (the cornball ending feels especially unearned), when DuVall should have instead dug deeper to exploit her characters for the messed up people that they are.
Keough and Malone convey a palpable sense of yearning for one another ... but Kim and Bradley Rust Gray's barebones script doesn't match their efforts.

For a directorial debut, Ross's film is admirably odd and hard to pin down. What first starts as a meet-cute love story slowly morphs into a globe-trotting thriller, only to settle down into something altogether more bizarre and disturbing.
Despite its period trappings, Stillman's film never feels stilted, largely thanks to his bracingly modern heroine who takes no prisoners, and makes no apologies for her conniving behavior.
A mawkish family comedy, intent to please, The Hollars plays like an extended sitcom.
Silly and fun until it wears out its welcome.
The only true miracle that emerges out of all of this is Garner's performance.
For fans of Sandler's broad studio comedy, Pixels will go down easy. Everyone else should watch Patrick Jean's ingenious short film that inspired Pixels.
In spite of his characters' actions, Minervini miraculously captures traces of profound humanity.
Albert gets offered the opportunity to redeem her actions, and make light of why and how she conned the world. Unsurprisingly, she's a hell of a storyteller.
Tickled morphs from an offbeat caper to a disturbing exposé on the dangers of cyberbullying.
Porter's film is armed with a deluge of troubling data to make her case, but it's the personal stories she captures that make her argument all the more compelling.
Finn makes for a bit of bland protagonist, but he's nicely balanced out by his outlandish teammates, each so clearly defined by Linklater's subtly incisive screenplay.
By the time Clarence screams "wordness to the turdness", the humor has all but evaporated.
The set-up is familiar by caper standards (Ocean's Eleven on a lower budget, where the cops are robbers) - what sets it apart is Cage's brazenly bizarre performance.
As the violence escalates, an absurdist dose of humor is added to the mix, injecting the film with a distinctly modern sensibility that is welcome and does not let up.
Aims for inspired lunacy but misses the mark by a mile.
Under its scares, Under the Shadow serves as an impassioned allegory for female oppression - but Anvari doesn't shortchange horror fans.
Unfortunately, on the whole, Schamus' debut feels too self-serious to fully engage.
Hall has largely languished with supporting roles in films that in no way prepare you for the breadth she displays in director Antonio Campos's tragic character study, Christine.

It's doubtful that Brando ever thought the revelatory tapings would one day provide fodder for a documentary, but thanks to his recordings Riley has managed to construct a tribute to the actor that his fans have long deserved.
Shot over two hours in a single, dazzling take, Victoria is one of the year's most impressive technical achievements - but it's more than mere gimmick.
True to life, it's unpredictable and a bit of a mess. And that's what makes Maggie's Plan such a delight.

Peter Sollet's fact-based drama couldn't have come at a better time to remind the world how far equality has come in America, and how fresh the fight still is. Instead, Freeheld comes across as shockingly trite.
Patricia Rozema's drama doesn't burrow deep into its end of world scenario.
The unsure tone screams that this is a director embarrassed by the film he's making.
Even when The Walk inspires the eyes, the brain registers little but banality.
Like Reichardt's directorial hand, the performances are understated across the board, but deeply felt.
By the Sea's uncompromising nature is its most admirable asset. It's a vanity project that's difficult to love, but alluring to unpack.
McKay fails to transfer Lewis's source material into purely cinematic terms.
Jack's inability to connect with his new environment is devastatingly rendered, aided tremendously by Tremblay's remarkably credible performance, and Larson's palpable pain.
Shannon shows new shades in her deft handling of a tragedy she's tasked with bearing. Further proof that when it comes to drama, comedy actors are often the experts.
Wiener-Dog doesn't find Solondz going light to deliver an inspirational medley. Instead, he's created arguably his most caustic film since Happiness.
Yes, the story has the makings of a Lifetime movie; what grounds it are the terrific performances and Heder's rich direction and screenplay.
It forces viewers to take long looks at his most controversial imagery, proving that he still has the power to provoke, seduce and enrage.
Ahn's muted approach to his material, coupled with the passivity of the film's lead character, David Cho (Joe Seo), leaves Spa Night feeling too cold to fully engage.
A harrowing subject for a film, then, but somehow Landesman - who also wrote the screenplay - never manages to turn it into a gripping movie.
Nirvana for Pee-wee fans ...
Dennison holds his own opposite Neill, who hasn't been tasked with such a gravely amusing role in years. Together, the two are comic dynamite.
Profound, this film is not.
Ozon is often at his best when working with women, and he has a fabulous talent in Paula Beer to bring his protagonist, Anna, to vivid life. She's stunning in the role.
It's all of course nakedly manipulative, much like Bayona's last film, The Impossible. Luckily, his actors sell the hell out of the premise.
Even as All I See Is You descends into soapy nonsense, it remains visually engaging.
Patches of it are so ludicrously hammy it plays like one of those unbearably corny fake films teased at the beginning of Tropic Thunder.
It's a singular vision from an uncompromising director that just so happens to be about one of the most famous women in American history.
Like all of Herzog's output, it casts its own strange spell.

Chiappe's screenplay, based on Lissa Evans' novel Their Finest Hour and a Half, unfortunately suggests that even someone as spirited as Cole can only find true worth in the reciprocated love of a man, and not her work.
Hughes keeps her camera restlessly moving, straining to keep up with Eldon's travails - but she does little to ground her picture.

Schreiber is so good you wish he'd lead more films, while Moss is fiery as always, owning her thick Jersey accent like nobody's business. Matching them is Schreiber's real-life partner Naomi Watts ...

It's commendable that Perkins seems wholly uninterested in the tropes of the genre: there's only one jump scare, hardly any gore and no final girl. The elusiveness of the narrative, however, grows weary fast.
movie_title: I Am the Pretty Thing That Lives in the House (2016)

movie_review_blurb: They deserve to have their voices heard, and not simply muffled by The Pearl.
Chastain single handedly prevents it all from veering off the rails by dominating Miss Sloane with her forceful presence. She grounds her heroine to ensure you're with her.
The action is merciless, expertly choreographed - and as a result, energizing.
Admirably cynical until it loses its way in the final stretch, The Ticket nevertheless maintains a provocative allure, bolstered by a fiercely committed performance from Dan Stevens.

Each portrait melds to create a heartrending whole guaranteed to make men think to call their mothers more often. To those who have lost their mothers, the experience of watching Mom and Me might prove unbearable -- it's that touching.
In a scant 79 minutes, All This Panic sure covers a lot of ground.
The whole thing reeks of a vanity project for Butler (who also produced), affording him the chance to showboat as a Gordon Gekko type trying to redeem himself.
An unabashed crowdpleaser about a hero fighting to maintain that title when corporate greed threatens to tarnish his image.
Even if Timberlake's brand of funky pop is not to your liking, he proves himself to be such a forceful and gifted entertainer, that resistance is ultimately futile.

The script is out to pasture, neglecting to address the interior lives of all of its characters, and failing to deliver a single good punchline. The limp direction lacks the wacky sensibility that characterizes Sonnenfeld's best work.
Keeping it afloat are the stellar performances Holmes draws from herself and her excellent cast.
A layered and delicately wrought entertainment.
The Phenom, like its protagonist, is hard to pin down, making for a film that's transfixing and opaque in equal measure.
Clearly casting is key to its success. Luckily, Johnson hit the jackpot by getting Michael Shannon on board as the King and Kevin Spacey to play the corrupt president.
A meandering mess of half-baked storylines that amount to little. Hanks's affable presence keeps it all afloat.
Pity that the bloody finale only makes up for the last third of what's otherwise pretty dreary.
It's Franco who steals the picture, much as he did in Spring Breakers. As in Harmony Korine's neon-lit thriller, the actor goes no holds barred.
In crude terms: Alice's second trip to Underland wasn't worth the wait.
Documentary portraits live or die on the subject at hand -- and in his debut documentary Peter and the Farm, film-maker Tony Stone has a hell of a character to keep you engaged.
In his personal life, his rage has publicly manifested in horribly offensive ways. As an actor, Gibson is at his best when he taps into it.
The film, like the smug magicians that populate it, showboats by throwing more of everything at the screen. Critically lacking is the sense of fun that characterised its predecessor.
Like its predecessor, it's exceedingly well crafted, relentlessly terrifying and boasts characters you actually root for.
Like its distraught protagonist, Amber Tamblyn's Paint It Black is unforgiving, flawed and ferocious.

Coy's fight for equal rights is the focus of the documentary, but it's the family's willingness to allow Juhola into their turbulent lives that gives it the emotional heft needed to connect with even the most conservative of viewers.

Whereas the first two succeeded in explicitly condemning society's lust for carnage, Election Year opts to revel in it. It's a disturbing development in the series, especially given the times we live in.
Fun oozes from almost every frame; likewise the energy of a team excited to be revolutionising the blockbuster landscape. Let's just hope everyone will enjoy the view.
Her two exceptional stars do their best to convey their animosity via simmering glances. But in the end, Curran's muted approach does them no favors.
The Transfiguration is a character study first and foremost, spending all of its time with Milo. Problem is, he's so opaque that as a protagonist, he's completely impenetrable.
Now this documentary experience honors [Wood's] visionary movie for new generations, and hilariously gets to the bottom of the shocking and unspeakable horrors that await anyone who watches it.

Unlike other documentaries that have an agenda... or that subtly coach their subjects to look or sound ridiculous, director Brad Abrahams simply allows David to tell his intimate, fascinating and incredible story.
Barber delivers a dramatic Blair Witch Project for UFO fans, and anyone else who likes to wonder about what is lurking in our skies that the government doesn't want us to know about.
This is a real-life story of extreme bravery against all odds, with wonderful cinematography and special effects that take us back to the Cold War battle for supremacy in space.
Stick with Moonlight for some perspective. You'll absorb something good and emerge more reflective about things you've never thought of before.
Watching these superheroes save the day will only slow down yours. Stay home and do a Marvel marathon instead.
Nothing can compensate for the fact that it's a movie about repetition that is, unintentionally, highly repetitive.

This Iranian drama is chock-full of intrigue and has a lot of parallels with Indian sensibilities. There are a lot of reasons to watch it, least of all the fact that it is this year's Oscar winner for Best Foreign Language Film.
Give it a shot, the storytelling isn't strong enough to make you weep like a baby, but it will occasionally make you giggle like one.
This is the kind of movie that you need to sip and savour. It won't go well with popcorn and soda, but it's worth a visit to the theatre anyway.
We've seen crazier things done in the name of love on the big screen. Ultimately, it's easier seeing Heigl pine for love than seeing her try to snatch it away from someone.
With his English-language debut, Batra proves that his journey as a filmmaker is in sharp contrast with the title of his film.
Everything, Everything certainly isn't what epic, heart-wrenching love stories are made of, but it'll do as a date-movie that doesn't demand everything of you.
The Circle has the makings of a great thriller but just isn't well-rounded enough to leave a mark.
A Death In The Gunj will make you drop your jaw several times, except for the one time you'd really want it to: the climax.
Baby Driver is a great experiment in the heist-movie genre and with director Edgar Wright behind the wheel, you're sure to have a smooth ride.
It's the movie-equivalent of the string of 10,000 non-stop firecrackers that annoying kids burst outside your window in Diwali.
Having watched the previous films will help, but the movie is a legitimate standalone chiller. If there were a Horror For Dummies guidebook, Annabelle: Creation would make for a good chapter in it.
The documentary works wonderfully as a primer for someone totally unaware of the gravity of the issue, and will reinforce the need for swift action for the ones in the know.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Put simply, if you were the kid who secretly played book-cricket in history class, you may find the movie tedious, but if stories of brave soldiers and great wars excite you, march on into that theatre.
Go on this final voyage. The seas might get a bit rough but the pirates won't rob you off a good time.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It might not do much to your brain, but it'll certainly set your heart racing. If you're in the mood for blood, Wick is your pick.
The characters are inconsistent, the lines are handpicked from a Dialogue For Dummies guide and there's a general lack of attention to detail.
If you're in the mood to get scared this weekend, you'd have better luck surfing the news channels.
Indu Sarkar is at its best when it focuses on its protagonist's emotional struggles and dilemmas, leaving the politics behind.

Sushant Singh Rajput is a fine actor but lacks the casual charm required to make the self-important Shiv lovable. Jim Sarbh's delivery is painfully awkward; he doesn't have the gravitas required for spouting those evil-genius kind of lines in Hindi.
Unlike its namesake city, Gurgaon isn't messy enough and doesn't leave you gasping for air. But it provides a temporary taste of the dark side.
The funniest thing about this comedy is just how angry it can make you. Guest iin London, like its titular protagonist, is a burden no one should have to bear.

John Abraham is intense and impressive when he's breaking jaws and lifting cars, Tahir Raj Bhasin is good and shows his vulnerable side. Sonakshi Sinha's half-hearted performance, however, can be partly blamed on her annoyingly underwritten character.
Dear Maya works like a folded love-note slyly passed around a classroom: brief and heart-warming.
Parts of Jagga Jasoos are greater than their sum. But there's no reason you shouldn't head to a theatre and investigate for yourself.
If you care for some laughs, some YRF nostalgia and are, well, promiscuous with your choice of romcoms, you could take a chance with this one.
RSVP Yes to this wedding; it's grand, with good music, great people and delicious food for thought.

Anushka Sharma plays the most well-rounded character with abandon; she's remarkable. Ranbir's portrayal of the clumsy, turned-down one-sided lover is heartbreaking; his honesty comes through yet again.
Emma Roberts (usually seen as the mean girl) makes for a relatable, reclusive teen. Dave Franco is all smiles and charm; you want to go on this dangerous ride with him.
Moana literally means 'the ocean' and as the heroine conquers her namesake, she also conquers your heart. You won't regret setting sail and voyaging with her.
As an informative piece on the catastrophe at the Deepwater Horizon, the movie just doesn't dig deep enough. But as a visually rich disaster movie, it passes the test.
It's a great-looking film with an original idea. Watch it for its stars but it won't have an astronomical impact on you.

It is too reminiscent of bank-heist movies of the past; there are even clear shoutouts to the Dhoom franchise. A better plan of action and a few dry runs with the script would have ensured a product to bank on.
If you're going for the Kung Fu, chances are you'll end up in a meditative state instead.
Everything seems like it's moving at a speed we can't hold on to, but the answers do eventually come, and when they do, they are well worth the drive to get there.
This is a film for the people, a film for feelers and thinkers who want to see a story about a flawed person who loved his daughter and family.

This documentary is important, not just as personal investigation, but as a statement against official records: the countless cases where indictments aren't reached, where cases are closed, where young people are pressured to take plea bargains.

Though it isn't perfect, this story signals something we need more of, portraying people who have existed and survived in a country where their stories, like the Afro-Colombian soundtrack, ring loud and distinct.

The immediacy and realism of BHD is the key to its success, largely constructed through superior direction and a good cast, elements that ensure the viewer a harrowing yet enjoyable cinematic experience.

2001 alters the relationship between sound and the image, expands the technical possibilities of the medium and exists, in simple terms, as an example of cinema in its purest yet most optimistic and limitless terms.
Tarantino has constructed a highly artificial screen world in which to unfold his funky baroque bloodbath.

The sharp edges and shadowy crevices were smoothed off and filled in before this one made it to the screen, the superficial and bland two hours that remain leave no lasting impression.
Ginger Snaps finally represents nothing more than an overwhelming example of missed opportunity.

Singer has attempted to be true to his characters, and his intentions are well founded.

I really wanted to like Solaris, but it offers very little, and will inevitably fall upon the barren ground in between commercial success and critical acclaim because it isn't courageous enough in its execution to appeal strongly to members of either camp.

A musical comedy with more power chords than Jimmy Page.
