Be very patient, sidetrack history, don't look for the artistry of Lagaan, and you might just like this.
This one might just end up as the great summer let-down.
Aamir Khan is stupendous as the rule-breaker Rancho. But the rest of the cast doesn't remain in the shadows.
What uplifts the film is its very simplicity, sensitivity and its performances.
The film has an impeccable first half and could do with some editing in the second half. But the high drama, the arresting performances and the spunky audio track make NOKJ a memorable viewing.
Are we complaining? Not really, because the film's meant to be mad, mindless and zany. And we are meant to be happy, headless and nostalgic.
All in all, Ghajini is a thoroughbred Bollywood film which celebrates the formula with panache.
Go have a blast.
Dhoom 2 brings to Bollywood its first full blown action flick where the adrenalin just keeps pumping and jumping and the daredevilry almost outstrips Hollywoodian heights.
The jibes are gentle, the tenor is fond, yet firm. But most importantly, the characters are completely real: feisty and flawed, even as the end is exhilarating.
It's all done with an infectious zest and effervescence that keeps the ribs tickling.
Go celebrate the cornball comic display by Salman Khan.
Great performances by a bunch of unknowns, a gritty pace and a marvellous restraint make Chakde India an unbridled ode to patriotism without any hysterical chest-beating.
Rest assured, you're in for a merry ride, with loads of thrills, emotional banter, romance and camaraderie between a host of characters who seem to be having as much fun as you.
For anybody who wants to know what is the on-screen definition of Bollywood (read popular mainstream Hindi cinema), Dabangg is truly text book fare.

Don 2 is a classic action/crime thriller that doesn't let go, even for a moment. More importantly, the plot has been finely crafted, with every twist and turn falling into place like a complicated albeit neat little jigsaw.
Once Upon A Time In Mumbaai offers you both substance and soul, even as it dabbles with a slice of reality. Don't miss it.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Mumbai (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film is brimming over with scenes that relentlessly move you to tears, not because they are sad, but because they are uplifting, inspirational and just sometimes heart-rending.
The rest is one miserable rigmarole, where Tusshar and Shreyas try to infuse some madcap moments in the tedium, while the rest of the people just keep screaming and running.
Great action, riveting drama, real dilemmas and interesting characters... X-Men: First Class is fun all the way.
Explosive and highly entertaining.
Christopher Nolan might just end up as the most alluring and enigmatic film maker of contemporary cinema.
It has a feel of kitsch, despite the director's attempts to sculpt it as a racy thriller.
In an industry where sequels rarely work, the Golmaal franchise seems to have struck gold with its formula of making sense out of nonsense.
Post interval, you end up restless. And fidgety. Because nothing really connects.
Stitches is bursting at the seams with good ideas, but director Conor McMahon stumbles when it comes to the execution.
A movie populated by dislikeable characters and written/directed with no aplomb whatsoever ...
It's a concept with decent comedic potential, but the script from Martin Petit and Ken Scott (who also directs) rarely raises more than a titter.
The ultimate boss battle rivals anything you might have seen in Zack Snyder's similarly ludicrous 300, and the stage is set for yet more ridiculous Pandey adventures further down the line.
A shoddy, muddled film.
In dire need of a keen editor, and perhaps some clearer subtitling.
By the time an extremely misjudged 9/11 montage swings into view, you'll be wishing they'd just let the photograph speak for itself.
Weighed down by a script that relies heavily on Shrek-like modern snarkiness in period garb for its laughs, but without any Shrek-like jokes.
[There is] a sense of relief when the credits finally roll.

There's a certain last-act development that feels a bit forced considering this otherwise relaxed tone, but it's hard to bear a grudge when the rest of the film is pulled off with such naturalistic grace.
The songs that remain feel like last minute inclusions, the force of their lyrics lessened through ropey translation.
It's left to LaBeouf to carry the main weight of the story, and as such your enjoyment of the film will depend on whether you find his brand of wide-eyed earnestness endearing or irritating.
A kids' film horror fans can sink their teeth into...
An out-and-out failure.
Yuma is trying so obviously to be the Slavic Scarface - and, for a good portion of the running time, it earns that title.
You don't really need jokes when you've got a ginger 'tache, a silly voice and a big fat woman swearing, do you?
If the film is intended as a viciously satirical jab at Hollywood gentrification, it certainly hits its mark. It just isn't at all enjoyable to watch.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, this collection of video nasties will ensure you'll want to sleep with the light on, and be glad you converted to DVD.
Through his dealings with politicians and businessmen in both countries, Brügger exposes startling levels of corruption and deceit.
Thankfully the cats save the day, and additional credit goes to Ogigami for steering clear of romcom conventions.
It's simply a well-executed, highly enjoyable summer popcorn movie, which is exactly what it should be.

From the outset, The Cold Light of Day purports to be nothing more than a by-the-numbers action thriller. What's shocking is how it manages to take this predictable-but-sturdy template and sell it short.
An enjoyable but less than totally absorbing linear adventure.
Frankenweenie is obviously the work of a filmmaker still getting to grips with his craft, but is hugely enjoyable nontheless.
An indispensable and moving piece of filmmaking.

Unfortunately both the story and the effects take a slide into silliness in the third act, as the open-ended short lurches into a melodramatic conclusion that chimes with del Toro's taste for fairytale excesses.
An intriguing cinematic spectacle: an awful film that seems aware - nay, aggressively boastful - of its own awfulness.

Directors John Mitchell and Jeremy Kipp Walker never seem to do much more than point and shoot, but in such a character-led film (made with obvious care and affection), that's a strength rather than a weakness.
A film that succeeds in both its low key premise and extraordinary conclusion ...

Hellion deserves to be seen for the adolescent Wiggins' performance alone - with echoes too of Jennifer Lawrence's turn in Winter's Bone, it'd be gratifying to see his career take a similarly meteoric turn.
A character - and film - overburdened with poetic profundity.
The cinematography is spectacular, the soundtrack is decent (if relentlessly upbeat) and your little monkeys will most likely leave the cinema infused with a lust for nature.
At the very least, you'll walk away from A Story of Children and Film with an additional 50 or so movies to add to your watch list.
movie_title: A Story Of Children And Film (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Poor dialogue, wooden acting and a lack of originality are the major sins which scupper this pseudo-cerebral neo-noir from Jorge Dorado.
Those who stick with it ... will find much to enjoy: one tense, lengthy sequence does an exceptional job of wrong-footing the audience, while the conclusion is satisfyingly well-constructed.
The effects-heavy finale goes some way to reinforcing the film's horror credentials, and a minor epilogue revives a dash of comedy, but it's an imperfect end to an adventure that started off so well.

Calvary is a reasonably good analysis of Irish Catholicism's role in the age of atheism, but it's much more valuable for its depiction of a good man attempting to live and die by his own set of morals.
The Congress asks profound questions about performance and identity, especially how the former might distort our perception of the latter, and of reality in general.
What Lucia Puenzo leaves us with is a story that's well-made without being overly memorable.
There's lots to love about Salvo.
Lindholm could arguably be praised for succeeding in making the audience experience his characters, but a more stringent editor would have given the film a much keener sense of pace.
A beautiful and accomplished film.
Tublen's last-act feels like a purposefully cheap gag, but LFO is nevertheless a consistently humorous lo-fi sci-fi story.
Teen sitcom-level dialogue, wooden acting, snogging-in-the-rain flashbacks and ludicrously chrome-plated alien racecars.
By and large Steinman's shooting style is both sympathetic and unobtrusive, complemented by cinematographer Sevan Matossian's eye for humanity among these vast, unforgiving landscapes.
Oh, Josh Duhamel - is there nothing you can do?
Even that hoariest of old staples, the romantic downpour, is fresh and exhilarating this time round.
A highly enjoyable Bollywood-take on the superhero action genre, with a hefty dose of wushu-style wirework added in.

Cattet and Forzani's approach is a little too exhausting to be completely enjoyable, but they deserve credit for managing to marshal some sense of narrative resolution by the end, when they might have just left the audience floundering in oblivion.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At 90ish minutes, the film hardly outstays its welcome, but it'd be interesting to see what Florence could do with a leaner edit - and maybe an extra 20 quid or so.
It's the sort of thing that can play out well in prose, but ends up being dreadfully dull on film.
Noah Baumbach's study of family dysfunction is poignant, disturbing, and more mature than his earlier film on the same theme, The Squid and the Whale.
That rare period piece in which characters and their relationships are rendered with as much precision and detail as the set and costumes.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jirí Hubac's script is a gem. His characters are engaging, intimate and the dialogue is realistic and greatly moving. The scope of the Silberstein family is large and we grow attached to their lives, full of strength, warmth and vitality..

It is the quintessential version of the story of the classic mythic hero, one who begins as underdog without a chance, and faces insurmountable challenges and hurdles to become a champion, doing it all with grace, grit and style.
movie_title: The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg (2000)

movie_review_blurb: ...a rich melange of tumultous and sensual events. The story, acting, direction, set design and costuming fluidly combine to give a passionate portrait of living and loving on the edge of despair in a place and time where there was no tomorrow.

... a light, yet engrossing piece. Lux, now in her eighties, does a great combination act as narrator, Jewish grandmother and subject - taking us through a film that is part biography, part entertainment and part history.

What emerges is an unsettling picture of childhood innocence combined with indoctrinated prejudice. Promises is a compelling piece that demonstrates just how well children can be trained to live out and carry on their parents' anguish.

One of the best things about "Real Women" is exactly that %u2013 the real sized women (and men) who fill out this endearing coming-of-age story with a physical and emotional robustness that puts the Hollywood size-three's to shame.
Some would say that it's 'Schadenfreude,' a fascination with disaster, that keeps us watching...But this film provides rare insight into the failure of a American family...
Overall the talking heads do a great job - as in "How Quantum Physics Can Change YOUR Life!" The same can't be said for the storyline, which leaves much to be desired.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: With its usual twist, it's surprising that The Cobweb hasn't become a cult classic. This '50's studio picture combines the ever popular Hollywood topic of mental illness with interior decorating.

Films like Southern Comfort do what even legislation cannot: they seep into our consciousness, and work their way into our collective growth until the establishment and mainstream society finally relent and expand their viewpoint of what constitutes human
The film's focus is not just the all-consuming power of individual addiction, but the cancerous economic depression felt in all the Mississippi River towns the pair pass through.
The sheer volume of information means that much of the dialogue feels exposition-heavy, but the performances ensure it never becomes sluggish.
This is undoubtedly Ronan's coming-of-age role, and she conveys Eilis's quiet strength in the face of huge emotional turmoil without a hint of melodrama.

Suffragette is a piece of living history, a celebration of how far we've come but also a stark reminder that, despite the best efforts of these pioneering women, we still have some distance left to go.
The experiences and stories - which have all been gathered from the US and UK - are extremely similar and, while initially frightening, the effect is quickly eroded by repetition.
A visually exhilarating, profusely congratulatory reflection of Zemeckis' personal belief that Petit is an artist, and someone whose accomplishment deserves nothing but celebration.
Make no mistake, this is a love story as tender, passionate and powerful as any you're likely to see.
It alternates between horror and comedy, without convincing at either.
Legend has one insurmountable flaw: it's just too glossy.
Turner is solid, if perhaps miscast, with beguiling screen presence and the strength to (mostly) avoid succumbing to the teeth-gnashing melodrama of her character's situation.
The cast do what they can.
Impossible to take seriously.
The boogeyman is terrifying in prospect - and in glimpses - but so much screen-time is given to his looming bulk that he is divested of all his fear factor.
There is not a single weak link amongst the impressive ensemble cast, who keep up with Thorne's powerful dialogue as it ricochets around the room with increasing tempo.
Gender stereotyping aside, The Gift is an otherwise accomplished debut feature with far more ambition than standard genre fare.
The story trips over itself at every turn.
A thoroughly daft thriller that fails to reach the heights of its source material.
Slick, accomplished and hugely entertaining, another slice of glorious mayhem from a franchise that continues to play to its strengths and deliver the goods.
Bombastic, organic and utterly original, Tangerine is not just a film, it's a vital, visceral experience.
All told, this is blunt, offensive filmmaking that should have no place in modern cinema.

Yarris was at the mercy of a faceless machine he could not understand, let alone control. Now, over 30 years since his arrest, Sington's captivating, compelling film offers him the most poetic of justice.
Remainder is a strikingly original, hypnotic film and, by the time it reaches its bold head-scratcher of a denouement, one that leaves an indelible mark.
While it may be packed with whip-smart, endlessly quotable dialogue and laugh-out-loud moments, its enduring popularity undoubtedly stems from the fact that it has genuine heart.
While it may be a film of commendable high ambition, ultimately Traders is just another grim urban fairy tale about the ridiculous games of deeply unlikeable men.
Watching these men engage in one foolish game after another is at first mildly amusing then quickly dull ...
Queen of Earth plays like a horror. Yet, at its heart it is a devastating story of depression and its impact.
A body swap thriller whose high-minded ambition is overwhelmed by a preposterous story and a reliance on action clichés.
A film that speaks to the universal realities of the female experience.
The Daughter eschews melodrama to become a searing, poignant and devastating study of the seismic power of betrayal.
Hilditch's apocalyptic vision is striking in its visuals, bold in its bleakness and completely unoriginal in its core narrative.
Knight of Cups becomes the very thing it claims to satirise, a gilded chalice that reveals itself to be an entirely empty vessel.
Favreau has achieved the near impossible, managing to stay true to both Kipling's tales and Disney's revered 1967 animation, while offering something entirely new.
Silva succeeds in keeping his characters sympathetic and their relationships honest, if unconventional, and his approach is bolstered by some terrific performances.
The cast is brilliant across the board, particularly Richard Elis as the uber-Welsh Gareth, but Black Mountain Poets belongs to Lowe and Wells.
Court is a masterful piece of social cinema that rewards audience investment and marks Tamhane out as a filmmaker to watch.
Aims for the claustrophobic chills of Rosemary's Baby, but comes closer to the outlandish bunny boiler camp of Fatal Attraction.
The Survivalist is a stunning, thought-provoking film that, despite its bleak focus, has a surprisingly uplifting message about the power of human connection.
[Has] an uneasy, jingoistic tone ...
The film derails long before it lumbers to its tasteless denouement.
A beguiling, meditative study of the indelible link between memory and identity, and the transformative power of love.
It's a fascinating story but, as a film, lacks focus and momentum, playing more like a creative experiment than a finished product.
A fascinating watch, and an interesting exploration of the age-old battle between art as creative endeavour and as commercial, and political, enterprise.
Part human drama, part comedy of errors, All About Them stays on the right side of Carry On-style farce thanks to the authenticity of its characters.
movie_title: All About Them (A Trois, On Y Va) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A bold, inspired and entirely unique piece of British cinema, London Road is absolutely unmissable.
The power of Ava DuVernay's astonishing film comes from its understanding of the limits of King's work as much as its celebration of his achievements.
Plays like a straightforward police procedural, buoyed by the intense dynamic between Fan and Gwei and a visual inventiveness that makes far more of an impact than its story.
movie_title: Bai ri yan huo (Black Coal, Thin Ice) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of treating this illness in the subdued, reverential tones usually reserved for such themes, director Bryn Higgins wisely embraces the jagged edges of Lily's psyche.
Focus on the performances and there's much to like here.
King has both paid homage to Paddington's roots and made him relevant for a modern audience.
While it may prove frustratingly mundane for some, thanks to its intrinsic humanness Sacro GRA has a quiet power despite its crumbling aesthetic.
It's frustrating to see yet another bland collection of clichés being served up in the name of horror.
Moss allows the natural facets of this story to shine through, creating a gem of a documentary that's raw, honest and brutally relevant.
Plot and character development are ultimately as redundant as the monsters themselves.
It is so convoluted, so bogged down by its own sense of worth, that it simply collapses under its own weight.
While it's certainly social commentary, Gone Too Far is also a breath of fresh air in the often stifling stable of British sociorealism.

Too one-dimensional to be a character study, and too dull to be a thriller, The Calling is disappointing not just because of its bland, procedural tone but also because it completely wastes a truly impressive cast.
An involving, Hitchcockian tale of a persecuted man fighting for redemption against the most unlikely of circumstances.
It ultimately succumbs to the conventions it's attempting to lambast.
Unmistakably an exercise in style over substance.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Even the star power of the lovely Ms Green can't help Cracks escape the melodramatic doldrums.
Like Yi herself, the film may seem at times rather naïve in its outlook, but it's also honest and entertaining.

In this new, post-Michael Moore age of documentary filmmaking as lucrative big-screen fare, a documentary that educates without condescension, informs without bias and entertains without losing its focus is a valuable commodity.
As a piece of small-scale British filmmaking it's an interesting enough diversion.
Social commentary with a video game mentality. Intriguing, if not entirely successful.
Summer Scars develops into something altogether more disturbing, with a climax as brutal as any Hollywood slasher.
A colourful portrait of Nepal as a country driven by ancient tradition, yet also embracing necessary change.
A charming celebration of the beautiful game.
A film which, given its story and cast, is surprisingly pedestrian.
While it may be a colourful human study, the film also proves to be something of a frustration.

At the centre of it all, lanky newcomer Walpole gives a remarkable, sympathetic performance as a boy on the cusp of manhood, struggling with the pressures of a small-town environment and a half-formed desire for something more.
Disney's futuristic family adventure is not just solid summer entertainment, but also one of the most forward-thinking films to come out of any major studio.
Perhaps this is entirely the point, but Still ultimately feels like an interesting idea that's been beaten into submission by a filmmaker looking to make an impact, rather than tell a story.
Despite their differences, this melting pot of people is so intriguing, so fundamentally likeable, that the requisite happy ending, although somewhat forced, is entirely welcome.
Hardy is excellent, his mix of strength and compassion giving genuine depth to a character who could simply have been a figurehead for the march of change.
A powerful study of the personal battles being fought behind myriad nondescript doors.
A solid entry in the enduring stable of Latin American social cinema.
Something Must Break falls over itself at every turn and, eventually, collapses under its own emotional weight.
movie_title: Nånting måste gå sönder (Something Must Break) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With Wild Card, Statham may finally have overplayed his hand.

Despite the unimaginable hardships to which it bears witness, My Name is Salt is not an expose of exploitation or suffering ... but a surprisingly uplifting celebration of exceptional human achievement.
An essential watch.
With her expert observational touch, director Susanne Bier has turned this psychological drama into something that cuts far deeper, right into the heart of the family.
Maidan is a vibrant, fitting and entirely humbling celebration of all those who dare to speak out.
Two Night Stand is as generic as they come.
An adaptation of Australian author Tim Winton's 2005 collection of short stories, The Turning is a beguiling piece of storytelling.
While it might be good to be bad, Suicide Squad is just plain awful.
Whatever you think you know about the band known as the Manics, you're probably wrong.
movie_title: No Manifesto: A Film About Manic Street Preachers (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The ultimate message of staying true to oneself may be familiar, but the emotional journey is raw and real.
Both Thwaites and McGregor are fine performers, but JR and Brendan are drawn in such broad, obvious strokes that it's impossible to get under the skin of their dynamic.
Lyne's passionate knowledge is obvious from the well-researched clips, which he pieces together like a thematic jigsaw to present a sweeping overview of the genre.
Such apocalyptic events are nothing new on-screen, but Norwegian director Roar Uthaug imbues his film with rather more grit and texture than formulaic Hollywood efforts like 2012 and San Andreas.
Plays like an extended Republican Party election broadcast, complete with relentless handheld camera carnage and beating jungle drum soundtrack.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A film that, while fairly traditional in its approach, is a fitting homage to these extraordinary men.
In exploring the genesis of iconic female superhero Wonder Woman, writer-director Angela Robinson has crafted a film that is as empowering as it is entertaining.
Shot in muted tones, Norway's untamed beauty reflects the character's own wild nature, a side of herself that becomes increasingly difficult to hide.
Nimbly striking a balance between fun flashback and serious discussion, 78/52 is an engaging and insightful companion piece to a truly influential piece of cinema.
If Jungle plays like another slice of survival porn, it doesn't diminish the inspirational true story that lies at its heart.
A poetic study of familial relationships straining and strengthening under the pressure of serious illness.
Considine's strong central performance gives the film an emotional resonance.
Hickey effectively uses the roller dance culture of LA's Venice Beach as a microcosm through which to explore uncomfortable truths about the country's attitudes to minority communities.
While Foxtrot plays as something of a comedy of errors, it also makes some biting political points.
While it may stare death square in the face, the film is a true celebration of a life well-lived, both for its protagonist and its incomparable star.
A film that's as dramatically restrained and emotionally inaccessible as the period it depicts.
By keeping things simple and playing to its strengths, Ghost Stories remains an exhilarating and entertaining experience.
Masterful in its craft and elegant in its message, it doesn't simply replicate the themes and ideas of the first film, but builds on them in ways that are both authentic and inventive.
Entertaining, insightful and pertinent, The Reagan Show is no nostalgic trip down memory lane; rather, it's a timely reminder that, in modern politics, all the world's a stage (or a Twitter feed).
A straightforward (and entirely unnecessary) rehash which proves utterly dead on arrival.

Japanese filmmaker Atsuko Hirayanagi explores the transformative power of human connection in Oh Lucy!, a film which seems to play like a standard culture clash comedy but reveals itself to run significantly deeper.
Sickly sweet and tough to swallow, romantic comedy Home Again is a jagged little pill of contrivance and cliché that entirely wastes the talents of lead actress Reese Witherspoon.
Any narrative improbability or twinges of melodrama are overcome both by the striking performances and the visceral, immersive filmmaking.
An infuriating exercise in cacophonous style over substance.
While its story is not new, it is sensitively told, and this nuanced approach, together with compelling performances, helps lift this film above the usual family drama.
Anchored by an astonishing central performance from newcomer Mputu, Félicité overcomes its less successful elements to become an intense, intriguing character study of a fascinating woman.
This potentially intriguing exploration of the sharp angles of brotherhood is diluted into something altogether more generic.
Immediate and visceral, Mudbound boasts powerful, and devastating, contemporary relevance.
Tone-deaf, mean-spirited and woefully unfunny, Daddy's Home 2's biggest offence is that it's being marketed as a family-friendly holiday comedy.
Gillespie has imbued his film with black humour, while never undermining the authenticity of the characters or detracting from the abuse that runs through the story.
Intriguing and inspiring, she is something of a feminist hero; not just because of her incredible life story, but also her refreshing, determined and decidedly modern outlook.

Inspired by a real-life incident, Swedish writer-director Tarik Saleh's blistering third narrative feature is a straightforward police procedural that packs a powerful punch thanks to its incendiary political backdrop.
Its simple yet revealing title indicates the dramatic depths into which debut filmmakers, the self-taught twins Damiano and Fabio D'Innocenzo, will dive with such impressive style.
For a story concerned with exploring the furthest reaches of both space and the human mind, Native is both derivative and bland.
Draws on archive footage, psychology and film theory to present a multi-faceted portrait of a complex man.
movie_title: In the Realm of Perfection (L'empire de la perfection) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A journey of romantic discovery which, while occasionally skirting close to darker issues, plays like a charming, if meandering, meet-cute road movie.
This personal approach gives the film a sharp intimacy, and from here Greenfield pulls out to reveal how similar patterns are reshaping lives and families the world over.

Despite the film's inherent shock value, Lords Of Chaos still manages to successfully mine the explosive psychology of adolescent angst - even if the horror movie aesthetics occasionally threatens to overwhelm proceedings.
The curse of the Stephen King adaptation strikes once again in Cell, an insipid and often ludicrous adaptation of the author's 2006 tech-horror novel.
Anderson has turned in an idiosyncratic character study that's cut from the same cloth as post-war melodrama, but has a modern style all its own.
A viewing experience that is not so much the study of a man but a sensory immersion; a journey of sweat and blood and steadfast resolution that is keenly, painfully felt.
The Queen of Fear combines humour and emotion to explore the emotional complexities of modern living.
Compelling human drama - as well as political commentary that is searing without ever having to soapbox.

Westwood: Punk, Icon, Activist uses interviews, archive footage and intimate fly-on-the-wall access to get (almost) to the heart of this remarkable woman; although one suspects that Westwood will always keep some secrets firmly up her sleeve.

Barker takes a simple premise and, through nothing more than some solid editing and a clear-eyed focus, creates an insightful and surprisingly moving snapshot of one of the most tumultuous events in recent political history.
[An] insightful exploration of the difficult realities of life for those who don't conform to widely accepted norms, and its celebration of the power of human connection - whomever we may be.
Asensio's beguiling performance keeps the film on track as it builds to an audacious denouement that comes out of the leftfield.
Jane is both a stunning celebration of nature and insightful study of our changing relationship with the world around us.
An insightful and sensitively-handled exploration of how a single event can leave an indelible psychological mark.
Plays like a fairly standard teen drama with a surprisingly unpleasant sting in the tale.
Stuffed with slapstick and fuelled by an energetic soundtrack, the GGI/live action feature Peter Rabbit is sure to appeal to the youngsters at which is it aimed.
By betting everything on the chemistry between its two leads, a tired formula and by-the-numbers action, The Hitman's Bodyguard misses the mark.
Begins as fly-on-the-wall travelography but soon becomes something much more intimate and eye-opening.
While Us and Them may be simplistic and outlandish in approach, there's no arguing with the rampant injustice onto which it shines such a harsh light.

The Chamber is an undeniably tense watch with a subversive, gut-punch ending. While not plumbing any real genre depths, it should prove a solid and lucrative calling card for its clearly talented debut director.
A Quiet Passion becomes both a celebration of the creative spirit, and a poignant reminder of its fragility.
An intriguing non-fiction essay on the shape-shifting nature of love.
Doss's truly Herculean endeavours rise above the clichés, providing depth of drama and character.

If Motherland has a message beyond raising awareness of the plight faced by millions of Filipino women, and the ongoing debate around the country's controversial Reproductive Health Act, it's that life goes resolutely on.
Despite its convenient Hollywood ending, The Young Offenders remains defiantly home-grown, grass roots cinema; and is all the more enjoyable for it.
A mix of gung-ho action and heavy-handed patriotic pride, the point of South Korean war film Operation Chromite may be somewhat lost in translation for western audiences.
A moving portrait of the effects of war on ordinary lives.
Both story and characters are ethereal to the point of frustration, with no backstory or detail to bring any real context to the drama that unfolds.
As a portrait of a man, it's ugly; as an insight into modern politics, it's both astute and damning.
Despite the talent involved, The Light Between Oceans is mawkish when it should be moving.

While Herzog - whose longstanding passion for volcanoes is palpable, and infectious - is never anything less than respectful to these individuals, an undeniable sense of whimsy runs through his hugely entertaining voiceover.
It celebrates the very best traits of humanity ... while also encouraging us to confront life's biggest questions. This is filmmaking at its most powerful and profound.
The Handmaiden is part romance, part gothic fairy tale and part psychosexual chamber piece, an initially beguiling film whose heavy-handed love scenes work to undermine its dramatic power.
Fraught with tension and rife with intelligent insight.
With its abundance of archive video and still footage, together with a host of new interviews, it's an undeniably glorious watch.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Both an enjoyable animated adventure and a thoughtful allegory about the importance of pursuing one's dreams.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As painful memories are unearthed, and loyalties are tested, directing duo Julia Halperin and Jason Cortlund effectively mine the fractured family dynamic for maximum dramatic impact.
While Tormentero's narrative meanders, it finds a more focused voice in its striking visuals.
While the film proves a challenging watch it ultimately works because it recognises, and fully embraces, the fact that there is not one stock response to such an assault.
While this old-school creature feature may not win over non-horror fans, genre aficionados will undoubtedly find much to enjoy.
Four years after she made her debut in solid series opener The Conjuring, Annabelle has well and truly outstayed her welcome.
A portrait of adolescence composed in vibrant colour and astute detail.
Like perhaps no other film before, it brings home the brutality of Islamic State, and the threat it poses to ordinary, innocent people caught under its regime; and ... those who would escape it.
Two lives collide with devastating results in German filmmaker Nina Vukovic's impressive debut feature.
An intimate family drama which eschews the usual melodramatic trappings of such fare to explore the quietly devastating impact of a husband's infidelity on those closest to him.

This modern David and Goliath tale shines a light not only on the injustices heaped upon Abacus, but also the systematic targeting of marginalised immigrant communities by an establishment desperate to protect the status quo.
A deeply personal exploration of the extremes of human behaviour, with a lean, real-world sensibility that makes it easy to empathise with the notion of survival at any cost.
Provost tells a heartfelt story extolling the virtue of forgiveness and showing how the concept of family can extend beyond blood ties.

Betting the house on a narrative flush with crude antics was always going to be a risky gamble. And, despite the best efforts of enthusiastic stars Amy Poehler and Will Ferrell, it doesn't come close to paying off.
Compelling viewing.
Hard-hitting in subject, but skillfully sidesteps the soapbox to become an involving human drama.
Even the captivating presence of Marion Cotillard can't save From the Land of the Moon from succumbing to embarrassing histrionics.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling snapshot of a region desperate for change, but still in danger of being suffocated by both its history and political inertia.

It's hard to know for whom it's been made; while very young kids may appreciate its visual bombast in short doses, older children will likely find themselves tiring of both its charmless, outdated animation and the dull, underbaked narrative.
A mature and moving study of childhood, growth and identity.
Aftermath becomes a study of grief that, despite occasional moments of mawkishness, is anchored by raw honesty.
A small film with big ambitions and an even bigger heart, A Moving Image has a message that goes beyond its limited scope.

The mystery of a supposed alien abduction combines with the potency of adolescence in Alex Taylor's striking debut, which turns wilful narrative ambiguity and visual experimentation into a sharp-eyed study of the modern teen experience.
A solid take on a fascinating story.
As solid and watchable as Evans is, it's not enough to lift Gifted above movie-of-the-week territory.
Watching Walken ham it up was a treat as always, but a few gleeful minutes of watching him tap dance is hardly worth three hours of anyone's life.
Dominik's presentation of events is original and thought-provoking.
Writer/director Teplitsky has a great eye for detail and often manages to say a lot by saying very little.
It features boring cliches and a positively awful leading lady.
Just One of the Guys is worth repeated viewing, especially for Hyser's hilarious and charismatic performance.
For the most part, the movie is goofy fun.
Deserves its accolades for, if nothing else, setting a tone for Australian filmmakers and reaching a level to which they should now aspire.

While there are more than a couple moments of tenderness, which most parents and children will be able to relate to, the great intentions "I Am I" may have had with its intimate story of bonding fall far too short.
Aaron Swartz wanted to make the world a better place, and this documentary makes sure you never forget that.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Carlos Marques-Marcet's stirring feature debut "10,000 KM," about a relationship getting tested by long distance, takes a minimal approach in wrestling with the emotional demons borne when a long-term couple get separated for a year.

Tired, lazy, incongruous, shocking and hilarious in all the wrong places, "Rage" is destined for the graveyard television slot, squeezed between infomercials for mops. Perhaps there is a good drinking game in here somewhere.
"Alive Inside" contains a tiny revolution within its message, and will likely end up being one of the most important documentaries of the year.
Despite these missteps, The Giver should still be pleasing to the specific target audience to whom it's aimed.

"Open Windows" may fail to collide several worlds together in order to relay a message about the one world we're living in today, but the construction is clever enough to keep you interested until the end.
The gnawing sense of failed potential is inescapable. Similar to its title character, "Han Gong-ju" is beautiful, brave and ambitious but ultimately too damaged to blossom into greatness.
This the kind of overly manipulative, Hallmarky picture that's too busy overdosing on saccharine and smarm to flesh out any of its characters, or make a single spoken word of dialogue resonate.

The theories in "Level Five" simultaneously thrive in realms of computer science, ethnography, and cognitive psychology, while the picture remains cloaked by the emotional weight of a historical tragedy that marked an entire nation.

If you enjoyed the first trip, there is no reason you won't enjoy the second. It's familiar enough with its brand of improvisational humor, but just different enough (apart from the location) to stretch out the expiration date.

You'll walk away feeling sombre and slightly downtrodden but, thanks to a handful of strong performances and a strong emotional core, the central debate will linger in your mind, which is exactly what "Lullaby" sets out to do.

You'd do well not to take "The Harvest" too seriously, but like its deliciously simple and 70s B-movie horror title suggests, as a wickedly fun time. And we'd bet that John McNaughton wouldn't have it any other way. Good to have you back, sir.

"The Grand Seduction" reeks of a pleasantness that makes for a very soothing watch. The lack of character depth and the contrived plot won't be placing it near any top ten lists, but there are far worse ways to spend two hours in a theatre these days.
"Phoenix"is as much a portrait of a woman longing to find herself again as a portrait of an entire nation longing for a way to re-build.
In any case, "Haemoo" is a picture worth seeing for its thrills, scrupulous tension-building and mischievous genre twists that will have you gasping one second, and laughing the next.

"Samba" is a love story set in a contemporary world brimming with immigration issues, but it manages to be neither political drama, nor bubbly romance, somehow getting away with being labeled as a comedy.
Apart from the performances, there is nothing much to latch onto in "The Riot Club." The bitter sense of humor entertains, but overstays its welcome halfway through.
Bordering on the bland, stepping into Hallmark territory on a number of occasions, this love-filled biopic still managed to melt most of our reservations away.

Ullmann's version of "Miss Julie" exists in a special cinematic category; it's toxic, it's hypnotic, and passionately translates Strindberg's genius instinct for enlightening the multi-layered psychological spectrums of human desire for lust and power.

Uninspired films utilizing cinematic devices that felt old decades ago are a regrettable part of the cinematic viewing experience, and "The Forger" squarely falls into this category. Even Travolta is better than this.
Despite the valiant efforts from the two leads, the only thing of value that gets robbed in "American Heist" is our time.

It's not perfect, but as far as feature debuts go, there's very little you can fault "Adult Beginners" for. Slightly pedantic and maudlin at times, with telegraphed metaphors and rushed pacing, it's still hard to call any of these hiccups major flaws.
A work of immense and intense emotional vigor, sprinkled with fun-loving traits and intellectually stimulating prowess, "The Duke of Burgundy" is the stuff dreams are made of.
If you have enough patience, especially if you find yourself tapping your feet to the beats, you'll discover an emotional journey of a young man's entrance into adulthood.

The probing of the gray areas of morality are reminiscent of "Gone Baby Gone," and Andreas' vertigo once he convinces himself to grip the reins of the high horse, open the doors for fascinating debates, even if the questions are slightly belittled.
In "Welcome to Me" we are spoiled by the comedic capabilities of Kristen Wiig, an expert doing what she does best. We wouldn't really want it any other way.
...Maidan is a rewarding experience and an alarmingly important wake-up call for those still in the dark about one of today's most critical situations.

Certainly not for casual viewing, Costanzo's "Hungry Hearts" cloaks conventional narrative structure with a suspense more in line with Roman Polanski than Alfred Hitchcock, and should leave fans of tense cinema well nourished.
As far as the spy genre goes, Pierce Brosnan's "The November Man" is more filler than thriller.
First-time feature writer-director Shaun Kosta tackles romance with both reason and heart in mind and you can't help but respect that kind of reach for truth.
It's one of those rarities when too many compliments are not enough and the recommendation to see it as soon as it's near you cannot be stressed enough.
...the film loves itself so much it renders itself beautiful, but utterly shallow.
It's even hard to recommend "The Revenge Of The Green Dragons" to lovers of B-movie crime action films, because this is a whole different level of mess. Consider yourselves warned.

What makes The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby truly stand apart from all the other films of its kind...is the emotional depth that is allowed to be dug by the film's premise and length, executed almost perfectly
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What makes The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby truly stand apart from all the other films of its kind...is the emotional depth that is allowed to be dug by the film's premise and length, executed almost perfectly

It's drama, it's crime, it's a story of a family's survival against the struggle of life and even though it lacks the blood, gore, zombies and the monsters of the Fantasia Film Festival, Metro Manila is a horror story in its own unflinching way.
It is Nick Cassavetes' most adventurous and fun-loving film, in its own sense of freedom reminiscent of his father, the late great John Cassavetes.

The Dutch were not wrong in awarding it for its bravery, but the old maxim of whether the glass is half full or empty takes on a whole new meaning with Clip because the glass is shattered into pieces too small for reconstruction.

Adamson claims that this was a labor of love, but it leaves you with the feeling that it was made for those who've read the book, and in such a lackadaisical approach to storytelling that it's unlikely to attract new fans.
This is unprecedented stuff right here, on a topic so volatile it feels like it's just waiting to explode. And as a film, it's effective - for the most part.
Diez has created one of the year's most scathing looks at one of the world's most misrepresented human acts
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If you find yourself in the mood for a black comedy about a guy who is definitely worse off than you are right now, The Husband is that guy.
