movie_review_blurb: It's set in a forbidding landscape at a dangerous time, and Cousineau and Ivalu show how companionship and shared tradition can go a long way toward sustaining people even in the face of personal devastation.
movie_title: Before Tomorrow (Le Jour avant le lendemain) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Undoubtedly, everything documentarian Darius Marder shows in his debut film Loot actually happened, but Marder's approach to this "truth is stranger than fiction" story is so forced that the movie feels phony.
Viewers will have to decide for themselves whether My Son is a terrible, terrible movie or an uncompromising Herzog experiment in reality-bending. Here's a suggestion: consider the track record.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's more clever than funny, but it's very clever.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Waiting For Armageddon lets a handful of the devout explain their worldview in greater detail, yet filmmakers Kate Davis, Franco Sacchi, and David Heilbroner don't go looking for the simple-minded or easily mockable.
The movie is unusually sensitive to the ways young people pick up their cues on how to act like adults, and how awkwardly they practice what they've learned.

Khrzhanovsky's tone is too whimsical at times, and his points about repression too leaden, but that often happens when a cartoonist dabbles in live-action. Anyway, Khrzhanovsky's approach improves the material far more than it hinders.
Jaud isn't telling a story so much as he's making a case, and while his case is persuasive, it doesn't really work as a movie.
movie_title: Nos enfants nous accuseront (Food Beware: The French Organic Revolution) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The "doing crime for fame" theme is more than a little played-out, but Hardy's so boisterous -- and Refn's filmmaking so dynamic -- that it's fairly easy to buy in to the inherent entertainment value of bloody fisticuffs.
The movie is visually stunning, deploying fluid camerawork and stark black-and-white imagery to record the hardscrabble lives of Venezuelans living and working on a remote salt marsh.

Lee doesn't reinvent the wheel when it comes to filming live theater, but he moves the camera artfully and edits with an energy that matches the music. And he makes good use of close-ups, capturing the sweaty faces of a troupe of remarkable performers.
Shane Meadows has a rare ability to convey the drama and humor of everyday life in well-observed, well-acted scenes that rarely drag on interminably or try too hard to dazzle.
The Way We Get By is neither pro- nor anti-war; it's a somber study of perpetually unsettled lives.
Madsen's action sequences are beautifully choreographed and shot, and the movie is packed with slick shootouts and narrow escapes, but it all lacks a certain oomph.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Think of Not Quite Hollywood as a vividly illustrated catalogue of astonishing smut.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Cove offers a lot to think about in terms of the future of fishing, and Psihoyos' gift for using fiction-feature conventions does make a seemingly unpalatable subject entertaining.
The movie goes out on a high, but until then, it plays almost like the pilot for a TV series. But it would be a good TV series.
Slick and respectable, and delivering old news.
Once [director] Stone drops the generalities and starts getting specific, Earth Days improves considerably.
What begins as a multilayered tale of scientific discovery and cultural history gets reduced to a single maudlin idea: that even Charles Darwin had to evolve.
Taxidermia is frequently funny, for those who can stomach it.
On that count, Timoner is correct: Harris is unduly obscure. But was what he accomplished really all that great?
It's one of those movies that plays to the cheap seats, making the racism bigger, the assimilation process rougher, and the family squabbles extra-broad, lest viewers miss the point.
Hardcore Disney fans will appreciate how serious-minded and intimate this movie is, but for others, Walt & El Grupo might feel like an expensive vacation slide show, assembled by strangers.
Crude is remarkably clear-eyed in the way it shows how even people on the right side of a cause only succeed if they're willing to play a little dirty.
Krasinski literalizes Wallace's stylistic love of asides too much, but it helps that he's aware enough of his movie's limitations to keep Brief Interviews blessedly short.

Capitalism is intended to convince Americans that they've bought into an economic system designed to screw them over, but the tone is so smart-ass that it's bound to put a lot of viewers into a default defensive posture.

A Serious Man is wholly a Coen brothers movie, in that it's full of exaggerated characters and comic cruelty, anchored to a way of looking at the world that seems to posit a fundamental absence of meaning.
An American Journey is short and scattered, and doesn't follow through often enough on its "catching up with The Americans 50 years later" premise.
The movie concludes with a series of tense, unpredictable scenes. Isn't that why we love sports so much, because we never know what will happen?
This is a smart, melancholy crime picture, which takes its cues from the title of the perverse old standard Christensen plays on her stereo at night: "You Always Hurt The One You Love."

Green definitely knows his way around a suspense sequence, but he needs to find a way to work those sequences into a movie that has its own organic life, and isn't so... well, please refer back to the title.

If a team of clever screenwriters tried to script a cautionary tale about the politics of fame (and the fame of politics), they likely couldn't come up with anything odder or more apt than Erik Gandini's documentary Videocracy.
The Father Of My Children is largely about how life drifts by, and how we don't always leave the mark in the world that we'd hoped, so Hansen-Løve resists the urge to overdramatize or over-stress.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As a Romero project, Survival Of The Dead is a frustrating disappointment, nowhere close to the director's classic '70s films -- though it is better than Romero's last "reboot" zombie effort, Diary Of The Dead.

By contrasting Hitchcock's explanation of "The MacGuffin" with TV commercials and old arguments over who's winning the Cold War, Grimonprez makes a case for how historical events can be driven by threats more perceived than actual.
Cropsey continues what's been a welcome trend this year toward documentaries with strong, surprising narratives.
Once again with the Duplasses, there just isn't enough of anything: not enough funny lines, not enough variation of mood, not enough plot.
Winterbottom captures the atmosphere of a dusty community where everyone knows everybody's history, and where money and power can only sway public opinion to a point.

The combat footage Junger and Hetherington got for Restrepo is unlike anything ever seen in a documentary; it's raw, relentless, and made all the more unsettling because neither the soldiers nor the audience can see who's doing the shooting.

What initially seemed like charming character eccentricities become more obviously random as the plot begins to zig and zag, as though Resnais were spinning a wheel to determine each scene's direction.
Douglas makes all the contrivances feel like universal, soul-testing dilemmas. He encourages the audience to lean in and watch him close, to pick up a few tips on how to look cool while melting down.
There isn't much to Alamar -- and González-Rubio sometimes seems to go out of his way to keep the film uncluttered by incident -- but it's short and agreeable...

Walker has something important to say with Countdown To Zero, but if this movie were standing on a doorstep with a petition, most reasonable people would sign it quickly and send it on its way, rather than inviting it in to chat.
So long as someone's making movies about stoic cranks with stubborn streaks, Robert Duvall will be able to find work.
Kline gives a wild, wonderful performance, reminiscent of his work on A Fish Called Wanda.
Aside from some overly jaunty soundtrack music, Smash His Camera assembles Galella's anecdotes smartly, and supports them well visually.
Blakeson finds ways to make good use of his assets: three talented actors, a few evocative locations, and a script that springs like a mousetrap.
Thank goodness Animal Kingdom is so stylish and sharply plotted.
A Film Unfinished is affecting as a rare document of a terrible place and time, and those who lived there.
Most of the material in this movie has been seen, heard, or read before, but never with this level of useful illustration.
As a character study, Farewell is rich enough to mitigate some of its ineffectiveness as suspense.
In almost every ... way, Change Of Plans is smart about the transformative pace of modern life.
movie_title: Change of Plans (Le Code a Changé) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie began life as a series of museum pieces, and it retains the transportive effect of a well-conceived exhibit.
Cox's character is a living, hissing embodiment of the idea that no good deed goes unpunished. As an actor stuck in a movie that wastes his talents, Cox can surely relate.
October Country veers awfully close to exploitation.
Ajami keeps asking: When do people cross the line? And when does pulling the trigger become a viable option?

Happy Tears is a complete mess of a movie, but Lichtenstein conjures some sweet moments and striking metaphors -- and none more striking than Posey's $500 boots, which look either black or blue, given the available light.
Thoroughly absorbing, exciting, even poetic.
Well-crafted and intense.
Like any good B-side, The Exploding Girl is engaging but rough, lacking the kind of polish that would make it a hit.
The low-boil mystery-thriller Stolen was once known as The Boy In The Box and then Stolen Lives, but now has a title as nondescript as its contents.
Mother considers the various ways children are shaped by their acquaintances -- who may not have their best interests at heart -- as well as by family members who mean well, but still make mistakes.

From the jokes about Hutton overreacting to his daughter's menstruation to the comic ruminations about the relative attractiveness of genitalia, Multiple Sarcasms often plays like a bad stand-up routine dramatized by serious actors.
Malloy mixes gorgeously grainy black-and-white and color footage of Jack and Meg White onstage and off; practically every shot in the movie could be blown up into a wall-sized poster.
movie_title: The White Stripes Under Great White Northern Lights (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Thorn In The Heart's home-movie-style images are frequently lovely and the film has flashes of poignancy, but Gondry never fully gets across why the specifics of this family history should interest anyone outside his circle.
The battle sequences [are] suitably intense, especially in the early going, when Li, Lau, and Kaneshiro, low on manpower, rely on wicked-looking traps and ambushes to get the job done.
In short: we see the Chess Records story simplified and telegraphed. But at least the cast doesn't act as though they're mired in the biopic muck.

Director Tom DiCillo does his damnedest to make his documentary about The Doors unwatchable, but the subject matter is too compelling -- and the vintage footage too electrifying -- to be completely worthless.

Though it's cool to hear the variety of the Iranian underground music scene (which encompasses heavy metal, blues, folk, hip-hop, and cabaret-pop, among other styles), No One Knows About Persian Cats is a drama largely devoid of, well, drama.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Just as a permanent record of a remarkable artistic movement, Exit Through The Gift Shop is valuable. But there's more going on here.
It's hard to knock any movie that opens with an eye-popping train robbery, followed by a balls-out siege, and then a super-cool heist.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Some people might find it distasteful to make a movie about guilty rich folks who give themselves permission to splurge. Others will rightly appreciate the honesty.

Vincere starts to run dry of stunning visual gambits and become redundant in its second hour, as the madhouse sequences dominate, but Bellocchio's central premise retains its power and poignancy throughout.

In her first movie since 2002's magnificent Morvern Callar, Ramsay continues her fascination with textures, at times reducing her lead character's world to impressionistic fragments: her hands, a wall, splashes of paint, et cetera.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Part quirky comedy, part existential mystery, part flash-mob musical.
The nested narrative structure gives the movie a sense of inevitability that makes it all the more powerful when Almaric's wife and kids try to figure out what could make him happy.
Schröder and Provaas frame their conversation well, making good use of the color, the reflective surfaces, and the surfeit of exposed younger flesh in the District.

The movie starts out rowdy, then turns more serious as the heroines confront their own weaknesses, and while both sides of Bachelorette come off as forced at times, the film is consistently funny, and Headland achieves a rare honesty.

Matthiesen and his cast have created a believable space, and that ultimately helps give Teddy Bear the tension of a fine suspense film once Kold sits down across the kitchen table from Steentoft to speak his mind at last.
Wylde has a scruffy wit not unlike a young Michael Keaton, and he and Anders make a winning pair as they tool around L.A., killing gangsters and guzzling booze and blood.
The film is about how the digital revolution has changed the ways moviemakers capture, edit, and manipulate images, and it gets practically every famous, relevant person on the record.
What primarily redeems the Inbetweeners movie is that it's so surprisingly tender and sweet.
Those with nothing are seduced by the prospect of something, such that they hesitate to complain, lest they end up with less than nothing.
There's a soul to these nesting and rhyming stories of ruthless killers and what motivates them to pick up their guns and knives -- and in some cases, gas cans.
There's plenty of real drama in this movie without Stern and Sundberg having to pump it up.
17 Girls has a nice look, and strong performances, but ultimately, the Coulins fail to go deeply enough into the heads of their protagonists.
There's a lot about the Michelin Guide and the restaurant industry that Three Stars barely touches in its too-broad overview.
movie_title: Drei Sterne - Die Köche und die Sterne (Three Stars) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is a "you know what would be cool?" movie that considers the real-world ramifications of its science-fiction whiz-bang, and a film of ideas that doesn't skimp on the action.

The story's fundamentals are solid, and the battles between this village of kung fu experts and an army of 19th century technophiles are so good that the inevitable sequel (already in the works) will be welcome.
The kind of open-ended, character-driven light melodrama that might've been better served as an HBO series.
The sports drama gives The Iran Job a strong hook, while the cultural context enriches the movie's real story, which is less about Sheppard's life in Iran than about the people he meets.
Quietly devastating.

This is a crime story with little to no interest in the who or the why, but only the what and the how. It's a reverse-procedural, tracking not the solution of a crime, but all of its awful particulars.
Despite the shagginess, Scorsese mostly stays focused on Harrison as a reflection of his fans, eternally searching for something elusive - something that only came around occasionally.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A fine, powerful piece of documentary filmmaking, using old-fashioned vérité techniques -- and more than a little audience manipulation -- to show how political influence and media savvy help the wealthy exert their will.
The acting is shaky, the scare scenes are fairly stock, and it takes way too long for Reynolds to put all his pieces in play, especially given that the movie doesn't have much of an ending.
Whenever Klown hits, it's hysterical.
As always with Hong's films, Oki's Movie goes through stretches where it seems aimless and self-indulgent, followed by stretches where it's sharp, funny, and poetic.

Adapting non-fiction to cinema can be tricky even for a documentarian, but Jennifer Baichwal makes a game effort at turning Margaret Atwood's book-length essay Payback: Debt And The Shadow Side Of Wealth into a movie.
At two and a half hours, Warriors Of The Rainbow has the shape of something weightier than the simplified good-vs.-evil movie it actually is.
movie_title: Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Fitzgibbon's cast is excellent, and the movie's animated interludes liven up what could've been thoroughly pat.
In a way, Patience is a lot like how one of its interview subjects describes an attempt to do Sebald's walk: He says he could retrace the steps, but not the experiences, or the revelations.
Full of life, heart, and funny little details about daily existence, as it meanders its way toward moments of real profundity.
It's best to imagine this movie as a study of three good young actors trapped in an indie film project with a yammering weirdo.
A broad period comedy that squanders a fascinating subject ... by refusing to see it from anything other than a modern, winking perspective.
The Other Son's setup is too contrived, carried along by conversations that are either confrontational or artificially elusive.
Quote not available.
The footage in Paul Williams Still Alive-old and new-is highly entertaining, even moving. But it's as though Kessler recorded the DVD commentary track first, then made the movie.
A lightly comic genre piece where not much happens and no one has much amusing to say.
The Artist Is Present does at least seem to capture moments where Abramovic seems genuine...
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Within the square framework, screenwriter Antoine O'Flatharta and director Thaddeus O'Sullivan are able to convey a lot about the atmosphere and attitude of a community in transition.
The movie is vibrant and modern, and doesn't treat Miigár as a mute, unknowable alien.
The jumble of characters and plotlines remain indistinct and removed throughout.
More horror movies set in the 21st century ought to integrate technology into their scares as well as Nicholas McCarthy's The Pact.

There isn't much to Union Square, but the movie does understand how people want to love their families on their own terms, forgetting that their families may be the only ones who really know who they are.
This new Bel Ami has a lot to recommend it, but it never seems as artful or smart as Dangerous Liaisons, the film it most resembles.
Even while The Day He Arrives doesn't come to much-at least not in comparison to some of Hong's other films, such as 2006's brilliant Woman On The Beach-it's still time well spent.
Maybe it takes an old pro like Levinson to show how an increasingly played-out genre can be improved.
The humor in Nature Calls tends toward the dopey and obvious ...
In Caesar Must Die, the characters are both actor and audience, looking at themselves through the lens of a centuries-old fictionalization of history.
Is this the stuff of gripping drama? Not at all. But like nearly all of Kiarostami's films, it's the stuff of good conversation.

Lots of films (and lots of books) have charted a boy's path to manhood. Bless Me, Ultima is special because it's about this boy, in this time and place, where his peers and elders are rushing to label him before he can forge his own identity.
Leviathan is an immersive experience, plunging viewers into darkness and chaos, amid a rush of vivid color and rapid movement.

Diaz ... emphasizes the uplifting aspects of Pineda's Journey experience, describing how he came from poverty and delinquency, before he dedicated himself to his craft, caught a lucky break, and became an inspiration to struggling nobodies everywhere.
What's lacking is a larger cultural, historical, and aesthetic context.

While this story might've been just as engaging in live action, Miyazaki's animation does clear away the extraneous detail, re-creating the world of 50 years ago and instilling it with the poignancy of a family snapshot.
This is a movie about a young woman figuring out what her identity should be, set against a time of dramatic change.
Gimme The Loot has an energy that's been missing from independent film lately. It's not dreary or quirky; not excessively stylish or stubbornly formless.
Director Marc Evans and screenwriter Laurence Coriat fumble both the musical side of their movie and the coming-of-age side.
The effect of Room 237 is intense. It's a deep dive into the rabbit hole of semiotics, designed to train viewers to become alert to what they're really seeing.
Blancanieves' plot is gimmicky, but Berger mainly uses it as a line on which to hang one craftily shot and cut setpiece after another ...
Before And After Dinner ... has a lot of value, because Gregory is such a remarkable individual whose career has gone under-recorded on film and video.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The movie can be repulsive at times, but Cronenberg is more interested in ideas than in blood and guts.
Zombie proves once again that he understands how many different ways there are to give an audience the creeps.
In The House bares the voyeurism inherent in all stories-and the class-consciousness inherent in voyeurism.
Unlike Kempner's previous documentary, The Life And Times Of Hank Greenberg, his latest has too much 'life' and not enough 'times.'
What little story there is has no sense of real life, no matter much the film pretends to be about children learning hard truths.
Koch doesn't try to do anything radical as a piece of filmmaking, but Barsky -- a former newspaper reporter -- covers Koch's story magnificently as a journalist.

Girls Against Boys is undone by Chick's apparent supposition that he's the first filmmaker to notice how men sometimes take advantage of women, or how putting a gun in an actress' hands can be a complicated symbol of empowerment.

John Dies At The End sometimes strains to live up to its midnight-movie reputation, but not every B-horror picture combines demonic creatures and ultra-violence with musings about what it means to be alive in a world that's getting more unreal by the day.
Kellstein gives viewers more or less the same show that the fans and gamblers get.
A bare-bones man-against-his-worst-fears white knuckler, shot through deep, menacing shadows.
It never expands its scope or meaning over the course of its two-hour running time. But the specifics make the story powerful regardless.

Drawing on his training in mime and his fascination with Gnosticism, Jodorowsky converted a story about a bizarre murderer into a grand work of art, full of symbols and imagery that reach beyond language to something primal and original.
The life story of a man who's led one hell of a fascinating life.
The movie becomes a character sketch, carried by its wealth of detail and a fantastic Carlyle performance.
Bana and Wilde sport bad Southern accents and deliver overly mannered dialogue while dropping hints about their abusive childhood.
In Our Nature lumbers a lot, especially early on, as Savelson introduces the cast and has Gilford and Slattery keep coming up with weak excuses to stall the movie's premise from kicking in.
And now for something almost completely useless.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Cumming and Dillahunt are so terrific-as is Isaac Leyva as their ward-that they pull Any Day Now up from its more maudlin and melodramatic elements.
They don't seem like real people savoring their youth, but rather like illustrations in a book about how the Beats behaved.
While Not Fade Away is undeniably a mess, it's a loveable kind of mess, where the missteps come from daring, not caution.

It's 134 minutes long, and substitutes loosely related situations for plot. But a few broadly comic moments aside, This Is 40 also captures the rhythms and concerns of real life in ways that slicker Hollywood comedies don't.
"Not overwritten" can easily shade into "underwritten," which is the case with Fairhaven.
Director Dante Ariola and writer Becky Johnston have such a strong idea at the core of Arthur Newman that it's all the more frustrating when they follow it down the most familiar path.
A movie largely devoid of attitude or suspense.
Luv is split right down the middle between preposterousness and truth, and between amateurishness and confidence.
Vasyukov and Herzog are united in their fascination with the particulars of how to thrive in some of the harshest conditions on Earth.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Impossible confirms that Bayona is a major talent, with a skill for constructing sequences that build tension as masterfully as Steven Spielberg did in his '70s heyday.
Throughout, Hazanavicius finds clever, poetic ways to illustrate the allure of Golden Age Hollywood stardom...
Given Besson's career-long affinity for visual flash and breathless storytelling, it's especially disappointing that The Lady is so ordinary.

It's probably unfair to pine for the movie a director didn't make, but it's disappointing that Nanni Moretti's Vatican dramedy We Have A Pope has so little to do with the actual selection process for a new pontiff.
Contrivances aside ... Janie Jones is one of the more realistic depictions of what the rock 'n' roll lifestyle is really like.
The best segments in Charlotte Rampling: The Look have less to do with the actress' musings on life and death and more to do with her exploration of artifice.
There's a difference between "funny" and "comedy," and the movie adaptation of Killing Bono tries way too hard to be nutty, at the expense of just getting across what McCormick knows.
The Conquest offers that familiar thrill of being allowed to peek behind the curtain and see what our leaders are really like...
The pleasure of The Love We Make comes from watching one of the most famous musicians in the world looking totally chill, whether he's rehearsing with his band or casually chatting with Bill Clinton.
Two feature films into her career, writer-director Céline Sciamma has proven unusually skilled at making short, plot-light movies about budding adolescents discovering themselves.
Garbo: The Spy can only suggest who Garcia really was, and why he took it upon himself to fell a tyrant. But even without the fine psychological shading, Garcia's story is a doozy.
There's an allegorical quality to what Leigh's up to here.
A movie about self-absorbed douchebags that wallows in their douchebaggery.
Daguerréotypes has aged splendidly, acquiring flavors that would've been inconceivable at the time it was made.
It relies too much on two particularly played-out indie clichés: a spare, plunky soundtrack, and a narrative structure that teases out characters' backstory far longer than necessary.
It's About You's sound is relatively clean and dynamic, but there's nothing remotely resembling a narrative here.
The film is stunningly composed, with images that convey Pitts' sense of being ground down by modernity and beset by institutional hypocrisy.
Offers one good twist on the killer-vs.-campers concept, but otherwise is about as basic as it gets.
The action in The Front Line is bloody and tense, but the movie also reduces war to its simplest terms...
Part performance film, part backstage documentary, Crazy Horse is familiar in form, yet remarkable both for its subject and for who's sitting in the director's chair.
The ironies pile up. But there is some pathos here too.
Roughly 99 percent of the time, if a movie that seems like it should be a big deal appears almost out of the blue, it's because it's lousy. The Double doesn't exactly buck that trend.
Even after the movie takes its turn for the surreal, it remains rooted in the reactions of slack-faced good guy Little and the gruff-but-loveable Longstreet.
Even committed Elmo-haters may be converted by the time the closing credits roll, because Marks smartly locates the heart of the movie in Clash's devotion to Henson.
The confusion of Martha Marcy May Marlene proves effective, not sloppy.
A movie that's poignant, bittersweet, and true.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Thematically it works, even when it falls short dramatically.
The problem with Albert Nobbs though is that it's hard to believe that the people around the heroine haven't figured her out yet. Even with prosthetics, Close isn't all that convincing as a man.
Killer Joe pitches to the rafters, amping up a hicksploitation thriller with unnecessary jolts of savage violence and abuse.
Wouldn't it be more effective if there was some range to the way the characters behaved, beyond just conforming to the roles of antagonist and antagonized?
What elevates the material is McQueen's impressionistic approach to depicting Fassbender's life of inescapable need.
The location of Your Sister's Sister is lovely, and the performances are top-notch, captured by Shelton in the same casually honest way that made Humpday such a delight.
Highly entertaining, especially for ballfans.
A cleverly staged and structured film which attempts to explain and understand how Israel seizing Palestinian-occupied territory became accepted practice.
The Hawaiian setting gives The Descendants a distinctive flavor that survives Payne's efforts to bury it in schmalz.
Happy, Happy unfolds in a fleet 85 minutes, with no wasted scenes and with strong performances from all concerned.
There is a lot more going on here than the story of a largely forgotten underground sensation.
What makes Pearl Jam Twenty a little better than the average fan-friendly documentary is that Crowe focuses on the more significant parts of the Pearl Jam story.

Nichols is still concerned with family legacies, and the ways people in smaller communities relate to each other, but Take Shelter is slower and smoother, deliberately developing a mood of creeping dread.
Tucker & Dale Vs. Evil is too slick and too cute; Tudyk and Labine are terrific comic actors, but the movie might've been better served by less-recognizable faces.
The Sons Of Tennessee Williams takes a simple-maybe too simple-approach, mixing archival footage with talking-head interviews and shots of people sewing sequins and applying makeup.
This aestheticizing of troubled lives proves problematic over the long haul.
Even though I'm not sure I understand what Stillman was going for minute-to-minute, I was swept away by how original Damsels is, and how funny.
This is one movie people are going to be flinching at and talking about for some time to come.
Larrain crafts Post Mortem as a slow, quiet character study, narrowing in on Castro in his home and office while the world outside descends into madness.
This is one of those puzzle movies that's frustrating in pieces, and underwhelming once it's all fit together.
While Celeste And Jesse marks Jones as ready to make the leap from TV to film, it also shows that she maybe shouldn't be her own screenwriter.
In its own small way, in documenting two people who want to be together but are too scared to commit, Twenty-Eight Hotel Rooms is masterful.
The unbridled scare tactics cast too big a shadow over the agit-prop doc Israel ended up making.
Morrison sketches a portrait of a vanished way of life for one Northeast England community, along with an explanation of sorts for why it disappeared.

Return is unusually attuned to its protagonist's alienation, which is especially painful because its source isn't some horrendous event she witnessed, but the hundreds of annoying aspects of everyday life.
The movie zooms from incident to incident, piling up examples of the anti-hero's misdeeds, primarily so it can ponder how one man could be so stubbornly wicked.
It charts how a man who spends his life playing the angles can miss the hard brick wall he's about to smash into.
Bullhead is well-plotted, with a powerful ending, but its most brutal scene comes early, explaining why for Schoenaerts, life has been one long wince.
Somewhere between The Artist and The Fairy lies the silent-era homage that's truly worthy of its influences.
What is it with first-time Australian filmmakers and ultraviolent true-crime movies about thuggish underclass families?
Better Than Something doesn't really try to resolve the mystery of how someone could be simultaneously so productive and destructive.

Gelb creates a peaceful, contemplative mood with his long shots of men delicately molding fish onto rice, such that when Ono walks past a blaring shopping-mall video-screen at one point, the intrusion of the modern world seems out of place.
Just as a document of the sheer physical labor that goes into covering a giant canvas with color, Gerhard Richter Painting is never less than absorbing.
The movie is caught between the poignancy of the everyday and the exaggerations of fiction.
Dorff and Torres make a lot out of very little, always keeping the audience aware of the larger world outside the small, dark space in which they've trapped us.
What's fascinating and frustrating about The Island President is how it reveals international politics to be even more polarized and mired in bureaucracy than local politics.
It's a fascinating film to think about, but far too cool to touch.

For all the explanation, the main problem with What We Do Is Secret is that [director] Grossman fails to adequately convey why The Germs mattered so much.
Along with Shotgun Stories, Felon, and a few other recent 'indie pulps,' Red is part of a wave of low-budget genre films that turn injustice into an abstract force ripping decent folk apart.
Trouble The Water is infuriating in its depiction of helpless Americans getting left behind, and uplifting in the way it shows the Roberts putting their lives together.

Indie films about arrested adolescence have practically become a genre, but the way Jacobs avoids pat explanations...is so refreshingly low-key that it's easy to feel like Jacobs has reinvented the wheel.
While it isn't that hard to stay a step or two ahead of Timecrimes, the movie is still a nifty little genre piece, an old-fashioned science-fiction mind-game with a healthy dollop of 'Oh, the irony.'
Aside from the casting and the location shooting, there's not much to distinguish Ping Pong Playa from Ladybugs or The Mighty Ducks.

Pretty much everything about this afterlife comedy is straight-from-the-shelf save for Gervais, typically hilarious as a misanthrope who organizes his work and his private life so he doesn't have to talk to anyone.
Miracle At St. Anna stabilizes after an outright awful first hour, and becomes merely a middling war movie with a heightened social consciousness.
A kind of postmodern, grown-up fairytale: a Cinderella story for the reality-TV age.
movie_title: The Amazing Truth About Queen Raquela (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's definitely possible to make artful message movies -- just consider the filmography of ex-Mormon iconoclast Richard Dutcher -- but Forever Strong is generic faith-and-redemption fare, devoid of nuance.
There's a terrific short film buried in Ballast.
Though Obscene tells the story without fully exploring its nuances, that story is both fascinating and more than a little inspiring.
Ultimately, Allah only made these guys mildly likable.
movie_title: Allah Made Me Funny: Live in Concert (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps Ritchie has improved over the past 10 years -- or perhaps any movie would look good after the execrable Swept Away and Revolver -- because Ritchie's latest gangland comedy RocknRolla is far and away his best work.
The Duchess recalls Sofia Coppola's Marie Antoinette, in that it's about bed-hopping and courtly ritual during a time of revolution.
Didn't we invent film festivals so we could sequester all the star-studded 'how I spent my summer vacation' indie film projects and keep them out of our arthouses?

Goodman doesn't allow even a hint of postmodernism or self-consciousness to creep into What Doesn't Kill You, and though the movie's various heists and shootouts are gripping, they aren't especially kinetic or stylish.

Though Theater Of War is informative -- both about Brecht and about the effort it takes to mount a big New York production -- Walter overreaches in trying to connect Brecht's anti-war sentiment with contemporary protest movements.
Oblivion contains more than its share of indelible images and memorable characters.

The Informers should be more aware of its own unsavoryness, and revel in it a little. As it is, the movie is far too weighty, as though it were honestly trying to convey some kind of cautionary message.
At times, Treeless Mountain almost feels like a fairy tale -- but without the magic.
Revanche is, first and foremost, a good story, craftily told.
[Director] Zonca's merely feeding off Swinton's manic performance, which starts out tough to watch, then becomes gripping.
A slight, subtle character sketch, structured and paced like a particularly fine short story.

Summer Hours drags in the middle, but its final scene is almost overpoweringly tender and beautiful, offering a hopeful rejoinder to all the prior scenes of family members shedding their shared legacy.
Jerichow's sparseness, tiny cast, and minimal plot can make the film seem a little elusive, but there's a certain elegance to Petzold's concision, too. He shows all he wants us to see.
While it's often as amateurish as it is assured, Glatzer and writer Robert Lawson want to convey so much that the sheer breadth of the movie means they hit a few of their targets.
The film works as a tour de force for McHattie -- a veteran character actor making the most of his character's long, fluid monologues -- and as a sly commentary on journalistic responsibility.

Séraphine is far more powerful when it lingers on Louis at work. Her canvases -- mostly nature studies -- were cluttered with colorful shapes and filigree, clearly arranged by an obsessive personality.
A chilly, bleak film about characters so programmatic that their plight is easy to shrug off.
Moon is enjoyable as much for its small scale and solid execution as for its crazy twists and creeping existential dread.

While Enlighten Up! is entertaining and provocative regardless, it's too bad that Churchill was so focused on whether Rosen was having his preconceptions shattered that she never stopped to consider her own.
There's a matter-of-factness to BLAST! that overcomes the documentary's lack of one strong thread.
Under My Skin is well-produced and engaging, but it's also anecdotal and conspiratorial, and damnably non-confrontational.
From the wall-to-wall piano score to Rogers' tedious navel-gazing, The Windmill Movie renders prosaic and pretentious the churning conflict behind the process of artistic creation.
It's beautifully shot, crisply paced, and subtly performed by a cast of veteran actors.

From Valentino Garavani's imperious carriage and diva fits to his coterie of tiny dogs, the subject of Tyrnauer's doc comes off like a fictional character, scripted by a writer with a weakness for cliché.
While Anvil! is frequently funny, it'd be a mistake to call the band a joke.
A beautifully choreographed and photographed story about tradition and modernity in rural Asia.
It definitely wouldn't have done anyone involved with Good any harm to ask what relevance heavy-handed history plays have to do with the world of today.

[Director] Celestino steers clear of the can't-miss pulp thriller that Yonkers Joe could've been, and goes for broke by giving it big dollop of schmaltz. His horse doesn't come in, but it runs a respectable race.
Just Another Love Story is enjoyably moody in the early going, and it develops into a decent Hitchcockian thriller at times.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cherry Blossoms' compositions are meticulous, and Dorrie modernizes her style with intermittent use of a handheld camera and impressionistic editing.
A respectable enough little ghost story, but it loses a lot of sparkle by being similar to such other guy-talks-to-the-dead thrillers as The Sixth Sense and Ghost Town.
A thoughtful, often poignant study of modern urban life and race.
Each of Clemente's subjects is talented enough to support a feature-length documentary of her own.
Most of the last hour of Memorial Day feels like a retread at least, and horribly exploitative at worst.
The movie feeds off Rourke, who plays a genuinely decent guy who never lets his dawning self-awareness interfere with his responsibility to give the fans a show.
A gritty political thriller, with a laser-like focus on those moments when Poland was undone by mounting circumstance.
Robert Blecker Wants Me Dead is straightforward as documentary filmmaking, but it's fascinating as a dialectic on fairness.

For all its cop-outs, Phoebe still trumps the 'how to be a better person' hoo-hah of so many middlebrow dramas, if only because the problems it depicts are real, not overcooked reactions to trumped-up traumas.
Rarely has the voyeuristic appeal of sitting on a jury been so cleverly expressed.
So much about the movie is laced with real wit and compassion.
The movie devolves into a series of increasingly pat, ill-thought-out setpieces, presided over by a hero who can't really sell sincerity while he's sporting three-day stubble and a massive jewfro.
Like a museum piece, placing historical figures in frozen positions, and asking us to judge them as the curators do.
Between the pervasive old-world charm and the soundtrack's light classical music, Shall We Kiss? feels as pleasant and pointless as an afternoon of antiquing.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a documentary about a wannabe celebrity and the internationally famous artist who almost makes his dreams come true. And like Sherman's subjects, it's all surface.
The relentless negativity in Must Read After My Death can become overwhelming at times, but it's undeniably mesmerizing.

Full Battle Rattle works just fine as a two-fisted combat story, with unexpected bursts of violence peppering that old universal message that war is hell. But the added layer of pretense pushes the movie to another level.
In contenting itself with the changing public perception of a long-misunderstood event, Wanted And Desired is compelling enough.
Compared to the slick approach that Hollywood took even to the 'social problem' films of the era, The Exiles is bracing and raw, more akin to the French New Wave and British kitchen-sink dramas.
Bar-Lev is also intrigued by the ethereality of childhood, and whether nurturing a gift can also kill it.

About A Son may not let in anybody who doesn't already have one foot in Nirvana's doorway, but those people are invited in fully, to experience the contradictions and preoccupations of a man whose music defined his era.
Finishing The Game doesn't get anywhere that Hollywood Shuffle didn't go to first.

Riley makes a perfect Curtis, and Corbijn's finely shaded recreations of classic Joy Division performances are so exciting that the movie could've been nothing but fake concert footage, and it would've been every bit as moving as the filmmakers intended.
If nothing else, Terror's Advocate offers a useful summary of the last half-century of global politics, and how changing public perceptions can make goats out of heroes.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fine, but a little dry.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Lumet tackles this material like an old master, finding scenes to settle into and hanging out there longer than a younger director might.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The problem with Rodolphe Marconi naming his documentary Lagerfeld Confidential is that he's promising more than he can deliver.

Either one of the most self-indulgent vanity projects in the history of the Hollywood star system, or a rare revealing look at a distinguished actor who usually keeps his real self out of the spotlight.
The Future Is Unwritten is as overstuffed as Sandinista!, but it races ahead like 'White Riot.'
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fat Girls is fully in the "quirky indie" mold, populated by frumpy characters who sport slack expressions and enthuse about silly life plans.
Even abridged, The Life Of Reilly is spellbinding.
As an expression of from-the-gut anti-war rage, Redacted is admirable, but as art, it's undercooked.
What Would Jesus Buy? is one of those all-too-common issue-docs that's so clear about its point that it's practically pointless.
Though the material is hardly fresh, it retains some fascination, and Stone has assembled Oswald's Ghost well, with few of the stylistic tics that marred his Guerilla: The Taking Of Patty Hearst.

The film bears the mark of a real directorial talent, eager to push the documentary form in inventive directions, just like Errol Morris and Werner Herzog, and for that alone, it deserves a nod of appreciation.
The movie is engaging for the way it documents the rise and fall of a semi-natural landmark, and especially for the way it shows how people still come to California to remake themselves.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Williams isn't afraid to ask -- without providing any definitive answer -- whether black people are owed something for the legacy they were denied, and whether the grandchildren of the people who denied it should be properly held accountable.
Conceptually, Lust, Caution has been thoroughly thought-through, down to every lipstick stain Wei leaves on her teacups.
The Last Winter's heart is in the right place, but it isn't pumping any blood.
Much of the movie is spot-on.
Handsomely crafted and well-acted, but its sense of scale is as constricted as a noose.
Visually, Beyond Hatred is precise, handsome -- even brilliant.

t's almost impossible to make a fair-minded, non-exploitative documentary about the abortion debate, but Stephen Fell and Will Thompson take a credible shot with Unborn In The USA: Inside The War On Abortion.
movie_title: Unborn in the USA: Inside the War on Abortion (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Slickly made but not deeply felt, and while [director] King shows signs that he may one day make a film as rich as Peter Jackson at his peak, next time he should try to get the audience to care equally about the eaters and the eaten.
Yet another 'isn't it a pity' doc, where the damnable inequity of globalization provides an occasion for muted, impotent rage.
In Between Days plays like a teen movie with all the narration removed.
Few modern filmmakers are as adept at crafting a haunting image as Kim.
Writer-director Gaggero shoots for a kind of docu-realism, with a few overtly cinematic interludes, like one well-paced split-screen sequence.
Starting Out In The Evening is like the opposite of 'mumblecore'. It's 'loquacitycore'.
So No End In Sight is hardly another partisan anti-war doc. Instead, it's a cogent, often infuriating explication of how the execution of the war went awry.
[Director] Gavras knowingly handles [protagonist] Kervel's little flashes of sympathy for the cause.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Besides the restless style, Dans Paris is remarkable for being more about familial bonds than French cinema tends to be.
Pacing is a problem with Love For Sale, but meaning never is.
[A] pitch-black, bone-dry comedy.
Swanberg is accurately charting the social rituals of the young and inarticulate.
The Monastery is like the opposite of Into Great Silence.
movie_title: The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's so honest about the desperation middle-aged people feel when they have no one to share their lives with, no prospects on the horizon, and nothing to eat in the fridge.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [It's] about the painstaking process behind what seems so off-the-cuff.

Like all of Shane Meadows' work to date, his latest captures the simple pleasures of hanging out with a big group of friends, laughing at nothing. And it shows how easily that camaraderie can shade into hooliganism.
There's something to be said for Venditti's ability to build the kind of trust with a subject necessary to get full participation.

A Walk In The Sea is at its best when [director] Robinson contrasts the haziness of the Warhol crowd with the specificity of Williams' family, who can recall every anecdote he ever told them, including every perceived slight.
movie_title: A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If the idea is that we're always being watched, why does it seem that in this movie, no one's really paying attention?
As fascinating as Glass often is, it's simultaneously too conventional and not conventional enough.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In many ways, Fugitive Pieces is a beautiful film. But it's a bit too beautiful.
Mister Lonely has its moments of wonder and beauty, but the film is obscure by design, and meant to appeal to those who favor the alternative canon of directing greats.
Anna Biller's debut feature Viva consciously combines elements of all of the above, offering a painstaking recreation of the look and feel of campy retro sexploitation.

Refusenik is a little dry in its presentation, relying on a conventional mix of talking heads and stock footage. But Bialis has good footage to work with, including some film shot by the BBC in Moscow using equipment smuggled in by tourists.

My Father My Lord is short, quiet, and shot in a style that favors closeness and intimacy, yet [director] Volach is able to convey in small strokes how a few rooms and buildings can become a child's whole universe.
[Director] Zalla prefers to wallow in the dead-end, an approach that's initially powerful, then numbing.
The Edge Of Heaven's final part is less spectacular by design, and feels a little forced at times, but Akin's multigenerational cast helps give the story a touching sense of perspective.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Young & Restless In China is the first of a planned five-part series that will follow nine diverse Chinese citizens over the course of 20 years.
Bigger, Stronger, Faster* offers persuasive examples of circumstances in which we let people make their own choices, no matter how dimwitted, from plastic-surgery addiction to daredevil stunts.
All told, Ellison is a fascinating person to spend 96 minutes with. But you probably shouldn't risk that 97th.
Mostly On The Rumba River works best when it sticks to the musical performances, which Sarin films in lengthy scenes built from extreme close-ups of lips, fingers and sweaty skin.
In the bizarre and singularly delightful My Winnipeg, [director Guy] Maddin offers a docu-history of his hometown, entangled with memories of his childhood.
There is more to To The Limit than just pretty pictures. The movie is both a study in human endurance and a sketch of two men whose fraternal love sometimes curdles into disgust.

Isherwood and Bachardy's story features cameos by a galaxy of literary and cinema stars, but few are as impressive as the protagonists, who defied the conventions of their times by living openly as a happy, well-adjusted couple.
Some documentarians think like essayists, propagandists, abstract painters, or magazine reporters. Doug Pray approaches his documentaries as though he's writing books.
Full Grown Men often becomes as intolerably silly as the twee Amerindies it's reacting to.
The absence of bite prevents the movie from leaving any kind of impression.
The movie took a long time to get distribution, but there's no expiration date on filmmaking this strong.
Fontaine puts a string of similarly striking images in succession, but they don't really coalesce into a movie.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Body Of War such a powerful documentary isn't the clever rhetorical device of debate vs. reality, but the way it documents American life in the '00s.

Well-plotted, with a strong lead performance by Michael Shannon, and a fair amount of authentic regional flavor. It isn't really meant to be a treatise on Southern life. At heart, it's a country-fried genre film, minus the peppery white gravy.

The characters Lehmann and company use as generational mouthpieces bear no relation to any people who have ever existed, and they barely work as parody. It's cool to see the old retro cereals on the restaurant shelf, though.
The two main points Persepolis makes are that strife is relative, and all politics are personal.
Imaginary Witness works fine as an illustrated history, but the material could've supported something more probing and provocative.
movie_title: Imaginary Witness: Hollywood and the Holocaust (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally resonant, nerve-jangling experience.
Woman On The Beach is a stripped-down, witty explication of how we all get stymied by the impulses and options inherent in the simple act of living.
As issue docs go, The Business Of Being Born is about as well-put-together and non-aggravating as the genre can get -- which isn't saying much, but it's still a small victory.

There are certainly worse ways to spend the holiday season than in the company of two charming old actors, being reminded that human companionship makes life worth living, even as it makes dying a little tougher.
Beaufort is a deliberate, reserved dramatization of how an army stands down.
Jellyfish is the kind of film that will ring true for some viewers, while striking others as too slight and precious.

Tonally, The Band's Visit steps gingerly on the line between 'sweetly humane' and 'cloyingly quirky,' but [director] Kolirin pulls back the reins just enough, maintaining control by expressing as much with his framing as with his script.
It's A Free World...'s dilemmas are undeniably thought-provoking.
Frankly, the scenes of these girls trying to work together and share ideas are enough to make the movie's point.

For the second film in a row, [director] Li excoriates the values of an increasingly market-driven China, where people treat their fellows as products to be exploited, and scramble to get an edge on their 'competitors.'

Director Nicholas Klotz's subtle suspense film Heartbeat Detector comes across like a hybrid of Heart Of Darkness and Michael Clayton, digging into the roots of a psychosis affecting a veteran corporate lackey.
A film that does an injustice to the whole chaotic situation in Eastern Europe by making it seem not just impossible, but impenetrable.
movie_title: Bunt. Delo Litvinenko (Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File) (Rebellion: The Litvinenko Case) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Love Songs is definitely daring, but too much of it seems calculated to lead up to a final line about how to guard against grief: 'Love me less, but love me a long time.'
Aleksandr Sokurov's anti-war drama Alexandra opens with a curious image and spends 90 minutes squeezing it for all it's worth.
Anyone who's spent a lot of time at independent-film festivals will feel a familiar sinking feeling within the first 10 minutes of Backseat.
One of Rivette's most accessible films.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What distinguishes Kiss Of The Damned is its look, which combines the garish gore and muted tones of '70s Euro-horror with the subtle glow of modern moviemaking; and its sound design, which frequently mixes in a hellish throb.
The movie's central idea and bright young cast are so good that some of its shallowness is forgivable.
Aftershock becomes perversely predictable after a while. Just imagine what a conventional disaster movie would do, and wait for the opposite to happen.
It's moving to know that even Nimoy's son is as in thrall to an icon as the rest of us.
As a portrait of a middle America full of forgotten people and ruined civilizations, this is one of the year's scariest movies.
Mostly ... "The People Garden" is so slow and spare that it barely registers. It just floats through the forest, silent and bloodless.
Though well-acted and stylish, this meta-grindhouse exercise strains under its own self-satisfied cleverness.
This 'emotionally immature braniac' character is funny and heartbreaking in equal measure
There's something widely relatable about the way Barry tries to find somewhere to fit in, and preferably in a place where he can be himself and not somebody else's symbol.
Ultimately, this is more the rough outline to a movie than a satisfying picture in and of itself.
A keenly observed coming-of-age drama.
Hearkens back to superb '70s American B-movies.
While its story moves forward in a way that makes sense, Du Welz's pacing is too slow and too choppy for the movie to build up much momentum.
What the documentary does well ... is critique a culture that allows young men to disregard other people's humanity.
This old-fashioned premise has been upgraded for the "smart house" era, but a plodding pace and a lack of technological specifics still make this picture about as state-of-the-art as a Commodore 64.
Good intentions and a decent cast can't save a film this painfully unfunny.
movie_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Vanity projects don't get any weirder - or much worse - than the Ferrara brothers' "New World Order."
Mixes its boldfaced messages with some that are more subtle, designed seem into the audience's subconscious.
Music buffs will want to see all these now-famous folks in their obscure early days. But they'll come away admiring a man they've barely heard of before.
It won't take long for genre fans to recognize that the movie is as dreary as it is derivative.
Stone and Corbin are unusually attuned to the visual textures of rural life.
While Moussi has ample skills as a fighter - and is plenty handsome to boot - he lacks Van Damme's charisma.
Dull and drab, the film squanders an attractive young cast and a killer title.
All the principals are plenty capable, but this is hardly any of these folks' peak.
Thematically, the movie repeatedly contemplates crushing failure, although it's not devoid of hope.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone compiling a supercut of the slasher genre's greatest hits would be wrong to exclude Madman's super-creepy shot of the shaggy Marz silhouetted up in a tree.

Ultimately, this film is about two well-meaning people coming to grips with who they actually are versus who they've always thought they were supposed to be. And when it's on a roll, While We're Young is hilarious.
The movie's strength is in its conception of Michel and Zampa, who develop a destructive rivalry, rooted in their mutual determination to prove their superiority.
Stories Women Tell does succeed at what it primarily means to do, which is to take abortion out of the realm of the theoretical and make it more personal.
"The Fight Within" is too generic as a sports flick, and too pro forma as a tract. There's more vitality and humanity in the closing-credits blooper reel than in anything in the actual picture.
It's slower and quieter than it needs to be, but "Sole Proprietor" has a distinctive vision of a world populated entirely by ruthless, violent people accustomed to operating under their own rules.
The movie's a small gem: a good old-fashioned chase picture, thickened with pulp.
Though more sensationalistic than serious, this film has a scale and an energy that rivals any Hollywood blockbuster.
While anecdotes aren't the same as evidence, it's hard not to be moved by the first-person accounts of ordinary people in "Making a Killing."
movie_title: Making a Killing: Guns, Greed, and The NRA (2016)

movie_review_blurb: When Two Worlds Collide employs a variety of styles and approaches to construct a single gripping narrative.
This hybrid of survivalist action and young-adult drama remains watchable from start to finish, even if it never becomes essential.

Though the acting is inconsistent and the dialogue often laughable (and not in the good way), the film has an appealing can-do quality and a strong dose of craziness that keeps it from ever becoming boring.
The film's convoluted plot and dense mythology ... may leave even "Final Fantasy" devotees scratching their heads.
Just sweet enough and slick enough to appeal to pigskin fans and Christian family audiences.
Though its story and character-development aren't up to the standards of the genre classics it's aping, the movie sports an attractively sunny look, and has a striking location.

There's so much quality children's entertainment on TV and at the movies these days that there's no real reason to take your kids to see a dog - or, more specifically, "Space Dogs: Adventure to the Moon."
movie_title: Space Dogs: Adventure to the Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: When it comes out on home video, fast-forward to the stunts. You won't miss a thing.
Though it's a shade too vague, Spa Night does a fine job of articulating the existential ennui of someone who loves his parents but knows he can never be what they were expecting.

The deviations from O'Brien's plot don't always work, but the characters do come across as real people, in a believably fallen world, following a carefully planned-out path and trying to avoid a fatal misstep.
Though it's mildly enjoyable throughout, the movie is ultimately just a loose collection of nice little scenes, held together by a few palliative clichés.
What Malick has created here is, on balance, a marvel, and one that deserves to be widely seen.
movie_title: Voyage of Time: The IMAX Experience (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What stands out then is the sense of place, which feels like it was drawn directly from Schwartzman's own experiences as a musician and a child of a celebrity. He knows what he wants to show, if not yet what he wants to say.
There's a sharper point to Uncle Kent 2, although the sequel's also something of an endurance test, in ways the original never was.
Though some may find its allusiveness and magical-realist turns to be overly fanciful, The Red Turtle nevertheless remains throughout a simple, gripping story of survival ...
This is the kind of salt-of-the-earth story that American filmmakers don't bother with much anymore - although frankly, there's not much here to convince anyone they should.
The shapes are a distraction. However, what's happening within them is compelling enough to overcome the stylistic overkill.
The clips from Mifune's work still amaze.
Writer-director Nick Gillespie's horror/war hybrid "Tank 432" aims for queasily unsettling ambiguity, but lands in a place that's more tedious and confusing.
Byrne does a fine job of juggling a lot of information, which he does by starting with the immediately arresting story of Sands and then jumping back in time.
For the most part this is a clever and confident expansion of a terrific short. It stings less but packs plenty of poison.
This doc is a vital record of an America transitioning to martial law so quickly and stealthily that we're barely acknowledging the change.
Story mostly focuses on the alarming and heartbreaking particulars of a society that first criminalizes then exploits its underclass, squeezing every last dime from citizens who can't spare a nickel.

[A] short but unforgettable debut documentary, which contrasts the lives of two Minnesota drug dealers-one grizzled, one young-as a way of exploring the larger social problem of Native American gangs.
Dense with plot and mythology, the film is refreshingly unpredictable - if only because guessing what comes next would require understanding what the hell is going on.

By weaving in old speeches, pieces from other books, and even some visual juxtapositions that maybe only he fully understands, the director makes a persuasive, intuitive case for Baldwin as a poet and a prophet.

Though the film moves slowly - like a half-hour anthology episode stretched to three times its natural length - co-writer/director Jackson Stewart's obvious affection for obsolete technology earns some goodwill.
It's hard to recommend "Blood Brothers," which is mostly unpleasant and shrill. But it is unusual enough to suggest that Prendes' next film might be better.

The inexplicability of "Abattoir" keeps it engaging for a while, but by the time it hits the one-hour mark without anything even remotely exciting happening, even a horror connoisseur's patience will run thin.
The script by Cam Cannon and co-producer Richard Rionda Del Castro is frustratingly unfocused, jumping from incident to incident while using Cage's flat, whispered narration to fill the gaps.
A movie that's admirably provocative, even if at times it seems to be more interested in being challenging than being entertaining.
This is the rare horror film that could be aptly described as "relaxing."
More B-movies could stand to be like "The Shelter," which at least tries to tie its darkness to something real.
As much a study of a changing society as it is a story of evil spirits. The movie is first fascinating, then terrifying.
Retains all the offbeat humor and casual surrealism that has kept this franchise afloat for over three decades.

While holding onto the handmade charm of the original, the 4K version makes the image less murky and the seams less visible, giving the picture back the vividly nightmarish quality of its original theatrical run.
While the dialogue is colorful and the acting strong, this is ultimately a 90-minute neo-noir stretched unnecessarily past two hours.
The "roaming hands" dream is one of Miss Hokusai's most memorable set pieces, but it's far from the only standout.

Macdonald effectively draws lines between his subject's past and his present, attempting to make sense of what his harshest critics see as self-serving contradictions. In a way, it's all of a piece, embracing the best and worst of an ever-changing nation.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Maitland's experimental approach to a tricky subject leaves viewers with a deeper understanding of a terrible moment in American history.
While the movie's artfully made and daringly disturbing, Dekker ultimately overestimates how many sick twists one motion picture needs.
What's most terrifying about The Babadook is that Kent grounds a bizarre supernatural premise in very real feelings of anxiety and depression.

While the proverbial "'90s kids" may get a nostalgic kick out of seeing their old action figures in the flesh, novices are likely to be bored by a movie that feels more like a failed pilot for a TV show.
Usually, with a movie as mundane as The Whole Truth, it's tempting to say that a better cast and crew would've made something more special. But on paper, this film had the goods.
A slow-burning mystery that gets darker by the minute before reaching a lurid, queasy finale.
The Rob Zombie brand promises hard-core horror and scuzzy atmosphere, and "31" delivers just that. Even on autopilot, Zombie makes movies that hit hard and leave a stain.
Even though this is a (mostly) true story, the forced ironies of having infamous teen mass-murderers interact with the heroine feels more than a little exploitative.
"Mr. Donkey" is deeply flawed but also fascinating. There's a good story here, woven between the thudding jokes.
"The Unspoken" has so much plot that it really shouldn't need to rely as much as it does on big, loud sounds. After a while, the assaultive music becomes a tip-off that the movie's not working.
Director Nick Jongerius can't entirely keep the story from feeling warmed-over, but fans should be too pleased by the movie's professionalism to complain much.
The movie's noisy, busy and not that funny. But there is a sweetness and a cockeyed optimism here.
Demme keeps finding something new and unusual to shoot, fascinated by the minutiae and peripheries of a major showbiz endeavor.
One of the major points The Bad Kids makes is that most "problem students" have common struggles that could be managed with the individualized attention that big public high schools can't provide.
Ultimately, the story these journalists chased was about how institutional power degrades when it gets taken for granted.
A strong twist ending and a creative use of effects helps "Let's Be Evil" overcome its limitations.
Landis and Cabezas never figure out how to pitch the ironic pulpiness of Mr. Right as anything other than a glib, pointless joke.
At its best, the film has the quality of a nightmare, one that keeps happening whether the characters are asleep or awake.
Barbosa skillfully skewers the presumptions of rich folks who presume they deserve all that they've gotten, even as they're squandering it.
Though almost entirely devoid of facts and figures, the film represents the best kind of cinematic journalism - more like a live-action painting than an ESPN special.

Debates about how best to represent both fashion and China - with the likes of Baz Luhrmann and Wong Kar-wai weighing in - are provocative and useful. But Rihanna walking the red carpet in an Asian-inspired ensemble is fine art in motion.
The languid pace and barnyard earthiness won't be to everybody's taste, but it's hard to deny Mascaro's vision.
What is How To Let Go? A dire prophecy? A call to arms? A personal travelogue? It appears to be a combination of all three -- and frequently a disjointed one.
movie_title: How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate Can't Change (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's something achingly poignant about watching the octogenarian Nieves and Copes direct "themselves" - while addressing what might have been.
The film mostly feels perfunctory and awkward - like calling home at Christmas.
There are good lessons to be learned from the Market Basket saga. "We the People" doesn't trust the audience to figure them out for themselves.
movie_title: We The People: The Market Basket Effect (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Term Life" is cleanly plotted and tautly paced, but it's never as fun as it should be.
For the many, many viewers who've never heard of Dream Alliance, Osmond's documentary is edge-of-the-seat stuff.
It all adds to the idea that Star Wars was both the best and the worst thing to happen to its low-level supporting cast.
After an opening 10 minutes that promises something depressingly mediocre, the film takes a turn to the atmospheric and gruesome, and winds up being one of the year's more provocative shockers.
[An] uninspired, nonsensical mishmash, which crudely cobbles together second-hand religious imagery, abrasively noisy jump-scares, and - for some reason - techno-phobia.

While a film like "Serial Killer 1" may disappoint anyone expecting "Bullitt" or "Lethal Weapon," its focus on legwork and motivation could well appeal to fans of "Law & Order" - the TV show and the social construct.
A savvy, sensitive study of suburbanites coping with an encroaching apocalypse.
Frankly, Jude's not that much fun to spend an hour and a half with. The problem's not that she's a handful, but that she's a clichéd handful.
movie_title: One More Time (When I Live My Life Over Again) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hartmut Bitomsky's Dust makes a pensive study of the title particulate, considering the way we wage a never-ending battle with the tiny specks that gather around us.
Mostly, the film documents how a rich musical tradition continues to captivate listeners around the world even as its practitioners are struggling at home.
movie_title: They Will Have to Kill Us First (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Chongqing Hot Pot" effectively stokes the fantasy that with the right breaks, a group of struggling, hard-working folks can get their just reward. It's a tasty notion, if not enough to nourish an entire movie.
Only Yesterday can sometimes seem a little too random in what it chooses to show, but it has a cumulative power as Taeko comes to understand that the past that shaped her needn't define her.
There's exactly one fascinating, original character in Anna Axster's well-meaning but bland debut feature, "A Country Called Home." Unfortunately, the movie's not about him.
Fright fans more interested in thematic depth than visceral thrills may appreciate what writer-director Michael Petroni attempts, but even they'd likely admit there's not much to savor.
There's real power in the more unobtrusive scenes of Parker, Sadler, and the rest going about their ordinary business, ignoring protestors and treating patients.

Herbeck's script pokes at the anxieties of parents who leave their kids alone with virtual strangers, while Bolger excels at playing the nightmare version of a babysitter: seemingly sweet, cool, and capable, but secretly evil.
Even by the shaggy standards of found footage, "The Final Project" is amateurish.
For those who aren't automatically turned off by the idea of an issue-doc that Schoolhouse Rock-ifies a serious, grown-up subject, Boom Bust Boom is a worthwhile way to spend an hour.
A stylish, rousing throwback epic, telling the fictionalized story of Wong as a young man, circa 1868.
movie_title: Rise of the Legend (Huang feihong zhi yingxiong you meng ) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly, just as "SPL" did with Yen, this sequel serves as an ideal showcase for talented martial artists.
At times, this movie feels too much like the Christian version of "The Phantom Menace," offering unnecessary explanations for well-known stories.
City Of Gold takes something of a once-over-lightly approach to Gold's life, sprinkling little bits of his biography throughout ...
Take Me To The River is vague to a fault, suggesting just enough to get across what may be going on, while remaining open to interpretation.
Nearly everything about "The Preppie Connection" - from the high-school class war to the flat, explanatory narration - has been cribbed from other, better films.
Make no mistake: This film is a tear-jerker, taking an intimate look at one family's heartbreak and how their art moves people.

The movie's Jules Verne-esque contraptions are fun to look at -- and will make steampunk fans drool with delight -- but by no means do Tardi and company want viewers to feel nostalgic for this alternate past.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The movie doesn't do justice to a promising premise.
By keeping the movie's goals and scale modest, Budreau makes something that should resonate with Baker fans and newcomers alike.
The pacing is slack and the splatter excessive, but this twisted cross-genre exercise should be red meat to gore-hounds.
The idea of Chevalier is so compelling that the movie earns a lot of goodwill that it never completely squanders.

Begos opens "The Mind's Eye" with the words, "This film should be played loud," as though his movie were a rock song - which is actually a fair analogy for a simplistic throwback homage that's all hook and no sophistication.

A feather-light thriller that adds nothing new to the "gather a group of friends and kill them off one by one" genre. Though slickly produced and competently acted, the movie mostly just follows a formula.
Give credit to Medem for trying to make a routine weepie more memorable, but the level of originality and creativity he applied to how this movie looks would've been better spent on his script.
There's almost nothing to this movie besides a woman puttering about her flat, unaware that she's in danger.
"Vigilante Diaries" never rises above what it is: a bunch of frenetic shootouts and fight scenes unencumbered by plot.
It's hard to nitpick too much, given how insightful and emotional so much of this documentary is.
Willis' workaholism benefits "Marauders," an otherwise plain action picture carried by strong performances and a mildly compelling mystery.
Under The Sun is really two films, threaded together: one a carefully crafted lie, and the other something closer to the truth.
Equally inspired by Quentin Tarantino, the Coen brothers and the seediest of '70s drive-in exploitation, "Carnage Park" is a frequently repellent film that's nonetheless cleverly constructed.
Even King's commentary on how cyber-connectivity breeds brainlessness feels shoehorned-in - mostly limited to a few lines from a snooty private-school administrator played by Stacy Keach.
Once again the filmmakers bring a design sense and a set of storytelling influences unlike anything happening in feature-length cartoons today.
"Outlaws and Angels" can't overcome its distractingly showy camera moves or its tendency toward scenes that drag on interminably.
Like Blackout itself, "The Blackout Experiments" is often chilling and hard to shake.
Caple has a unique eye and a strong sense of place. Here's hoping that next time he applies them to a fresher story.
By tackling the larger issue of Native American gangs through the story of two northwest Minnesota drug dealers, Riccobono personalizes a problem that deserves more attention.
It's no "Rosemary's Baby" - or even "It's Alive" - but the Danish supernatural thriller "Shelley" is a fair addition to the "natal horror" genre.
There's something a little off about a horror movie when a long chat about model trains is more gripping than any supernatural hoo-hah.
Captain Fantastic is in some ways a simplistic film - entertaining, though not especially deep. But Mortensen gives his all to the role.

The film doesn't always work as a genre exercise, but it's a winner as a character study, in large part because of how committed Hagan is to playing Janie's derangement. Casting directors in search of the offbeat should take note.
When all is said and done, this documentary mostly amounts to a collection of anecdotes and stray bits of analysis, assembled in a way that has a flow but lacks force.
An unusual and affecting baseball drama where nearly all the action is internal.
Lane, like any great storyteller, springs surprises after luring her audience in.
For all its faults and frustrations, this documentary is always a vivid portrait of a man who considered himself a working musician, just trying to support a family with his creativity.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)
