movie_review_blurb: While it has a sharp hook - and is reasonably diverting - it never rises above the routine.

This film doesn't lionize Weiner or justify anything he did. What it does is capture the frenzy of politics, the iron-clad egos of politicians, and the failure of the media to cover the parts of campaigning and government that actually matter.
It's not a great movie but a welcome one, if only for how it attempts to revive a whole genre.
Eventually ... the movie finds its own voice and groove, and avoids being a mere retro exercise.
This film barely brushes up against the many, many issues it raises, but those conversations can be had in the lobby, after the pleasure of watching an underappreciated artist finally get her due.
If writer-director Mark Savage and co-writer Tom Parnell have anything clever to say, their broad characters and crude gags keep them from articulating it.
The Dresser rises and falls on the strength of its central duo, and it's hard to imagine two currently working actors who could rival Courtenay and Finney as well as McKellen and Hopkins do.
Rather than shrugging with disgust, Ferguson points to the better world that nearly everybody wants and that already exists in some places. Then he simply asks that we vote for it.
Part of what's so terrific about The Fits is that so much of it is open to interpretation, even though the film as a whole isn't that oblique.
From the troubled child who communes with the beyond to the featureless suburban home that hosts malicious spirits, this movie ticks all the boxes for modern mainstream shockers.
AM's fans should get a lot out of the doc, but casual music-lovers may wish Kerslake would just get back to the party.
movie_title: As I AM: The Life and Times of DJ AM (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a journalistic marvel, assembling fact after fact and observation after observation into a portrait far more complex overall than it appears at any given moment.
If a movie's going to insist on its audience watching two people have an illicit fling for the better part of an hour, that couple needs to be a lot more charismatic.
A compendium of genre clichés - or, more charitably, "homages" - "Queen of Spades" offers little that fright fans haven't seen before.
movie_title: Queen Of Spades: The Dark Rite (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Acevedo has a wonderful command of visual storytelling, as evidenced by how well he frames those dark interiors; he and Guzmán use every spare beam of light to illuminate the edges of his characters.
movie_title: Land And Shade (La Tierra Y La Sombra) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although each of the first three films tells a full, discrete story, they work best cumulatively, as the ongoing adventures of one cranky, conscientious cop.
movie_title: A Conspiracy of Faith (Flaskepost fra P) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although each of the first three films tells a full, discrete story, they work best cumulatively, as the ongoing adventures of one cranky, conscientious cop.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although each of the first three films tells a full, discrete story, they work best cumulatively, as the ongoing adventures of one cranky, conscientious cop.
"Clown" has the goods. Refreshingly dark and sick, this is a movie for those who like cinematic monsters that hit so hard they leave a mark.
The lack of any likable characters ultimately undoes "Urge." Kaufman and Stahl have made a classic party-throwers mistake: overrating the entertainment value in watching other people get high.
Fans of the genre - and the cast - may find it a pleasant enough diversion, but given the recent wave of strong frontier dramas, this film feels especially minor.
As leftovers go, "Solace" retains a fair amount of flavor, thanks to high-end ingredients.
Every time the narrative seems to be headed toward some pat, sentimental revelation about loss and healing, it lands just a little off-center, avoiding predictability.
Badgley is terrific, and even if he doesn't quite succeed in making Jeff Buckley likeable, he does make the singer's standoffish attitude understandable.
While subtle, moody horror films can be great, without something solid to coalesce around, eventually the atmosphere dissipates.
Di Giacomo listens patiently to people who earnestly believe that they're plagued by a supernatural evil. In a way, their calm certitude is as scary as any actual demon.
So evocative that by the end viewers may be as cold and hungry as the movie's cast of courtiers.
"Geostorm" has a more clever premise than it needs to get to its ultimate goal of trashing some of our planet's nicest places. But the results are still mostly dull-witted.
"Halloween Pussy Trap Kill! Kill!" is just dumb enough to be a potentially fun candidate for someone's "bad movie night."
The movie bleeds honesty, though its individual components are more memorable than how they're assembled.

There's a subtly meaningful power to what the film actually does: witnessing the awkwardness that ensues when the creatively free try to communicate with people who lack the context to understand unfettered expression.
It'll do the job for anyone who must see a "Saw" movie in theaters on Halloween weekend.
Miike retains his twisted sense of humor, with mangling and disemboweling deployed for comic effect. And after 99 movies, he certainly knows how to make action memorable.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Bad Match" effectively explores the everyday horror that comes from people treating their fellow human beings as interchangeable playthings.
While Lynch has experience delivering breezy action, "breezy" can shade into "frivolous" - or even "forgettable."
Even at its most serious and sophisticated, it retains the pleasingly funky aroma of pulp.
With his rubbery frame, deep-set eyes, and sun-baked California drawl, the actor's wiry energy dominates any scene he's in. Wherever [Sam] Rockwell's placed, he's perfect.
The lack of any real imagination makes "Attack of the Killer Donuts" a chore.
This is an alternately handsome and harrowing ghost story, about a civilized society haunted by its own unspeakable needs.
The genre's a little twisted, but the film should still appeal to fans of books about moody detectives, doggedly pursuing justice against a frosty backdrop.
"Leatherface" is the best "Chainsaw" movie that doesn't have "Directed by Tobe Hooper" in the credits.
This movie puts the wild, comic tales of resourceful poor kids into a frame, pulling back just enough to make it clear that the situation Moonee's in - while exciting - is untenable.
There's barely enough plot here to fill a feature, but this energetic throwback's DIY effects and general looniness should appeal to horror mavens.
As a morality tale, "Haze" is old news. But as an in-the-moment explanation of how hazing happens, it's so fresh, it's raw.
Writer-director Keir Burrows' rapid-fire dialogue and barrage of images ultimately prove too exhausting, though it's always energetic.
This is an easy picture to watch... and to root for, in a way, because it's so rarely overbearing. But it's only ever mildly engaging.
It's at times frustrating but what's enthralling is that the whole picture feels like an exploration - and one where not even C.K. knew where he was going when he started shooting.
Burdge holds the picture together, playing a character who walks a fine line between being sympathetically damaged and terrifyingly loony.
Even at its pulpiest, "Happy Hunting" has a point to make - about how in modern society we often use the pretense of morality to justify base savagery.

The basic concept behind this franchise remains sound: take some borrowed scares from professional haunters, add a few spooky twists, then leave the audience puzzling over how much that they saw actually happened.
Picture a half-dozen or so loosely related short films, cut-and-pasted together into a dazzling collage.
The brother filmmaking team of writer Tim Ryan and director Trevor Ryan exhibit imagination, but haven't developed the skills to mold their many ideas into a cohesive picture.
Darkest Hour is more challenging and even more revelatory than run-of-the-mill awards-season releases.
What makes "Super Dark Times" one of the most exciting American filmmaking debuts in recent years is how well Phillips and company grasp both the intensity and ephemerality of adolescence.
There's scarcely a new or old horror movie cliché that goes unused in "Don't Sleep," a supernatural thriller that tries a little bit of everything - all competently, none memorably.

The best that can be said about the Flatliners remake is that the new filmmaking team of writer Ben Ripley and director Niels Arden Oplev makes the original's members look like peerless masters of horror.
Even if The Death And Life Of Marsha P. Johnson doesn't wholly deliver on its premise, France does a remarkable job of finding the continuity between New York in the '70s, '90s, and now.
movie_title: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A consistently surprising and unusually well-acted thriller, which says pertinent things about suburbia, holiday entertainment and toxic masculinity.
The ambitious auteur is getting better at making his novelistic ideas punchy and cinematic, but "Demons" is still a B-movie that takes itself too seriously.
A lifeless demonic possession drama.
The best scenes in "Red Oleanders Raktokarobi" layer live theater, poetic allusion and Bollywood pop - which makes them exciting to watch, even when their meaning isn't absolutely clear.
There have been a number of gripping "you are there" films about refugees over the past few years, but Human Flow distinguishes itself from the pack with how handsome it looks.
Mostly, "The Sound" gets by on pure sensation. Mattison finds a lot to look at in the shadows - and in the heavy hum of the subway's deep holes, she finds a lot to hear.
The movie has enough of Woods' flavor to put a memorable spin on a familiar genre - so much so that it's almost a crime it isn't better.
The cast and creators of "Sweet Virginia" dig underneath flat pulp conventions and find the real pain and emotional instability at their roots.
"Slumber" itself feels like it was loosely adapted from a few cursory Google searches.
The apparitions are cool. The schmoes they're haunting hardly seem worth the effort.
Takes nearly half its running time to get to the scary stuff - and then keeps the lighting so dim that it's hard to make out which shadowy figure's the monster.
The ultimate point of "Mom and Dad" is that it doesn't take a rage virus to make a middle-aged man want to put on his old Misfits T-shirt and smash something.
It's to Heard's credit that his presence in the movie is pretty much the only reason to watch.

"Wastelander" proves how computers have made it easier to produce a film for pennies with a look that would have cost a fortune 40 years ago. Unfortunately, "Wastelander" also confirms that a mediocre script still dulls even the shiniest picture.

Christensen and co-writer Colin Minihan mostly repeat old beats from suburban supernatural horror films like "Poltergeist" and "Paranormal Activity," but strong actors and lean, unfussy storytelling ought to be more than enough to please genre buffs.
The film looks stunning and presents some provocative ideas, but González's quietly contemplative approach is numbing.
Grant's slippery presentation muddles his point - if he has one - but it's fun to guess at what's a put-on.
"The Monkey King 3" is more about eye-popping spectacle than narrative sweep, but it's generous with images that make audiences go, "Oooh!"
It's a pity such memorable characters are stuck in a story so middling.
movie_title: Detective K: Secret of the Living Dead (2018)

movie_review_blurb: For viewers who take it more as a moody, metaphorical historical drama than as an out-and-out horror film, there's a lot in this lush-looking, sensitively acted picture to recommend.
Writer-director Derek Nguyen's supernatural thriller settles confidently in a place between classy and trashy.
The veteran director has more than enough chops to keep a doggedly generic premise lively.
"Mohawk" is a gripping and despairing action picture, about how we can't seem to stop trying to destroy those we distrust - including ourselves.
"They Remain" does what it means to do. It makes the natural feel threateningly alien.
"The Outsider" is a slick copy of multiple, much-better films and TV series. It's so well-polished it's practically featureless.
DiMarco's noir-inflected family drama is confident and mature, but less involving than it could be, because the filmmaker and his star make their anti-hero stubbornly unappealing.

The original had some squirmy points to make about femininity and motherhood that this "Inside" lacks. But the movie works on a gut level ... as in, "Sharp blades are scary when they're pointed at a pregnant belly."
Any hard messages it means to deliver are hard to hear over the frequent sound of gunfire.
A gifted cast and some finely shaded detail add dimension to the low-budget indie "Madtown," an overwrought melodrama that nevertheless remains engaging from start to finish.
The dialogue in "Devil's Gate" is mostly expository, and while the cast does its best, the characters feel more like sketchy outlines than real people.
Ask yourself: "Do I have any interest at all in a movie with 'WolfCop' in the title?" If the answer's yes, you probably won't be disappointed.
The key to Lady Bird is that Marion is never painted as an ogre. Her toughness is played for comic effect: as an understandable character flaw born of her genuinely meaning well.
Well-intentioned but tedious.
All of Snyder's DC films - Justice League included - seem more concerned with the repercussions of actions than with the actions themselves.
The movie eschews narration and captions, and instead just strings together one stunning scene after another of inconceivably wealthy oil men indulging their passions.
A well-told story, with a strong sense of place.
There are limits to how much of an edge a movie gets from incompetence - as writer/director/producer Susannah O'Brien's "The Doll" proves definitively.
I, Tonya aims for a different kind of retroactive justice. Gillespie and Rogers argue that Kerrigan actually had chances to shine on an international stage that Harding never got.
The ideal audience for "Gangster Land" would be someone who's never seen "The Untouchables" or "Boardwalk Empire" ... or, heck, even "Guys and Dolls" or "Bugsy Malone."
movie_title: Gangster Land (In the Absence of Good Men) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The results are both mesmerizing and provocative.
The movie's both haunting and honest, confronting what it's like to see the community that sustains you die right in front of your eyes.
The mountain backdrops are stunning, but the movie's real draw is its understanding of how children pick up more from their parents than their skeptical, self-pitying moms and dads ever imagine.
Honorable in intent, but dreary in execution.
"A Portrait" may not make Frisell's biography fascinating, but it does give the proper due to a guitarist whose music flows like water into any handy vessel.
"A Christmas Story Live!" lacked the feeling of a piece of theater unfolding in front of the audience's eyes in real time, like a slick magic trick.

Ultimately, the biggest problem with Bright is that it squeezes nudity, profanity and blood into the kind of dopey adventure that should be aimed more at adolescents - right down to its simplistic lessons about tolerance.

Whatever artificial limitations Sorkin puts on his female characters though, he's empathetic enough to understand that Molly Bloom's story is about a woman being controlled and underestimated by a succession of presumptuous jerks.

But while The Post celebrates the free flow of information, it's primarily about the businessmen who expected Kay Graham to follow their advice to kill the series, and how shocking and revolutionary it was when she ignored them.
Georgian writer-director Nana Ekvtimishvili (In Bloom) brings a rare subtlety and sensitivity to this ironically titled domestic drama.
It seems to want to be an artful social statement when it might have been better had it been trashier and more overtly terrifying - more "Hostel" than "City of God."
"The Vault" is a combination heist and horror picture; and it's the rare genre mash-up where each element's equally strong.
The movie does what it sets out to do: stranding the viewer in a dark place, surrounded by remorseless predators. It's an old recipe that can still please a crowd.
Though a little meandering, Road to the Well has flavorful dialogue, and a sense of scope that's rare for a movie about betrayal and murder.
While writer-director Alexander Babaev's "Bornless Ones" doesn't do anything radically new, it deepens its characters and situations enough to be distinctive.

The auteur's age, precociousness and pedigree automatically make "Stray Bullets" an item of interest, although fans of the Fessenden clan will be pleased to know that the movie's also pretty entertaining and only a little bit amateurish.
Strong lead performances and a startling twist juice up the found-footage exercise "VooDoo," which squeezes unexpected novelty from an exhausted subgenre.

There's a level of wild B-movie ambition here that's preferable to the usual blandly violent, overly serious genre fare. If nothing else, Von Hoffman clearly has a voice - even if his accents are imitations.

A flatly earnest Hoult and Jones are hamstrung by drippy dialogue, while Kingsley and Hopkins overplay their more colorful parts - with the former doing a cartoonish Turkish accent and the latter delivering lines with strange emphasis.
"Lavender" means well, but it ultimately proves that not all ghosts need a backstory. Often, just being scary - even inexplicably - is more important than being meaningful.
Even when Don't Kill It veers toward the ordinary, Lundgren is there with his lived-in face and playful eyes, waiting as ever to spring into action. It's great to see him in a fun movie again.
Theroux raises troubling questions about psychological warfare and how devoutness shades into fanaticism.

What makes "The Devil's Candy" a standout is how well-developed these characters are. This is ultimately a movie about parenting, and how even "hip" moms and dads fear the choices they make are hurting their young.
This movie won't be for everybody, but fans of Lowe's prior work should be thrilled to see such a distilled dose of her perverse humor.
There's a lived-in quality to "Dig Two Graves" that's all-too-rare for low-budget movies in this genre.
"The Blackcoat's Daughter" connects the pieces and ends strongly, though Perkins smartly spends more creative energy on crafting creepy situations than on pointing toward the payoff.
This is the first act of a better movie, stretched to fill a feature.
Forced character-arc aside ... this is a tightly constructed and well-acted indie with a few standout sequences. It's further proof that sometimes all a filmmaker needs is a cab and a camera.
A lively, layered throwback to the days when splatter auteurs like John Carpenter, George Romero and Lucio Fulci ruled the drive-in.
"Bethany" is polished, well-acted and filled with memorably disgusting images, but its portrait of a frazzled adult survivor of child abuse is ultimately formulaic and a little sleazy.
The plot of "Eloise" is more ambitious than the typical "haunted asylum" picture, but the retro costumes and set-dressing in the flashbacks belong more to a TV drama than a low-budget thriller.
A warmed-over hash of "Candyman," "Oculus," "Insidious" and a half-dozen other spook-shows.
A vivid picture of modern life, and an inspiring tale about how a more tolerant family-and society-can make it easier for people to be themselves rather than negating themselves.
Julian Rosefeldt's visual panache and Cate Blanchett's astonishing versatility bring cinematic verve to something that could've easily come off as too dryly conceptual.
Even when the movie's falling into a straighter line, the early emphasis on quietly nuanced characterizations and a measured pace give the danger more dimension.
Mostly stays within the narrow parameters of the "knocking off generically attractive youngsters one-by-one" movie, never getting campy enough, bizarre enough or satirical enough.
There's genuine artistry even to this film's most exploitative moments.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "The Snare" is admirably artful and oblique in putting its own twist on the haunted-house story, but it's derivative of much better psychological suspense films and is obnoxiously unpleasant to boot.
There's nothing especially new about jailhouse confessionals. What sets Starless Dreams apart are the particulars of who these crooks are.
"The Axe Murders of Villisca" never really comes to much, perhaps because its focus is too diffuse. The scares are low, and the plot under-baked.
Weirdly admirable... like a laid-back, stretched-out Monty Python sketch.
A terrific cast, but underbaked on the whole.
A talky, set-bound drama masquerading as a suspense picture, and nearly the entire movie consists of overwritten, overacted, visually inert confrontations and monologues.
A funny, Woody Allen-esque look at Hollywood singledom from a sophisticated female perspective.
The performances are all outstanding, but the comedy is hit-and-miss.
Zoe Kazan can transform even the most stock role into something indelible.

Taylor Sheridan pares his story and characters down to their barest essentials, making a movie that comes off sometimes as slight, but which ultimately delivers the goods for those who like smart takes on life-or-death macho adventure.
"Absolutely mesmerizing, with an anything-goes quality that's endlessly fascinating."
"Sweet and occasionally riotously funny, but it treats the material too simplistically.
No doubt Alex Ross Perry will follow up the film with a strong return to form, but this film is a collection of half-realized ideas and characters.
Franco never plays this character as hurt or vindictive. Right to the end, he's earnestly seeking, determined not to be slapped with any label, and willing to risk being totally alone.

The central theme of "Newness" isn't as profound or even as novel as either the filmmakers or their millennial target audience may believe. But at it's best, "Newness" is about how nothing's really all that new.

Some might find the subject matter too bleak; others might wish it were pulpier. But on the whole, "Berlin Syndrome" is incredibly effective. It gets to know the innocent, while rendering the evil banal.
It feels wrong to encourage this kind of misbegotten DIY project, but if you're a fan of the likes of "The Room" or "Birdemic," honestly, you can't miss "Mike Boy."

Give credit to the filmmakers for making a faith-affirming picture that aims to be more thoughtful than maudlin. But what they've ended up with is a fairly rote Christian redemption narrative - albeit with more charts and graphs.
The cast is game and the pace blessedly zippy, but everything about this film feels too fake to generate any real suspense.

"The Gracefield Incident" sports some impressive special effects in key scenes, but remains yet another found-footage thriller where the dialogue feels phony, the nonscary action is tedious and the images are artless.
Every densely layered image of oozing pus and gassy orifices is as imaginatively rendered as it is disgusting.
What keeps Menashe from just being outside-in ethnography is how much nuance Weinstein and Lustig bring to the main character.
Watching an actress of Hunter's caliber in a meaty leading role partly compensates for the creaky plot and overearnest tone.

While "Wolf Warrior 2" is blandly generic more often than not, there's something bracing about its patriotic fervor, which asserts that the Chinese will act in the best interests of the world's downtrodden, while the rest of the world just exploits them.
Icarus tells such an eye-opening story that it almost doesn't matter when the storytelling itself gets a little sloppy.
There's not enough story here but every time David pops up on the soundtrack to spout dime-novel clichés ... this movie takes on the quality of classic storybook, not straight-to-video schlock.
Those who pick through every motion picture searching for the "problematic" will want to steer clear of "68 Kill." But fans of wicked women may have a new cult favorite.
Without over-explaining anything, Whose Streets? scores some tough points against the institutions its subjects consider to be the opposition.
Frankly, a documentary like Emer Reynolds' "The Farthest" is exactly what the world needs right now.
"Bedeviled" ultimately embraces clichés rather the subverting them. The evil technology's up to date, but the storytelling's too old-fashioned.
While writer-director Megan Freels Johnston makes some unusual choices that set her film apart from run-of-the-mill low-budget horror, too much of her movie feels warmed-over.

An indistinct muddle of werewolf mythology, slasher formula and "teenagers in the woods" clichés, the horror pastiche "Lycan" might've been a passable picture if writer-director Bev Land had settled on what he was making.
The film isn't as provocative as it means to be, but it gets a lot of juice from Rapace's multifaceted performance and an "anything goes" approach to plot.
Mostly, it's a tightly constructed, unapologetically nasty little thriller, given depth and weight by Wallace's interpretation of a sweet woman suffering for her past.
At its best, the picture resembles Wingard's sharp-edged 2014 cult movie, "The Guest." More often, it feels like a 100-minute "previously on" montage for a cable TV show.
What we have here is a deeply flawed but frequently rewarding picture, with a lot to say about how stories can both guide and misguide us.
"Granny of the Dead" undercuts a potentially potent horror premise by mining it for gross-out comedy.
The impression that comes across is that this is what it takes to be a great artist: awareness, imagination and a willingness to do whatever needs to be done.
Seagal's roughly 15 minutes of screen time are ultimately a distraction - especially when he gets his own clumsy fight scene with St-Pierre.
The laughably stilted "Inconceivable" is mostly notable for who's in it - and how poorly served they are by the script and direction.
"Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary" ought to appeal to longtime fans as well as neophytes.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "The Black Room" is unabashedly trashy - with scene after scene of nudity and gore - but doesn't offer much beyond sensation.
From start to finish, "Black Rose" is about as pro forma as a motion picture gets.
[The] impressive lineup of interview subjects properly tells the story of a man whose contributions to popular music have been largely unheralded.
There's not much reason to watch this "Whisky Galore!" so long as the 1949 version still exists.
As a screenwriter - for this picture at least - Devos puts too much stock in his visual style to carry the meaning of a thinly plotted, snail-paced slice-of-life.
The film as a whole doesn't make a lot of sense, but from moment to moment it is effectively visceral and raw. It's compelling almost by accident.
The brilliance of Long Strange Trip is that Bar-Lev allows for multiple interpretations.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "There's a Future in the Past" is equally balanced between its smoking-hot live performances, interviews and day-in-the-life footage.
movie_title: Vince Giordano: There's a Future in the Past (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to tight direction by Brian Goodman and lively performances from Antonio Banderas and Jonathan Rhys Meyers, the film's engaging even when it's ridiculous.
True-crime obsessives may be disappointed that most of this film is fiction; but fans of grubby B-pictures should appreciate how assured the movie is.
"Camera Obscura" lurches between gory thriller sequences and dreary character development, and never develops any momentum.
Modeled after "everything's connected" movies like "Short Cuts" and "Magnolia," this slickly produced if somewhat dry multi-character study makes good use of location.
"Jasmine" doesn't offer much in the way of white-knuckle action, but viewers who remain patient through the movie's brief running time might enjoy arguing afterward about what it all means.
Thanks to three lively lead performances and smart storytelling choices, what could have been a distasteful premise becomes surprisingly entertaining.

"Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story" seems more intimate and revealing than these sorts of artist-approved self-mythologies usually are - even if it fails to fill in all of Combs' blanks in 80 minutes.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A picture of a presidency that traded on the celebrity of its chief executive to sell simple, reactionary ideas about taxes, social welfare programs, and national defense to fiercely devoted supporters.
As blandly forgettable as its title.
Telling the story of a psychopath and his sex-slave, the film balances the clinical and visceral.
In just under 80 minutes, Rolling Papers introduces enough ideas to fuel six documentaries-and with multiple layers to each.
Although Austrian writer/director Dominik Hartl has the right spirit for his alpine ghoul-fest, he ultimately lacks the material to generate more than mild amusement.

In the movie's best scene, as mother and son dance to an old pop song, the look on Reynor's face speaks volumes about loss and hope. It's a look that's going to be breaking hearts on screen for decades to come.

Darkman is funny, but it's no joke; it's the work of a man who underlines the conventions of adventure stories and horror because he enjoys them, and knows that even when rendered tongue-in-cheek, they're timeless.
There's a honest, moving core to Sick Birds Die Easy, which suggests that every potential utopia will be undone by human nature
King Of The Hill balances an incident-packed script with muted tones, painting a rich, absorbing picture of one boy's struggle to live by his wits.
The Lunchbox comes across as a crafty crowd-pleaser, but with a clever structure[.]
Chicago becomes less of a literal skewering of how celebrity criminals manipulate a rigged game, and more of a pure fantasy, not meant to be taken seriously.
Nymphomaniac looks like a major work from a major director: a compendium of [...] preoccupations with gender roles, authoritarianism, religion, obsessive behavior, and lust.
While it's corny by design, Hairspray also aims to get at something truthful, about the various kinds of prejudice [...] and how youthful optimism and music made a difference [...].

[...] For a movie about something as painful as child sexual abuse, Mysterious Skin doesn't repel. There's an allure to the images, which are as carefully posed and framed as figures in a softly illuminated dollhouse.
[The film is] about a woman chasing a feeling [...] With thoughtfulness and passion, von Trier strives to give his audience a high, accompanied by the meaning of the high.
The best parts of Jodorowsky's Dune explain just how a mad genius like Jodorowsky almost made the impossible possible, just by declaring it to be so.
Every standoff is larger in scale, and designed to make the one before look like prep-work [but] Even at their most extreme, the action scenes are grounded in human physicality-and frailty.
As effectively as almost any movie ever made about American suburbia, The Swimmer gets the contentment that comes with material success[...] And it gets how the fantasy is hard to sustain.
It's an outsized, abstracted version of everyday life circa 1930.
Hateship Loveship is unimpressive as a whole, but it's stitched together with small, memorable touches [...]

Nothing in Svankmajer's Alice is inappropriate per se [...] and Svankmajer does stay true to the particulars of Carroll's book. But he also put his personal stamp on Alice, by literalizing on film a lot of what reads as fantasy on the page.
Manakamana is both calming and imagination-sparking, forcing viewers to look at human faces for 10-minute stretches, whether those faces are talking excitedly or quietly looking around.
[...]The reason The Five Obstructions lingers as an essential part of von Trier's filmography [...] is because it reveals so much about why von Trier has worked the way he has in the past [...]
[Spike] Lee doesn't judge Tyson's sins, but he does express an attitude toward his story, through the way he frames a desperately ingratiating Tyson at a persistent remove.
The Returned is sort of about prejudice and paranoia, but for the most part, the social commentary is as absent as the action, with both taking a back seat to clever conceptualizing.
There's a spooky poetry to the climactic sequences of Kumiko, as a one-of-a-kind individual disappears into the snow, in search of a memorable movie prop that also disappeared into the snow.

7 Boxes is way too simple, but it mostly works, because every twist of the plot and turn of the street leads back to this one kid, who'll do anything to make enough money to become someone other than himself.
Some Velvet Morning is absorbing and enraging, sure to spark debate both about its meaning and its method.
Bogliano provides a steady series of jolts, all the way to an ending that's twisty but ultimately unsatisfying.
Kaye is at his best in Up In Arms, where he stops the show multiple times.
The premise is a thin thread on which the Goldwyn creative team hang big numbers, often barely related to the plot.
The Kid From Brooklyn keeps stalling the plot to fit in another of the usual Goldwyn musical-comedy elements
The best parts of the movie Mitty are the ones that hew closer to Thurber, because they put the cartoonish Kaye in a world every bit as nutty.
movie_title: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty (1947)

movie_review_blurb: A dreary affair, sanding off the original's satirical edges.
The Five Pennies is a solidly crafted movie that glosses over a lot of the real history of jazz.
Bicycling With Molière lacks the roughness of real life, or even the expressiveness of cinema. It plays like theater-and dinner theater at that.
The Selfish Giant is never so bleak that it's unwatchable. On the contrary: It's so immediately engaging that it's hard not to watch.
Every scene of The Killing Fields (and every participant in its making) is in service of showing how abruptly a seemingly safe and vital individual can have everything essential stripped away.
There's a strong narrative pull to Generation War as it moves from one crisis to another, [and] many of those crises are genuinely exciting and suspenseful.

As is often the case with Kore-eda's films, [the] larger theme emerges gradually, and mostly via low-key, slice-of-life scenes that initially seem too aimless, but make more sense once it's clearer where Like Father, Like Son is going.
[S]een alongside Godard's other films, Hail Mary isn't that shocking. It's a film of great sensitivity and yearning[.]
For Ever Mozart's wryly postmodern take on art vs. reality struck even some longtime Godard defenders as unconscionable at worst, tedious at best.
Some of what [Godfrey] Reggio is trying to say is obvious, and some is elusive. Either way, the effect is remarkable.
Tim's Vermeer is a highly entertaining, provocative film about an amazing experiment, and it's straightforward in its presentation and aims, throwing no curveballs.

With its earthy Sven Nykvist cinematography and its emphasis on the character's rumpled clothes and weathered homes, this Postman is like something from the [Bob] Rafelson of 10 years earlier: pensive and realistic.
The Great Flood works as a wordless narrative of human endurance.
Whether the movie's message is Travers-approved or not, the emphasis on joy and empathy proves heartening, even today.
No matter how creative its frames, Mr. Jones is [...] just an unimpressive stack of sticks and skulls.

With Devil's Knot, Egoyan doesn't make this material his own, so much as he halfheartedly restages what a few good documentarians have already shot. Anyone could've made this movie. Too many already have.
...Zwick never really solves the problem of how to make a houseful of semi-likable characters into cinema.
The violence isn't unmotivated, or generic. Fleischer and Leonard establish the setting and premise well enough that it's damn near tragic when Renda shoots up Majestyk's watermelon crop.

The movie offers an unusual spin on a classic Hollywood genre... by starting in a relatively civilized part of late-19th-century America and then rolling way out into the wilderness, becoming more of a Western as it goes.
Here's a seemingly twee movie that ultimately, surprisingly argues that some music isn't for everybody, some people are too broken to fix, and some would-be artists are better off in the audience.
...if The Possession Of Michael King had embraced its movie-ness, it might've said something powerful about what it's like to be Michael King.
Cattet and Forzani are more interested in the imagery and textures of giallo than they are in telling a rich, comprehensible story.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Willis Earl Beal is a mysterious presence in his own movie: a man in a stylish hat and a dirty shirt, who can pass for a rock star in one moment and a homeless drifter the next.
God Help The Girl is ultimately an affirmation of life and music: a quirky little how-to manual on surviving the worst of youth by learning how to contain it within a frame.
All That Jazz is one of the most self-indulgent movies ever made-but blessedly so.
This is a wisp of a movie, and yet it deals with an experience so pervasive that it's usually barely acknowledged-this restlessness people feel to fly off to somewhere else.
A Life In Dirty Movies is also fascinating just as a document of changing cultural mores.
Ultimately, any point gets drowned out by all the self-satisfied laughter.
The beauty of To Be And To Have is that Lopez's loss isn't the audience's. This movie is a portal, leading to a living museum of childhood.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As disgusting, harrowing, and ugly as the 1974 horror classic The Texas Chain Saw Massacre is, the film has moments of eerie beauty.
Ghost In The Shell is an ultra-violent, rocket-paced film-over and out in just over 80 minutes-but it's a poetic one, too.
"Mavis!" is maybe too short and too plain, but it covers a lot of ground and contains a lot of great music. It's a fitting tribute to a true American original, belatedly getting her due.
A Good Marriage comes off as curiously flat for a movie about a woman who sleeps next to a murderer every night.
...even in scenes of Kuti in his prime, Finding Fela can only give so much time to any one song or speech. Just when Kuti is getting on a roll, Gibney is ready to move on to something else.
What's so overpoweringly beautiful about The Umbrellas Of Cherbourg is that it matches human-scaled feelings of regret with the color and intensity of the movies Demy loved as a boy.
movie_title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (Les Parapluies de Cherbourg) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: The plotting is weak, and ill-served by the movie's generally lackadaisical approach; but the dialogue is witty, and Wilder and Diamond get a lot of mileage out of the idea that Sherlock Holmes is as fragile as he is brilliant.
movie_title: The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes (1970)

movie_review_blurb: Witness For The Prosecution has the pace and patience of live theater, but not the look. Wilder doesn't get overly flashy with camera moves and angles, but he does shift positioning subtly and effectively.
[...] a crushing disappointment. It's a sluggish movie with nothing to say about the moral rot of the powerful that the first two parts didn't say much better [...]
[...] Overlord's vision of war is still unlike that of any other fiction feature: more jarring, and more awe-inspiring.

[...] It's rare to see a movie where the first five minutes reveal almost nothing about what the audience can expect in the last five. [...] It looms over viewers like it can't wait to kick their ass. And then it kicks.

The Dance Of Reality represents Jodorowsky in an accessible mode, telling a version of his life story in a way that will allow anyone who's never seen any of his work before [...] to get a good sense of who he is and what he's all about.

Firth and Diaz, game as they are, look lost and disappointed most of the time during Gambit, as though they pictured themselves making Burn After Reading, and instead found themselves in The Ladykillers.
[...] We Are The Best! captures both the spirit of the early 1980s and the way pre-teens and teens have their own ideas of what's important.
There's an awkwardness to Ravenous' more violent scenes, and while Carlyle and Jones give zesty performances, the rest of the supporting cast is quirky to a fault.

Dormant Beauty always comes back to the difficult decisions that family members have to make for each other, contrasted with the huffiness of outsiders who try to project their own beliefs onto someone else's business.

The strength of Eastwood's Bridges is in its patience, and how it lets the love story develop from start to finish, even though the audience knows from the beginning the broad strokes of what's going to happen.
[Jerry] Lewis constructed one of his sturdiest scripts in The Nutty Professor, and he wasted scarcely a minute of it.
Judex's pacing is syrupy and its tone hazy, like a halting, half-remembered dream of a movie that may have never existed.
Polanski's direction of Venus In Fur is masterful-a pleasure in and of itself-but Seigner is the star attraction here, giving one of the best performances of her distinguished career.
[This] documentary portrait of Honig at the end of his life ... puts the poet's state of constant "now" in the context of the brilliant but sometimes cruel man he used to be.
Beyond its genre roots and its deeper meanings, Southern Comfort is a well-honed study of characters and setting.
Rarely has anything like this been attempted in cinema, with a filmmaker intentionally setting out to watch a young person grow up on screen.
The Congress frequently feels way too ponderous, as though Folman were sure he was saying something important with this film, and didn't want anyone to miss any of it.
The film [is] a warped mirror on American family life, depicting parenting as an act of grotesque selfishness.
Though A Master Builder is disappointing for not being a great film, it's affecting as another record of Shawn and Gregory's passion for theater.
Hellion lingers for most of its running time in a betwixt-and-between place, never becoming either the sublime character sketch or the overripe melodrama it alternately promises to be.
Her is such a well-drawn character sketch-with such a fantastic Chastain performance-that it practically justifies the whole experiment.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, Miracle On 34th Street is pure Hollywood hokum... But the film is pretty savvy too, getting a jump on mounting anxieties about the post-war cult of consumerism.
Mark Mori's feature-length Page homage Bettie Page Reveals All has the goods when it comes to its subject.

Rivers' use of older camera equipment gives Two Years At Sea the look of an old piece of film that's been left behind by a long-gone civilization, capturing the last man on Earth, and showing how he made use of all the old junk society left behind.

If Ishtar has a personal stamp, it's not in what it has to say about Reagan-era militarism, but in what it has to say about collaboration, and how well-meaning people can goose each other to greatness-and folly.
Beneath the affectations, there's poetry in Kid-Thing, and truth in its depiction of how absolute freedom can be a kind of trap.

With his Muppets, Henson found a balance between fuzzy post-hippie positivism and self-deprecating wit, and he added in the same quality that made many of the era's cultural phenomena so charming: simple problem-solving.
The film lacks the more corrosive aspects of [Jacques] Tardi's work, but Besson replaces it with something that gives the story a larger shape and meaning.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Everything is explicit; no one makes an unexpected move.
There's a context to Struzan -- not just biographically, but culturally -- and while Sharkey seems to understand that, his movie, ironically, doesn't illustrate it particularly well.
movie_title: Drew: The Man Behind The Poster (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In The Final Fight, the frequent full-combat interludes work against the truth-vs.-fiction themes of the rest of the film.
Mostly, The Big City is impressive for how Ray makes his observations about Arati's lot in life without saying anything directly.
The reason Charulata is often talked about as one of Ray's best is that so much of the story is told through images alone.
Harlan's film -- written by Vikram Weet -- is a routine low-budget genre picture, with blandly attractive young actors overmatched by the freakiness lurking in the wilderness.
Ali's greatest fight, covered in this film as it never has been before, was to be accepted as himself, not as anyone's symbol.
This is a small film about a society of castoffs, and while it's beautifully acted and often moving, it's also predictable, because it keeps wresting itself into familiar forms.

'Tokyo Waka' is mostly about crows, but it's in no way a conventional nature doc, because Haptas and Samuelson use the relationship between these birds and their habitat to contemplate how animals adapt to the modern world.

The movie's two main aims -- to blow the lid off the music business and to exalt some of the unsung heroes of American pop culture -- are somewhat contradictory, and haven't been worked into a polished narrative.
Gods Of The Plague is rich with pathos, treating these petty thieves and murderers as tragic figures.
movie_title: Gods of the Plague (Gotter der Pest) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Fassbinder toys with the imagery of noir and pulp, peppering The American Soldier with long scenes of men in hats driving through darkened city streets, and throwing in references to Batman comics and science-fiction.
The movie is one long game of misdirection, playing tricks on viewers from scene to scene, and showing how easy it is to steer a crowd into missing something important.
Shelton seems so preoccupied with making Touchy Feely feel natural and real that she's forgotten to add any incident.
It's entertaining as far as it goes, but this doc's greatest value may be as research material for the next great international caper film.
movie_title: Smash & Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The lack of anything resembling a narrative at times makes Pavilion feel more like a demo-reel than a movie, but the fleeting moments Sutton has captured are so vibrant that they accumulate into something that hums.
There's a matter-of-factness to Israel: A Home Movie that's disquieting, as it shows the joy and determination of a nation in the making, and the dismayed faces of those elbowed aside.
The Hunt works as simplistic, cathartic melodrama. It's about ambiguity, but there's nothing ambiguous about the film itself.

Ultimately, Berberian Sound Studio is just an exercise in meta -- a movie more about generating sensations than making sense -- but it's provocative and effective in the way it shows how a movie doesn't have to be "real" to be disturbing.

A Hijacking is more about one incident than about how it relates universally, but in thoughtfully exploring the specifics and emotions of that incident, Lindholm is able to show how modern life sometimes seems devoid of any accord.
Neville's greatest strength is as a historian, able to sort through a wealth of details to find the pieces he needs to tell one clear, compelling story.
Byzantium offers a twist or two on the traditional vampire mythology ... but otherwise [its] gothic atmosphere and air of tragedy feel awfully familiar.
The default middle ground between true-to-life and wacky in I Give It A Year turns out to be a place of dreary artificiality.
The Kentucky Fried Movie misses as often as it hits, but when the writers and Landis arrive at a great idea ... it's like watching an entire fruitful comic perspective being spawned.
That's what Katzelmacher is: a punishment, via art, leveled at all the ignorant, egotistical racists Fassbinder had known.
Nothing Can Hurt Me is a must for fans ... because so much of Big Star's story has been parceled out piecemeal over the years, in anecdotes and liner notes.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There just isn't enough going on beneath Beneath.
Even with Boris Karloff providing a lighthearted introduction and sign-off, Black Sabbath is fraught with fatalism.
movie_title: Black Sabbath (I Tre volti della paura) (The Three Faces of Fear) (The Three Faces of Terror) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: As is often the case in the Bava-verse, Kidnapped turns out to be located at the intersection of every dime-paperback plot, in that wild space populated by crooks, vampires, astronauts, and cowboys, all tromping inexorably to The End.
movie_title: Rabid Dogs (Cani arrabbiati) (Kidnapped) ( A Man and a Boy) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: The biggest issue with Grabbers is that it's more slick than squirmy. Aside from a few good low-fi gross-out scenes ... Grabbers has the look and style of a big-budget action epic, not a scrappy little indie-horror.
Ultimately, The Act Of Killing acknowledges that while Oppenheimer may have subtly tortured their conscience, these thugs are paying no real price.
Plot and character sketchiness aside, though, Vanishing Waves is incredibly absorbing, because Buozyte and Samper are smart about how sexual urges can override all reason and obligation.
While Drug War is ultimately more an exercise in craft than a movie with a lot on its mind, it's a remarkably skillful exercise, and hardly devoid of ideas.
Ultimately, Schesch and Weber's deliberate rhythms prove to be an asset, as the lunar hero explores the wonder of this world, refusing to get roped into anybody's action-plot.
All four of the main performances are so strong that they deserve more space to develop and intertwine.
The Punk Singer is assembled well, moving efficiently through the most important pieces of Hanna's biography...while Hanna and her friends explain the significance.
Love Is Colder Than Death is heavily abstracted, with the characters more like models in a fashion layout than people in a story.
Red Obsession is informative, and entertainingly so, with its honeyed Russell Crowe narration and sweet tracking shots through sun-dappled vineyards.
Spinning Plates is a slow starter...But the documentary finds more of a rhythm once it moves beyond generalities and starts getting into particulars.
Il Futuro is a playful, soulful movie, affecting because it's populated by lost children who can somehow sense they're in a movie.
Garrone doesn't deliver any kind of scathing indictment of human exploitation, making Hanging For Django mainly a pastiche/ripoff of Leone's best moves.
movie_title: Una Lunga Fila di Croci (Hanging for Django) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: Eastwood holds fast to the rebel spirit of the spaghetti Westerns and revisionist "New Hollywood" Westerns of the previous decade, but packages it in a film that's slicker and more mainstream-friendly.
The movie as a whole is hamfistedly whimsical and poetic, but Walken and Kidder are fascinating to watch.
Zizek doesn't build a cohesive argument;...he just pivots from point to point as though he were reading notes for a paper, not the paper itself.
This documentary is as much a thank-you as a lament.
movie_title: Baby Peggy: The Elephant in the Room (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Go For Sisters still does well what Sayles' films have nearly always done well: It tells a story with enough accumulated detail that by the end, it feels like it's really gotten somewhere.
Ultimately, Birth Of The Living Dead is little more than a glorified DVD featurette, but it's the kind of featurette that most Romero fans probably wouldn't mind watching more than once.
Even aside from what it's saying, and even with the many, many forced moments, JFK has a mad genius about it.
Too much of Dear Mr. Watterson is taken up by Schroeder and an array of non-professional C&H-lovers offering vague praise, with little to no real analysis-aesthetic, historical, or cultural.
Cold Turkey is well-acted, and at times even well-observed, but about 20 minutes of the material actually matters, and the rest is mere putter.
The movie's best effect is its star...He looks every bit like an actual demonic wild-thing, retrieved from deep within the German wilderness and trotted out to perform for Murnau's camera.
movie_title: Nosferatu, a Symphony of Horror (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (Nosferatu the Vampire) (1922)

movie_review_blurb: Anton Corbijn Inside Out is damnably stingy with expert analysis of Corbijn's art...There's no attempt to organize the events of Corbijn's life into a chronology, or to trace his evolution as an image-maker.

Even though Gondry and Chomsky's very different sensibilities don't mesh in such a way that either man's work gains substantially from the alliance, they're each such good company individually that Is The Man Who Is Tall Happy? is still entertaining.
movie_title: Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?: An Animated Conversation with Noam Chomsky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Knightriders is about 50 percent scenes of kick-ass moto-jousting, 40 percent philosophizing around the campfire, and 10 percent lyrical shots of King William
Mettler is fascinated by the slow process of natural decay, and how much of it is caused by human neglect or interference.
13 Frightened Girls! is like a Disney version of a spy picture, completely devoid of anything objectionable, aside from some outdated notions of gender roles.
What's really surprising about Homicidal is that...it's an enjoyably bizarre film, making some of the basic elements of Psycho even freakier.

[E]xcruciatingly punishes impressive international ensemble. [U]npredictable who will make it through each challenge [that] brings human perspective to a large continent.
[S]emi-autobiographical trilogy of Palestinian family's experiences from '48. . .culminates in. . .epic storytelling, with maturity and sorrow to match his now gray hair.
Surprising, humanistic tour through the detritus of global disorder with a motley individuated crew on an odyssey in a bleak, stormy landscape from Israel to ex-Soviet bloc.
[F]irst seems like just a charming tale of an old guy's quest for literacy. . .[but] it strikes a higher note: there's a lot to be learned about a forgotten generation.
[G]lorious, exuberant clips . . spectacularly illustrate gospel's chronological and stylistic history. . .and personal memories of several icons add warm backstage anecdotes.
The simple and stark contrast between playful children in a rustic soccer field and the tension over their modern risk is heart-pounding and breath-stopping.
Art tourists [get] special access [to] Kiefer channeling creative and destructive energy of boys (mankind? male artists?) in intellectual context and fantastic, adult scale.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [I]ntimate historical epic. . .of amazingly connected. . .aristocrats [in] flashbacks within flashbacks. . . stunning settings [and] tangled romantic quadrangles.
Thrilling when maintains damning focus on real woman's revelations about deep involvement of UN personnel and contractors, and her defiant determination against great odds.
[Despite] a rousing jam with elder blues icons [and] Zegers' showy role. . .story feels like a studied period recreation for the History Channel.
movie_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cloaks melodrama in a history lesson to personalize fraught events, trace how they were forgotten and rediscovered, with tears and some happiness found along the way.
[D]ramatic when rhetoric matches street action, they fearlessly divert retaliation on street corners and at funerals [so] the cycle can be interrupted one person at a time.
Both fresh and familiar,. . .[t]he irony of spending time with normal kids. . .played by a personable, age-appropriate, sweetly charming cast . . . is they are a bit bland.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [T]he young stars are so emotionally mature. . . almost too extraordinarily resourceful and heroic in managing family crises and facing death [but] inspire adults.
[F]eminist lessons are more charmingly symbolic than didactic . . .in striking images of what [she] was dreaming [at] the heart of the film [to] make her fantasy quite real.
[B]lows away Shakespearean fairy dust on fusty nostalgic notions of classic Yiddish theater, with exuberance of lo-fi Luhrmann in a West Side Story set in exotic Brooklyn.
Atmospherically steeped in rural noir. . .Stormare's agonized face keeps the focus on more a tormented character study than a mystery. . .greatly heightened by rootsy songs.
[A]voids cloying clichés through the bittersweet lessons each learns [to show] "I love you" can be richer, more nuanced, and more expansive than Hollywood fairy tales.
[E]ngrossingly generates as much suspense as fiction in . . . an unusually intimate portrait of a resilient [woman in prison] and a resistant criminal justice system.
[D]espite confusing presentation of . . . specifics of each song and artist . . . the passion comes through, enthusiastically bringing Neapolitan music to the world stage.
[M]odern version of Westward the Women . . .offers American moviegoers an entertaining, yet classy, [romantic] vacation trip through time and place.
Title phrase. . . is never said, but is powerfully visual [in] Pistereanu's blisteringly charismatic performance as he shifts from menacing violence to solicitous and caring.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [I]ntimately puts together pieces of a middle-aged woman's liberation into a charmingly fresh whole. . .[with] the burgeoning glow of the quietly expressive Onetto.
[M]ore focus on showy slam than ...writing poetry. How the best performers-and the best young poets-dig down deep and polish their work, finally makes this a satisfying film.
[A]ccomplishes difficult task of appealing both to nostalgic fans of Ochs and younger students of. . .the life and times of the political troubadour of the 1960's and 1970's.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [M]ore than a footnote to the 1960's counterculture, he's serious fun in this [genial] bio-documentary on the role of the clown/fool in society.
movie_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [H]ow a bill becomes a law in DC--a comedy. . .Spacey gives the full razzle dazzle of a flamboyant, complex idealist-turned-wheeler dealer. . .Lovitz is hilariously serious.
Slowly unfolds in a vérité style to quietly root for the hopes and dreams of distinctive individuals in a corner of the underground economy who manage to feel optimistic.
Standard ingredients of predictable nuptial nonsense are given an enjoyable new spin in contemporary, middle-class, multiracial, multilingual South Africa.
Less on the surfing and more on the entertainingly eccentric surfers, but narration can be as insufferable as it is informative, with superficial clichés of sports reportage.
Overplays blindness metaphors and foreign issues, but relishes the passionate theatricality of folk rituals, with some surrealism, to combine the poetic with the political.
Powerful warning with universal message-movies lie. Without memory and context, we forget the truth and believe what we see. Meticulously detailed, overwhelmingly emotional.
Broad, entertaining satire, with heartfelt pleas, on the difficulties for the farmers and those who try to help them.
Cogently and movingly provides fresh perspective on history while the screen splits with interviews that bring out mixed feelings for reconciliation vs. forgetting the past.
Avoids didacticism by convincingly creating romantic characters whose youthful naiveté is worth rooting for, even as their brief escape into optimism is sadly defeated.
movie_title: Salt of This Sea (Milh Hadha al-Bahr) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A few fresh twists on the usual saga of an outlaw family violently imploding. The chilling reason to see this is Weaver's smiling lioness protecting her favorite cub.
A literal and metaphorical tour de force about war through what a young tank crew can see and hear, it is a wrenching tribute to the travails of the universal soldier.
A powerful personal quest, the first film to show living perpetrators of genocide from the highest policymaker down through the administrator and the lowest killer.
[T]houghtful and entertaining look at the changes in our celebrity-obsessed culture over the past 40 years as seen through a ubiquitous lens and controversial career.
Moving poetry, very appealing actors, lovely landscape, and resonant music can't quite make up for the predictable family story and dialogue in a heartfelt film.
This extraordinary profile in courage starkly bears passionate and brave witness as two flinty farmers stand up for their rights in a good vs. evil fight.
Brutal, yet thoughtful, re-envisioning of the Viking saga that powerfully showcases Mikkelsen's non-verbal acting skills in striking imagery and evocative landscapes.
Broadly uses the universality of melodramatic emotions to overwhelm specifically set moral and violent battles.
Revealing portrait of 3 very different young people intensely focused on being champions, and the impact of their determination on their devoted families (and vice versa).
A couple . . . who can still prove that true love never dies--only if love can survive this heavy-handed dose of sentimentality landing on it.
Delightful musical trip of a teenage Aborigine through 1960's Australian outback with wonderful rocking mix of song genres, let alone hippies, to feel like Hair.
Beautifully plays out every girl's rebellious fantasy to do whatever she wants one summer. . .Combines realism with the magical perspective of the interior life of childhood.
Many clichés in uneven and odd mix of guffaws and philosophical analysis. . .[C]onsiderable violence surprisingly erupts...[M]ost fun is watching Norton interact with Norton.
Creatively uses the animal parable. . .in a very original approach to history that is as thought provoking as it is amusing. . . by anthropomorphizing politics.
movie_title: Rabbit a la Berlin (Królik po berlinsku) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Subtly changing the [novel's] darker tone, [t]he almost-too-sweet film's emotional climax arrives with a simple hug [as] a transforming human connection.
Merciless honesty makes an irascible Canadian reprobate surprisingly poignant . . . Hoffman shines in a gem of a scabrous performance. . .The women are more problematical.
Even with the glorification of Benazir Bhutto as a martyr to democracy, the personalizing of . . . this tinderbox helps make Pakistan's . . .politics more comprehensible.
[C]harmingly recalls earlier enjoyable finding-family-through-food-preparation movies. . .[that] did not include an Indian-American family. [Shah] positively twinkles.
[N]one of the boxing movie stereotypes -- Wiseman has found in Austin a very unusual boxing gym. . .for a kind of physical therapy. . .The lack of violence is emphasized.
[M]ost deliciously realized is the fleshing out of the Cold Warriors in the Swedish intelligence service, whose plotting reaches into the hospital, the police, and the court.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Enchanting song-and-dance numbers burst onto the screen as full-fledged musical tours de force. . . mak[ing] the typical mumblecore scenes in-between that much more boring.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [S]low portrait of damaged woman struggling against community expectations reveals universality [in] extraordinary Do-yeon who dramatically shifts gears again [and again].
[C]ontemporary Western. . . in S. Australia . . .spins new suspense . . . in a familiar story. . .with a stunning setting, compelling characters, and post-colonial guilt.
Closely follows remarkable story, from many viewpoints, of [a] community . . . creat[ing] an unusual paradigm for nonviolent protest . . .where most think that's impossible.
Three riveting performances anchor this engrossing . . .story of Lennon’s youth before [the] Beatles . . .even before the teen is seen writing his first song with McCartney.
[S]erviceable tutorial on the basics of the global financial crisis [that] targets provocative elements-. . .the global impact,. . . academics [and] updates the troubles.
A disservice to an influential psychiatrist and to an audience interested in the history of the Holocaust. . .no thoughtful or clarifying interviewer.
A learning-is-fun . . .anthology . . .with more pluses than minuses, [it] is as entertaining as it's educational and enlightening.
Valuable and educational resource. . .thoughtful, systematic, and unflinching presentation of legal case makes it relevant as a model for bringing charges in . . .genocide.
Fascinating for urban and film historians, but also a moving tribute to film's timeless power to illuminate social issues. See with new The Perfect Team:The Making of.
Though becomes less interesting when it turns doctrinaire, personal angle and substantive investigation make it involving and entertaining enough to absorb its warning.
[B]est at . . .probing . . . Israeli government's justifications, but doesn't bring same level of inquisition in looking at how Rachel arrived [at Gaza] that fateful day.
Markopolos goes on and on. . to seem monomaniacal. . . that any rational major investor should have suspected [but] he deserves his victory lap.
Past and present, the living and the ghosts, eerily collide [in a] a universal and specific story of solidarity. . . to keep on living victoriously over inhumanity.
Confused irony about Israeli self-delusion over heroes or the personal and nationalist consequence of living with a Big Lie are uneasily subsumed by changes in women's roles.
Just when it seems to be going [for] an amusing family Thanksgiving comedy, it zings sharply (and awkwardly) into exposing raw emotions from painful wounds sisters share.
The remarkable landscape of Australia's outback [and] Weaving's paternal to scary on a dime performance makes [it] much more than a depressing story about an abusive father.
Portrait[s] of the individual determination and nationalistic fervor that seems to driv[e] China to the top in so many fields surmounts the sameness of this universal story.
[A]uthenticity of the local cast and the rare images of a shantytown Roma ghetto in mountainous Slovakia outweigh stereotypes and the imposition of a Hamlet-like story.
[P]owerful rage against system carried by victims who detail sexism, harassment, stalking, rape, reprisals, and rebuffed complaints [whose] attackers haven't been punished.
[A]musing flashes of imagination. . . . turn into a conventional road movie, with usual. . . quirky characters. . . Carell and Knightley [not] a convincing romantic couple.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Big Bang Theory fans [should] transport . . . to a similarly charming story of endearing nerds and the practical companions drawn into their skewed orbit.
Besides blatant chick flick romantic appeal, the mothers/daughters relationships hold a modicum of interest . . .plus an incidental memorial tribute to the late Levon Helm.
Timely warning about political messages behind philanthropic-corporate complex that tied fundraising, research, discussion, and perceptions about breast cancer in a pink bow.
Where do cats go at night? Animated Cat delightfully answers that eternal question for young and older audiences [in] a city of shadows enveloped in noir sounds of jazz.
[I]n the middle of the West Bank . . .this unusual blending of the personal and the political moves intensely, if narrowly, behind the shouting and shooting on the TV news.
Cheerfully rocking alternative to Hollywood sappy, romantic comedies. . .Treadaway and Tena are a magnetic roller coaster at the center. Casting actors who can rock pays off.
[B]attle-of-the-sexes romantic comedy around a real historical figure. . .with fun and fanciful imagination about his life and his invention inspired by. . .social currents.
Suspensefully mounts evidence that the same collectors who basked in the reflected glory of the rising value of Schiele's works set up an elaborate conspiracy.
About as feel-good a fable set in the Middle East as can be imagined infused with music and magic realism [with] a female narrator.
Where the title character travels is a visually and emotionally striking journey.
Well-meaning biopic will barely satisfy people's curiosity about a little-seen woman. Played up as more tragic personal sacrifice than politics, she remains a noble symbol.
A call to citizen participation [through a] portrait of shoe leather political organizing pre-social media is lively, but seems more enjoyably quaint than inspiring.
[H]as a promising story to follow [but] disappointing, either as an introduction to progressive bluegrass or for longtime Thile fans.
Through interviews and animations, this entertaining musical mystery tour. . .traces. . .an engaging story so full of colorful characters . . .that I was leery of a hoax.
Though aided by beautiful views of Haifa, some amusing entertainment, and flashes of poignancy, the appeal is mostly heavily laden, cross-generational nostalgia.
Modern day follow-up to Sunrise At Campobello. . .awkwardly grafted on follow-up to King's Speech [that] seems exaggerated. . .with winking FDR [and] insular view of Eleanor.
Lots of surprises and unusual brio. . . in sorting out decades of stories and confusing points of view [with] visual documentation. Very entertaining.
A dazzling looking, amazingly adaptable theater transforms into. . . a busy eyeful of sturm und drang, where the gentler love story of Kitty and Levin outshines the tragedy.
Deaf victims passionately sign about years of anguish and pleas [but film] rambles. . .around the world [and] confusingly tries to pierce hierarchy to what pope knew when.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Punctuated with pungent visual and narrative footnotes, comes close to being the Pentagon Papers of the Israeli occupation of the Palestinian Territories' legal framework.
Hemingway gives her naïf substance and Johnson turns her crone into a caring mother-figure. . .in surprising ways so their winning poignancy makes up for the fanciful [end].
Glaciers melt alarmingly fast in exciting story of obsessed pied piper with a camera traveling by boat, copter, and dogsled into the Arctic to download astonishing footage.
The old country comes to the New World in a magical tale with ancient roots of a prodigal son returning for revenge . . .like a cinematic DeToqueville. . . kooky and lovely.
How the sons begin to share each other's lives is sensitively portrayed, and the film's more original than the usual Romeo and Juliet personalization of the regional divide.
[A]voids bathos. . .reveals unexpected depth in a heartbreaking bond. . . Different classes conflict [in] adjacent spaces . . .in spare, realistic Dardennes' style.
Brave, well-meaning effort. . .with a mostly local crew in a high-risk locale. . . Best scenes in too-simplistic film are glimpses of cultural traditions, especially music.
Adds to documentary canon of the Holocaust as it grapples with repercussions and impact decades later on the next generation. . .though [family] arguments are hard to follow.
Who lied or who hid the truth?. . .The more and more public facts and private revelations Goldfinger uncovers are tantalizingly confounding and irresistibly fascinating.
Beautifully sets up the feel and the times. . .with archival photographs and footage [but] distracts from. . .the intimate aural relationship between Fass and his audience.

A heartfelt tribute. . . participants thoughtfully and personally debate their choice. . .to protect their children in a utopia where they could grow up safe and socialist.

Embedded filmmakers on the frontlines of the war on middle and high school kids who don't fit in expose the battles they and their families face, survive, or, worse, lose.
[M]akes climate change dramatic, political, personal, and the right stuff of leadership. . . The film would seem hagiographic if his biography weren't so stirring.
Amidst excruciating violence, the storyline is not as strong as the harrowingly indelible performances.
Angry finger-pointing examination of how a Nazi war criminal influenced U.S. foreign policy for 40 years. . . Revealing look at torture history is even more relevant today.
Each day is a suspenseful challenge of how [the kid] keeps up a freeing masquerade; it's striking to see how gender casually figures into the daily life of children at play.
Herzog takes a startlingly clear-eyed look at crime and capital punishment in Texas. . . He just seeks to shine a light on the facts for the viewer to soberly decide.
Puts the hard work of teachers and their students into a realistic context and balanced perspective about the impact of the arts on teenagers' lives.
Hour by hour over this 24 hour period, the tension builds as to who will give in to what ethical lapses and how each will face the future.
Documentary about injustice piles on facts still needs to make a cinematic case [with] better graphics and clearer explanations. . .Fire images visually drown out reasoning.
[T]he moody film is a compassionate portrait, [but] wanders around the mostly downtrodden too much, even with brief flashes of optimism.
[U]pdate[s,] reinterprets the original material and incorporates old outtakes and photographs. . .for comprehensive forensic and legal analysis [but] confusingly organized.
Starts out like a teacher's history lesson about a vanished past, but turns into a detective story as memories collide, link to witnesses, and a nightmare starts to repeat.
Not a hatchet job. . .but adds so little insight by talking mostly to her enemies that a viewer almost becomes sympathetic about what she has to put up with. Almost.
A lovely little modern screwball comedy that only hard-hearted cynics will resist. An unexpected bonus comes with the delightful stream of old pro's as...master storytellers.
[S]upplements lots of stats with teachers' true tales. . . [E]ffective portraits poignantly personalize the multitude of charts and testimony from many education experts.
Too brief on details [but] earthy, living history of the roots of rap through the ribald and bemused perspective of a septuagenarian veteran of the music business.
[V]ivid archival footage from a time when African-American advocates. . .were not shown so up close and personal in U.S. . . despite being presented within an awkward format.
Trims book's absorbing plot down to the essentials of a complicated crime mystery and answers questions about that girl, but is not as visually exciting as the first film.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The focus stays on her internal transformation through the spiritual maturity that gives . . . a surprising sympathy for faith-based feminism rarely seen in films.
The charisma of the actors . . . helps communicate escalating tensions in changing relationships . . . in the hothouse of the freeing force of the unconscious.
From PTSD after a beating to. . .astounding rebirth into a new personality under the sea through dolphin therapy. . .the arc of Morad's life has to be seen to be appreciated.
Exploring enduring appeal to men,. . .the banality of human nature. . .may be a letdown, especially about elderly males, but is disturbingly universal as a modern fairy tale.
[R]eveals the personal cost of bringing first-hand information of conflict and war beyond borders [in a] sympathetic tribute.
[A]cademic research has never been shown with such visual verve. . . [E]ach professor's personality and expertise [is put] in sharp relief both comic and poignant.
Colorful visuals and sometimes overly broad sight gags communicate in a universal language [for] this heartwarming film infused with affection about growing up Maori.

Despite the miracle of the concluding uplift, the message is overwhelmingly that drugs will drown out the power of sex and rock 'n' roll.
Utterly heartbreaking. . . a moving addition to Panahi's oeuvre . . . [Iran] could try to silence one of its greatest filmmakers, but couldn't stop him creating art.
