movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Whimsy and geopolitical metaphor collide and then wobble away dazed.
Silent House must have been a nightmare to stage, yet director of photography Igor Martinovic makes it look effortless. Still, it's ultimately just a gimmick.
It's so effective at capturing the natural rhythms of being bored at work that the supernatural stuff feels like an unnecessary intrusion.
It's got explosions and horse-riding and fighting and monsters aplenty, but it evaporates almost as you're watching it.
It has just enough gravity to make you wish it delivered more fully on its potential.
I will say this for Man On A Ledge: most of the movie is indeed about a man on a ledge.
The animators lure us in with clever jokes and ingenious visuals and then sucker-punch us by revealing the characters' surprising emotional depths.

It reminds us how much we love Kermit, Fozzie, Miss Piggy, Animal, the Swedish Chef and all the rest, and it lets a lot of famous people -- among them Feist, Emily Blunt and Neil Patrick Harris -- pop up to express their own affection.
Fassbender lays himself bare in every way imaginable.
Like Marshall's last ensemble piece, Valentine's Day, New Year's Eve is strictly by the numbers, a generic exercise in empty momentum.
Unlike, say, Errol Morris in The Thin Blue Line, Herzog isn't seeking to exonerate anyone or introduce new evidence. He's just there, observing the process as it rolls forward and wondering why.

Lee aims to revive Goodman's legacy, using archival footage and thoughtful interviews with surviving friends and relations to create a portrait of a man who was quite literally too complicated for his times.
Polanski is a master at shooting this sort of thing. Anyone who's seen his nimble adaptation of Death And The Maiden knows he can turn a static drama into a pulsing, unnerving endurance test.
Sherlock Holmes: A Game Of Shadows improves on Guy Ritchie's previous Sherlock picture by abandoning any pretense that it's based on Arthur Conan Doyle's text.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Horn makes an appealing hero.

Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol isn't about geopolitical realism. It's about keeping your palms clammy with acrophobia (IMAX, baby) and your pulse at a certain rhythm while good guys do their best to keep the world turning.
Cronenberg's clinical approach to Hampton's too on-the-nose dialogue makes for a very static drama; it's as if the filmmaker is much more comfortable dealing with eroticism as subtext than text.
Quote not available.
The ever-mounting complications start to feel a little ridiculous about an hour in, but Kormákur keeps the action moving so swiftly that I didn't really mind.
Carano may not be a great acting discovery, but she suits this role just fine. She's entirely credible as an action hero.
Fiennes has assembled a terrific cast and given them their head, but the focus is rightly on his character, a ferocious warrior undone by his own integrity.
Quote not available.
Hawke gives a terrific performance as the disintegrating hero... and Bruce Greenwood is perfectly cast as his weary commanding officer, but they can't quite rise above the movie's mission statement.
Amy Ryan has a nice turn as Don's naive assistant, but her humanity is more than this movie can handle.
It's nicely observed, and at just 70 minutes doesn't overstay its welcome. Plus, cool dog.
Hildebrandt constructs a convincing case for space exploration as a massive economic opportunity right here on Earth.
We get a very safe, very respectful film that takes few chances and holds no surprises. Par for the course, I guess.
Having seen Everything, Everything, I have just one question: did that ending work in the book?
Even those with no horticultural ability whatsoever -- okay, I'm talking about myself -- can enjoy The Gardener.
It's fine for a bit, and even pleasant, but then you realize that you've seen all of these things before, and they aren't getting any fresher.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are a couple of decent action sequences and a nice running gag of insults directed at Efron's pretty-boy looks, but those are hardly reasons to make an entire movie, let alone one that's nearly two hours long.
Whenever Perez locks us in the Quangels' apartment with Otto, Anna and their secrets, Alone In Berlin is a master class in tension and intimacy.
The stiffness could be forgiven if the story were intriguing -- or even if Pinder and Levin were commenting on the format somehow -- but there's nothing here. I have no idea why this movie exists.
Mungiu uses one man's attempts to work the system to investigate the workings of the system itself.
Wonder Woman is good. Not great, but good. And really, after Man Of Steel, Batman V Superman: Dawn Of Justice and Suicide Squad, that's all it needs to be.
It's a paper-thin thriller that positions itself as a movie about the consequences of drone warfare, but it's really just a threadbare domestic drama with delusions of contemporary relevance.

The coming-of-age tale is familiar territory, but MacKay gives this one a sensual texture that feels like you're immersed in a really thoughtful short story, with a measured pace that gives us time to understand Sam's thoughts and feelings.

In My Cousin Rachel, Michell plays a similar psychological game as he did in his underrated 2004 adaptation of Ian McEwan's Enduring Love, coming right up to the edge of a proper thriller but never quite releasing the tension.
Ashley McKenzie's Werewolf is one of the strongest Canadian films you'll see this year.
The Transfiguration is a tragedy, but it's also a horror movie. And a very good one.
The Lovers is a colossal bore.
The Commune has its moments, but it never pulls itself together the way it clearly wants to.

Yes, it's visually striking -- except for the aliens themselves, rendered in weightless, glossy CG -- but it's also incoherent and pointlessly complicated, compounding the franchise with another unnecessary layer of space junk.
The feature debut of animator and cartoonist Dash Shaw, My Entire High School Sinking Into The Sea plays like a hipster graphic novel brought to life. I don't mean that as an insult.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gray's new film, The Lost City Of Z, is unlike anything he's done before. It's massive in scale and scope, a proper epic spanning two continents and nearly a quarter of a century.

Menorca never really works. Barnard's script is a strange, fluid construction of ideas past their sell-by date, animated by characters who remain frustratingly underdeveloped... Still, Gillis keeps you watching.
Gere is very good, offering glimpses of the emptiness behind Norman's smile rather than going bigger with the craven mugging the part seems to invite.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is the sort of movie that thinks scoring a gunfight with wacky banjo music will be hailed as original, or even daring.
It shifts tones and changes its thesis constantly, bobbing and weaving like a drunk trying to win an argument he can no longer follow. It's a uniquely frustrating experience.
Vol. 2 is as goofy a delight as its predecessor.

If the speedy cutting and celebrity-hungry nature of the package means we never get more than a superficial look at the real Ledger, there's enough here to encourage viewers to do more digging on their own.
Brett and Jason Butler have been making movies for a few years now, and they know what they like: tough guys standing around peacocking and insulting each other, and occasionally landing a joke.
Two minutes into The Sandwich Nazi, it's clear why Lewis Bennett wanted to make it: its eponymous subject, Salam Kahil, is absolutely fascinating.
Malek is always a fascinating screen presence, but he can't do much with long stretches of silent contemplation, especially when half of those find him buried under silly mountain-man makeup.

[Liman] clearly appreciates the chance to play at a smaller, more intimate scale. Cinematographer Roman Vasyanov's unnerving combination of wide shots and extreme close-ups makes open space feel fraught with danger.

In his feature debut, Australian writer/director Ben Young takes a simple and deeply unpleasant torture-porn narrative -- a young woman is abducted by a monstrous suburban couple -- and treats it like high art. It very nearly works.
Violet is a terrific first feature from an assured, confident talent.
You'll laugh, you'll gasp, you'll watch people's heads explode. What more can anyone ask for, really?
Someone needs to plunge a wooden stake into the heart of this franchise. Yes, I know that's for vampires rather than mummies. But seriously, I'll try anything.
Many of those segments are chilling and compelling enough to justify the digressions.

Mara is terrific at illustrating Leavey's complexities, especially in her scenes with Ramón Rodriguez as a military love interest and Bradley Whitford as her father. And the dogs who play Rex over a decade or so are beautiful animals.
Hayek and Lithgow are always watchable, but they've got very little to work with.
No, A Ghost Story isn't a horror movie -- unless you connect to the horror of the world moving on without you. In which case, yeah.
Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk is a stunning technical accomplishment -- like all of writer/producer/director Nolan's films, I suppose -- and also the leanest, sharpest thing he's made since Memento.
Girls Trip is funny and consistently entertaining, with female-empowering sexual content that will take your breath away.
Stretching over a century of recordings, Bainbridge draws some striking connections between Indigenous history and evolving American culture.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You just have to accept the darkness behind it as part of the package. Go see Brigsby Bear.
When [the directors] abandon their gimmicks and just let Al Gore deliver data, Truth To Power shows us why his work remains utterly relevant and tragically necessary.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Little Hours is a very silly idea that works perfectly, reinterpreting a story from Boccaccio's magnum opus as a goofy, cheerfully vulgar comedy performed by a fantastic cast of American goofballs.
No, it's nothing new. But it's pretty watchable all the same.
When [Kathryn] Bigelow traps us inside the Algiers [Hotel], Detroit packs more of a punch than any other film this year.
As a short film, this could have been an impressive stunt; as a feature, it's a waste of everyone's time, including the cast's.
Can someone please put this inane car-chase thriller back on the shelf?
The formulaic narrative is made unpredictable by the authentic surroundings and the potential complications of religion. But it's still formulaic.
Wind River is fine, and occasionally better than fine.
It's a familiar premise, but things play out in an unpredictable and engaging way.
Michael Winterbottom, Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon's third gustatory road trip scores familiar laughs, but it's still tasty stuff.

I see a lot of giant effects pictures -- it's an occupational hazard -- and I'd love to see more of them adopt the approach used in War For The Planet Of The Apes: make the effects invisible, and just tell a good story.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's fine, I guess, but if you've seen Hirschbiegel's previous examinations of the German character, Das Experiment and Downfall, you know he's capable of much more intensity and complexity than this project apparently allowed.
It's a solid horror premise, but director Tricia Lee and screenwriter Corey Brown stretch it a little too thin.

Does the world need three Cars movies? Probably not. But after 11 years, various spinoffs and a crap-ton of merchandising, Pixar's talking-vehicles franchise finally produces an instalment that feels like it's about something.

Heineman treats City Of Ghosts like a thriller, balancing talking-head interviews with tense set pieces created through music and editing. Maybe the story he's telling doesn't require any artistic enhancement, but you can't argue with the results.
The Book Of Henry positively drips with the unthinking cruelty and boneheaded story choices.
Is there a point? Nah. Like its brethren, Transformers: The Last Knight is a barrage of pixels and clutter with no real reason to exist except the perpetuation of its franchise.
For an hour or so it's a reasonably entertaining B movie. I just wish it had sustained that entertainment all the way to the end.
Sergio Navarretta's The Colossal Failure Of The Modern Relationship is a pretty generic romantic comedy with some appealing actors, set in the incredibly picturesque Niagara wine country.
movie_title: The Colossal Failure of the Modern Relationship (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Elliott may deserve the attention, but he also deserves a vehicle worthy of his talent -- and your ticket money.
A film about stasis risks becoming static itself, and somewhere between the careful framing and the deliberate pace, The Beguiled tips into turgidity, failing to turn intensity into urgency.
If Walter Hill and Jean-Luc Godard had a movie baby, it'd look just like Baby Driver -- but it wouldn't sound half as good.
Okja demonstrates that there is no subject Bong Joon-ho cannot make compelling, thrilling and moving.
Julian Rosefeldt's Manifesto offers many pleasures. Some of them are conceptual, some of them are surreal, and some of them are Cate Blanchett.
Not much happens in Babak Jalali's Radio Dreams, but that's all right. This is a comedy of gentle chaos; you just sort of coast along with it, smiling and occasionally chuckling.
When the focus is on citizens rather than institutions, the project produces something genuinely powerful.
movie_title: In the Name of All Canadians (2017)

movie_review_blurb: After a decade and a half and five feature films of wildly varying quality, here is a Spider-Man movie that shows the pure heart of its excitable young hero.
If Tickling Giants never digs as deep as it could, it's still a fascinating look at a culture just beginning to understand the power of sarcasm.
Cox has the tragedy of the man in his teeth. Would that it had been better served by the movie around it.
Their Finest is so skilfully constructed that you may not even notice it's a perfect replication of the genre it salutes.
The Devout opens strong and establishes some interesting stakes, and then all its dramatic tension drains away to nothing.
Had director/co-writer Robert Cuffley narrowed his focus a little, he'd have probably come out with a better film -- or at least one that feels more coherent.
It's not a good movie, exactly, and there are certainly better horror films around... But if you want to waste an hour and a half jumping at shadows, The Bye Bye Man will certainly do the job.
If you're into the weird stuff, you should definitely catch this one.
The material is culturally relevant and the mirror-image storytelling ingenious. But this would be little more than a thought experiment if the filmmaking weren't so immediate and compelling.

Hancock swallows Kroc's story whole, seeing it as an inspirational tale of gumption and determination, which makes Keaton's typically nuanced performance increasingly difficult to reconcile with the storytelling.
McAvoy and Taylor-Joy immediately establish an engaging, fluid chemistry - and Betty Buckley pops up in a subplot... And it's all expertly shot by It Follows cinematographer Mike Gioulakis.
There is exactly one funny idea -- a software virus that deletes all the porn on a hacker's computer -- but even that feels like it could have been written a decade ago. Hard pass.
It's 129 minutes long and feels twice that, draining the life out of actors as lively as Chris Messina, Chris Cooper, Brendan Gleeson, Elle Fanning and Zoe Saldana.
Told with simplicity, elegance and no dialogue whatsoever, it's an animated fable about loneliness and hope.
Respectful bordering on reverent, and disappointingly dull.
movie_title: The River of My Dreams: A Portrait of Gordon Pinsent (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hosseini and Alidoosti find the truth of every scene, and their performances keep The Salesman vital even as you sense the director pulling its strings.
There's a powerful movie to be made about the range of lives destroyed by the apartheid system -- both Black and white -- but Shepherds And Butchers isn't it.

The longer Rings plays, the more potential it abandons, introducing an elaborate new backstory for a character that simply doesn't need it and downshifting into a conventional psychological thriller in its final third.
Honestly? You could do a lot worse this winter, and you probably already have.

In addition to an ever-expanding lineup of guest stars, the movie builds a terrific running joke about the way New Yorkers will ignore literally anything that happens around them if it means getting to work on time.
Yes, it's fun to see McConaughey stride around as a wheeler-dealer who could be the less successful brother of his Wolf Of Wall Street philosopher king. But the movie around him doesn't measure up.

Leone is comfortable in front of the camera and has some intriguing things to say about the cultural treatment of sexuality in India, but you can feel Mehta straining to get Mostly Sunny to feature length.
Like Deepwater Horizon, it's better than I expected -- albeit nowhere near as good as it might have been.

Filmed over the course of five years, and letting people tell their own stories in their own words, The Stairs is a work with deep compassion for those who've made their way back from the depths of addiction.
Horror movies are all about tone, and Antibirth has one I'm not sure I've ever encountered before.

It's an impressionistic, experiential drama, situating us with its characters in bars and clubs and rooms and beds and letting us see how they are together as they find comfort and strength in each other's broken places.
John Walker looks at the history of Quebec's distinct society in a quietly personal documentary.

Shot in an appealingly undisguised Winnipeg, the romantic comedy Lovesick is a passable debut from Winnipeg writer/director Tyson Caron, even if it's utterly undistinguished in its story and its vision.
There's so much more to this movie than the storyline. Tampopo is a manic celebration of pleasure in every imaginable form, from the gustatory to the carnal.
Sadie's Last Days On Earth gets more things right than it misses. Its pessimistic comedy is layered with genuine feeling.
Miss Sloane has Jessica Chastain goosing it to life with a fascinating performance.
When you realize where it's all been heading -- ending on a moment that's as transcendent as anything in 40 years of the franchise -- you'll be so, so happy.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For a while, its sheer immensity-- and the chutzpah of its American Animal Idol conceit -- will keep you watching just to see how many plates director/writer Jennings can set to spinning.

Nicolas Pesce's feature debut takes a rural horror story and executes it in an intellectualized, austere fashion. You can appreciate exactly how well-made it is even as the dread piles on top of you like a blanket.
A graceful, deeply affecting work produced in an entirely original manner, it's one of the year's best films.
The most frustrating thing about Passengers is that it actually could have been better.
A dull, grey, ugly movie that takes two long hours to tell a very thin story.

Like most of Scorsese's oeuvre, Silence explores the link between physical suffering and spiritual conviction, but this time he seems willing to consider a darker question: not "What if it's all for nothing?" but "How will we know?"
Railroad Tigers is a tonal mess that never figures out a way to reconcile its serious subject matter with the wacky-fun-times vibe Chan and company are putting out. Much of the film just feels off.
It's much, much better than you might expect. And the ending packs a real emotional wallop, especially if you're coming to the movie without knowing very much about the story.
It's the Batman adventure live-action could never deliver, with bright colours and a warm heart. And also Daleks.
The only real question is whether the shorts themselves succeed, and more do than don't.
When I heard that Verbinski's latest project was a return to the horror genre, I was totally on board. And then I saw it.
The legend of Doug "The Thug" Glatt continues in Goon: Last Of The Enforcers -- though honestly, maybe it shouldn't have.
All I was left with was the desire to go home and spin up the original again.

It's ultimately Stone who walks away with the picture. Adding an impatient clarity to the old-soul watchfulness she displayed in Wet Bum, she slowly becomes Weirdos' moral centre. And it's something to see.

T2 is Boyle's Before Sunset, and for those of us in its generational sweet spot, watching it is like running into that friend you didn't think you liked any more and remembering why you hung out in the first place.
The Settlers is as comprehensive a look at the problem of Jewish settlements on Arab land as we're likely to get.
Wilson is so faithful to its source that it wrings all the humanity out of it.
There's something fascinating happening inside O, Brazen Age if you just lean in.
If you like this sort of thing, it's fine.

Remember the 21 Jump Street movie? That was a blast. The sequel was pretty great too. Chips wants to be a self-aware action comedy too, but Chips is not that. It's not much of anything at all, to be honest.
An effective, resourceful nightmare that convinces you the apocalypse is clawing just out of sight, beyond the edge of the screen.
If you're familiar with the original Ghost In The Shell, either as manga or anime form, I don't think this will work for you. The source material haunts it like an unquiet spirit.
The Zookeeper's Wife is a little too delicate, and that includes the way it handles what happens to some of the animals -- tastefully and just off-camera.

The music-industry backdrop makes Song To Song feel less isolated and self-absorbed, especially when the characters interact with actual musicians... But there's still a lot of spinning and twirling to get through.

Fans of Lynch will enjoy the sense of drifting through the reveries of a man who's spent his entire life drinking coffee, smoking cigarettes and actively reinterpreting the world through his very specific gaze.
Gifted exists to do a thing, and it does it pretty well. There are no surprises, but the audience I saw it with didn't mind. Neither did I, to be honest. As comfort food goes, it's just fine.
It's nuts, and deliriously so. See it with a crowd.
I'm really glad Soderbergh's back doing what he does best. I didn't know how much I missed the guy.
It's a rich, thoughtful character study that stands with its author's finest work.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a movie that feels refreshingly unpredictable even as it works within the standard franchise parameters -- much like Gareth Edwards's Godzilla, to which it's tied only glancingly, it finds its own tone and never wavers.
The larger portrait of Istanbul as a city whose residents almost unconsciously look out for even the littlest among them is heartening in an era defined by increasing isolationism and scapegoating.
For a movie in which anything can explode at any moment, Land Of Mine is awfully predictable.
Seeing Rathbun's psychic scars emerge is far more compelling than any talking head could ever be.

Every cast member gets at least one big laugh -- Nanjiani's is so weirdly great they repeat it a handful of times in the closing bloopers -- and the whole thing is over before it has a chance to get old.
Comedy nerds will enjoy the stories and be fascinated by the vulnerability of these unflappable performers.

Peele leavens the message with occasional (and much-needed) explosions of unexpected comedy, but have no illusions: he's dead serious about the story he's telling. The result is a remarkable genre work that stands with the best of them.
There's a difference between ambiguity and frustration, and Dark Night falls on the wrong side.
It's wonderful to watch the older performers mentor their younger collaborators, and it's exhilarating to see stage fright turn into electric confidence in a split second as the kids take the stage.
Jackman, who's always been remarkably human in this superhuman role, is as good as he's ever been at finding the beating heart underneath all that adamantium. I will miss the hell out of him.
I've said it before, and sadly Bitter Harvest gives me cause to say it again: the only thing worse than a terrible movie is a terrible movie that thinks it's good for you.
Deutch's textured performance still sells Sam's emotional arc, and younger moviegoers will find a lot to mull over in the narrative's key questions.
Table 19 is an ensemble comedy with a lot of good ideas that never pay off.

Saigon Bodyguards is very silly, but I can't say I didn't enjoy watching its two pals, straight-arrow Trinh and doofus Vien, knock around the eponymous city in search of the corporate heir who was kidnapped right from under their noses.
Take my advice and don't wait for Window Horses to show up on iTunes; see it as soon as you can. Take friends. Share the poetry.
Writer/director Funk's first feature after a series of solid shorts -- including 2013's Destroyer, which contained the seeds of this film -- is a strong debut, if a little heavy-handed.
God Knows Where I Am is a gentle, elegiac work, with great compassion for its subject.
This is an involving process documentary that's also a deeply satisfying story of kindness -- which suits the holiday season nicely.
Pattinson's performance is indeed flawless, and the breathless thriller built around it is pretty fantastic too.
What can I say? The world is awful right now. I was really glad to see this movie. We kinda need it.
I liked Dina, the person, just fine. But I have real issues with the movie that bears her name.

Look, at this point you know what you're getting. It's a DC movie; it's loud and frenetic when it doesn't need to be, overstuffed with peripheral characters who don't matter and action sequences that barely register.

Yes, it's deeply pleasurable to watch Nye school conservative blowhards who make their living promoting lies, but I wanted Alvarado and Sussberg to explore their subject as thoroughly as he explores the world around him.
They're fine actors doing good work, but their stories don't amount to much. Mudbound's real drama lies elsewhere, in a relationship that doesn't even begin until the final movement.
Based on the manga by Hiroaki Samura, it's a spectacular, energetic and almost exhausting samurai actioner that splatters itself across the screen with Miike's signature enthusiasm.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Joshua James Richards's camera also regards human coupling and animal husbandry with the same blunt honesty: it's beautiful, but it's awfully messy. You could say the same thing about love.

Whether you think you're watching a genius discuss his greatest performance or an obnoxious actor indulging in and subsequently justifying his most pretentious, selfish instincts...either way, it's fascinating.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a pleasure to watch these actors just sit and be together, but I'd be overly generous if I said it was especially memorable or even dramatic. We're left with an interesting experiment, but not much of a movie.

Dagg just lets it all breathe, building tension as people kill time in diners and motel rooms, hinting that something terrible is coming but not telling us how or when. That's exactly what this material needs.
The movie's compelling, what-the-hell mood drains away into a series of disappointed shrugs with the occasional disbelieving snort.
Jordan Canning's sophomore feature is modest, beautifully acted and full of surprising laughs

I could write another thousand words about why I love Dim The Fluorescents, but it's the kind of thing you need to see for yourself - a singular, fully engaged cinematic work and a cockeyed delight. Just go.
Joe Wright slathers this biopic with self-conscious artistry, but Gary Oldman is terrific as Churchill.
The movie's so enthralling that you won't even notice the emotional currents building steadily and powerfully underneath - until it wallops you with them, of course.
Please don't give this movie your money.
Sure, it's overly long, but it also features eccentric timing, shaggy humour and some hilarious new characters
Look, if you enjoyed the previous installments, you'll like this one too; it's designed to be precisely the same experience. This is not an endorsement.
The actors hit their marks and say their lines; the movie looks polished and professional. And it's completely empty, unable to interrogate its subject in any way that matters.

Supposedly based on actual events, Verónica likely owes more to [Paco] Plaza wearing out his videotapes of A Nightmare On Elm Street, Prince Of Darkness and Witchboard as a kid. Turns out imitation really is the sincerest form of flattery.
A film about the creation of a beloved children's icon shouldn't have to try this hard to make its audience feel something. And the ending is utter bollocks.
The struggle to reconcile the star-is-born theatre arc with the meat of Kildare's investigation pushed me out of the movie entirely.
If the scenarios in which Baumbach places his actors are a little on the creaky side, the performances are exceptional.
[78/52] is a fully considered investigation of a landmark moment in movie history.
[Happy Death day] is fun and energetic, and god knows you could do worse for a Halloween distraction.

Frederick Wiseman's new documentary Ex Libris - unofficially subtitled New York Public Library - is probably half an hour longer than it needs to be, but at this point Wiseman can take as much time as he wants.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beyond its value as a documentary, it's a statement of principle.
It's underdeveloped, missing vital connective tissue, not quite strong enough to live on its own.
Seth M. Sherwood's script totally misses the point that keeps the original Massacre so bloody effective.
It looks good, it features a lot of committed actors, and it's completely hollow.

If California Typewriter slightly overstays its welcome, as Nichol pushes past a natural end point to make the case for manual typewriters as the new vinyl... well, that seems somehow appropriate, too. Love has a way of blinding us to reality, after all.
There's a layer of feeling running through the picture that builds as the narrative unfolds, and when everything falls into place it's almost overwhelming.

It's awfully hard to take an exorcism seriously when it's being performed over the phone... but if it works, does that speak to the power of faith or the power of suggestion? And aren't they the same thing?
This is the first Star Wars movie made by an artist instead of a craftsman, and it leaves us on the verge of something new. I'm very, very excited to see what that might be.
Lynch - the actor-turned-director, not the director-turned-actor - sets up his shots and lets the characters talk, watching, waiting for a revelation. Damn it if he doesn't find one
The midsection of Downsizing is something quite wonderful...But once Payne and co-writer Jim Taylor have established their characters, Downsizing hits a speed bump.

Van Soest and Levine were in production when Ferguson exploded over the police shooting of Michael Brown, and they're smart enough to keep those events in the background as a running reminder of what can happen to Black youth in the St. Louis area.
Opening with moments of shocking violence but quickly sliding into absurdist whimsy, this is a weird one even for Kiyoshi Kurosawa. But it has its moments.

Annihilation is about four-fifths of a tremendous science-fiction movie: it starts well, creates a compelling alternate reality, builds a fascinating narrative and then just sort of walks into a wall.
It's not a pleasant ride, and if you've been party to an ugly divorce, it'll definitely set some uncomfortable memories rattling loose. But it's a gripping drama and a devastating character study.
Levithan's novel translates nicely to the screen, its fantastical elements grounded by a stellar lead performance from Rice.

Darren Curtis's Boost doesn't break any new ground, but then I don't think it's trying to...Curtis freshens up the familiar premise with interesting locations, distinctive characterizations and genuine stakes. And it moves like a shot.

It captures the terror of rugs being pulled out from underneath literally everyone. Fortunately, Potter wants us to laugh at that moment of free-fall instead of choking on the panic of a world going mad.

It's a pleasant enough waste of time, and you can enjoy watching the radically different ways in which performers like Nick Swardson, Nicole Schreiber and Nikki Glaser structure and deliver what's essentially the same anecdote.
A multi-character study of grief and loss as represented through the things people leave behind, it's a heartfelt work from Pellington.
As unnecessary remakes go, this one has a strange pull. Willis is giving a genuine performance in the middle of all the carnage, building fine moments opposite Vincent D'Onofrio.
Shin's feature-length follow-up builds itself around the short, incorporating its material and expanding on it...This story is strong enough to work on its own.
It's a soothing portrait of people pursuing the ineffable, gliding along with the elderly Thich and his disciples.

Every line reads as if it were still on the page; every characterization is one-dimensional and unbending. At 90 minutes, the stilted dialogue might feel like a deliberate, stylized choice; at nearly two hours, it's infuriating.
Not every movie needs to be an instant classic. Sometimes all you need is a pleasant diversion. Hopefully we won't have to wait another decade for Edgerton's third feature.
It works, but it's cold. All the while I was watching Thoroughbreds, I felt removed from it.
It's exhaustingly serious...while the script means to be enigmatic about Dominika's allegiances, there's really no question about who's doing what, or why.
It's not a classic, but it's proper fun.
The law of diminishing returns is stalking the movie, too. With each new revelation, The Ritual reveals just how derivative it really is, and the final movement is too dopey to be scary.
They might have fared better with a filmmaker who actually works with his actors to shape performance and character, something Eastwood has been proudly uninterested in doing for more than a decade.
There are a couple of really solid laughs, and Kasdan finds a way to soften the most sadistic aspects of the concept that hung over Johnston's original.
Pitch Perfect 3 is a satisfying farewell to a franchise that pretty much said everything it needed to say the first time out.
Oh, Lin Shaye. These movies don't deserve you.

There's a warmth and a joy running through the Paddington films that overwhelms in the best possible way, without ever tipping into syrupy manipulation. Maybe that's just the difference between treacle and marmalade.
Although it wants to be a modern-day reworking of the Michael Mann crime classic, this picture fizzles out.

12 Strong is the true story of the first American soldiers who went into Afghanistan following 9/11, and it is the least interesting version of that story imaginable: a monochromatic experience of beige men running through grey terrain.
You have to be a really talented storyteller to pull this off, and Hollow In The Land suggests that Corkle has a ways to go on that account.
There's a fascinating thesis tucked into Midnight Return: The Story Of Billy Hayes And Turkey, and it's only partially about the idea contained in the title of Sally Sussman's uneven documentary.
movie_title: Midnight Return: The Story of Billy Hayes and Turkey (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Conceived without a thought to pacing or tension, and shot on location in what is very clearly the Australian countryside, it's an empty, seemingly endless slog through all the usual clichés of this genre.
Here, we're trapped with experts shouting technobabble at each other for much of the action...and it's just not as compelling.
It's so intent on surprising us that it runs straight into a conceptual brick wall.
Permission offers a novel spin on its romantic-comedy premise, exploring the idea that people can do stupid things with the best intentions.

So many horror movies start out with a nifty premise only to back themselves into a conceptual corner, but Grant and Kovac figure out a way to pay off their conceit, and leave us wondering how they did it.

Spettacolo may not have the structural ingenuity of the filmmakers' previous work, but as a contemplation of identity and the value and comfort people find in telling their own stories, it makes for an engaging, entirely absorbing experience.

Black Panther is to the ongoing Marvel project as Coogler's Creed was to the Rocky movies - a film simultaneously beholden to its franchise and alive to every possibility within it, creating a new world within the existing master narrative.
For a first feature, it's fine - but it's never anything more.
It's a tour de force performance, played in a minor key.
This might be heresy, but I'll argue Villeneuve's sequel is a deeper and more engaging work than its progenitor, less concerned with action beats than with ideas, themes and character.
... instead of a lecture, the film focuses on the people doing the science, mindful of the unexpected collisions that result when geniuses bounce off one another.

Slow and steady, neither narrative nor essay, this is exactly the kind of project that Wavelengths was created to spotlight. Is it entertainment? Not really. But I can't say I didn't appreciate the experience.
There's not much substance beyond that, but it's sweet to watch [director Gustavo] Salmerón prod his parents for more stories while his brothers and sisters flutter around in the background.
movie_title: Lots of Kids, a Monkey and a Castle (Muchos hijos, un mono y un castillo) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director McGlynn's first featureh takes a slightly familiar premise and invests it with spiky energy, richly drawn characters and a streak of caustic humour.
There are a few moments that land, but too many more that don't...
Go in cold, knowing as little as possible, and let one of the greatest movies of the year explode before your unbelieving eyes.
[Karim] Sayad builds a central metaphor of Algerians being treated like sheep by their apathetic government, but he doesn't force it. He just lets us find our way to it between bouts.
... Gutland offers standard pulp fare set firmly on simmer, building to a twist that gets points for audacity but makes almost no sense a moment later.
Pyewacket maintains an uneasy tension rooted in believable human frailty.
While the story's ultimately pretty familiar, the religious angle adds some intriguing complications to the usual tropes.
There's just nothing new here, and nothing especially interesting.
The Crescent falls into a rut, drifting through long, languid sequences of vague menace and dicey dramatic choices.
It's a small picture with modest ambitions, but that doesn't have to be a bad thing.
[Professor Marston] pays off in a genuinely moving story with great performances from all three leads.
The China Hustle goes from methodical to hysterical, shouting down its own arguments.
This film functions as both cinema and journalism, the camera pushing us into a world we might not otherwise see and illuminating that world on a human scale.
What first seems like a gimmicky no-budget project turns out to be an ingenious way to explore the issues of sex, race and gender that run deep in the South African character.
Cole and El Arabi are appealing, engaging leads, and the premise, with its nods to every surveillance thriller ever made, is dramatic enough to pull us over the rougher spots.
Whether or not you actually like The Room is irrelevant; The Disaster Artist is its own giddy thing, and you don't have to force yourself to laugh.

To experience the whole thing in sequence is to watch two very long hours of prefabricated, ultimately predictable drama that lacks the texture of Walls's writing or the power of her hard-won insight.
Pavan Moondi mines hilarious comedy from this tale of doofuses in oddball situations.
[Bushwick] is a real-time thriller that plays out in a series of extended takes.
The Only Living Boy In New York, is a pretentious, affected, thoroughly obnoxious drama about a directionless young man who starts sleeping with his dad's mistress.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I like almost everyone in The Space Between, and I wanted to like the movie, too. It wouldn't let me.
[George] Nolfi's made a movie that tells rather than shows - and much of what's being told is stiff and clichéd, and not in a self-aware way that might have been fun.
For all its wonder, spectacle and suspense, Steven Spielberg's sci-fi classic is a movie about a smile that changes the course of human history. And there's something wonderful about that.
movie_title: Close Encounters Of The Third Kind: 40th Anniversary Release (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A wildly overqualified cast does their best, but they can't do anything with this dumb, uninteresting thriller.
You want [Tulip Fever] to be either hopelessly bad or a secret masterpiece, and all you get is generic all-star period piffle shot all too obviously on a London soundstage.

The latest allegorical drama from Lebanese auteur Doueiri (West Beirut, The Attack) draws on the history of the Middle East and long-standing tensions between Palestinians and Lebanese Christians. But even without that subtext, the film would still play.
Casting non-actors as versions of themselves - [Brady] Jandreau acts opposite his real father and sister - [Chloé] Zhao situates the story in a fully lived-in world.

Ronnie Sandahl's script is frustratingly simplistic, quickly establishing that the only real difference between Borg and McEnroe was that McEnroe had yet to learn to control the single-mindedness that made him a great player.

Pastiche filmmakers Cattet and Forzani (Amer, The Strange Color Of Your Body's Tears) take a deep dive into the ultra-violent Italian crime pictures of the 60s and 70s for this sweaty, sun-drenched shootout.
movie_title: Let the Corpses Tan (Laissez bronzer les cadavres!) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the film is just a flat imitation of Blood Simple, following along as a noose slowly tightens around the necks of the inept lovers-slash-murderers at its centre.
All about will and the focusing of it beyond all reason, it's both fascinating and revolting to watch these people punish themselves in the name of perfection.
movie_title: A Skin So Soft (Ta peau si lisse) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Shape Of Water reaches out, hoping you'll reach back. Just take care not to cut yourself on its claws.
It just doesn't gel, and it badly needs to.
A nervy, queasy combination of jet-black satire and stylized psychodrama.
It's very expensive and very busy, and it's utterly forgettable.
... the film does have its moments. But there's no doubt in my mind that the story would be better served at miniseries length.
... a religious parable so delicate and placid that it practically lulls you to sleep.
It's all very serious, and very flat.
No one sets out to make a movie this bad. But here we are, and here it is.

At times animalistic, at times tender and ethereal, [Marine Johnson is] whatever the role requires - a character trying to understand herself and the world around her with severely limited knowledge and resources.
movie_title: The Little Girl Who Was Too Fond of Matches (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers are specialists in non-threatening arthouse cinema, and this one is as non-threatening as it gets.
movie_title: C'est la vie (Le sens de la fête) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's a better movie rattling around somewhere that never fully forms.
Dark River moves inexorably towards that catharsis, pulling us along in its undertow.
Alternately lively and thoughtful, Lady Bird is the work of someone looking back critically on a frantic period in her own life.
In an era of peak zombie, it's rare to find a variation on horror's current favourite sub-genre that feels fresh and intriguing.

Kingsman: The Golden Circle finds director Matthew Vaughn and his co-writer Jane Goldman replicating and amplifying all of the things that worked about their 2015 spy spoof - and all of the things that didn't.
Set over a suffocating Brooklyn summer, Beach Rats takes an evocative, charged look at a closeted 19-year-old adrift in his own life.
Doug Liman knows something very important about Tom Cruise: the actor is never more interesting than when he's desperate and unlikeable.
It's a fun experiment in multi-character storytelling, and the world can always use more of those.

By letting us reach our own conclusions about the meanings of various interactions between people and beasts, the film creates space for a contemplation of animal consciousness and human responsibility.
Its queasy mood evaporates as soon as the house lights come up.
[In This Corner] carries a disquieting streak of immediacy.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Screenwriter Sean Drummond takes his time setting everything up - seriously, that opening prologue could have been half as long - but once all the pieces are in place, the film goes hard and doesn't let up. Nicely done.
It's paradoxical, I know, but the more Trier reveals, the less interesting his movie becomes.
It's a fertile premise, but the film somehow underperforms.
If you've ever wondered what Wim Wenders would do with a Bond movie, here's your answer: not much.
Keep your eye on Sam Rockwell as Harrelson's nastiest deputy. You'll think you've seen him do this before, but trust me: he's a goddamn revelation.
This is the arrival of a major talent, and a hell of a movie.
This is a life study in which you watch to see whether these people can find their way in the world. You root for them. You care.

Manhunt is a movie for the die-hard fans who've stuck it out with Woo over the last decade or so. If you're amped up for another all-out bullet ballet, it'll go down just fine. The rest of us, though, can expect to wince as often as we cheer.

Grace Park and Andrea Bang steal every one of their scenes as a mother-child pairing even odder than Greer and Doheny, and Andrew McNee is a stealthy delight as Liam's officious, easily distracted principal.
[Jason] Sanchez's script telegraphs every plot development and makes a crucial error in perspective by focusing on [Evan Rachel] Wood's Laura instead of [Julia Sarah] Stone's Eva.
As perfectly conducted as the orchestra performances that open and close the film, The Death Of Stalin zips along merrily as alliances are formed, plots are hatched and lives are destroyed.

The compression required to fit a year as convulsive as 2016 into a 90-minute feature means we never stay on one point for very long, and that the election of Donald Trump in November just gets dropped into the narrative like a third-act twist.
It is deeply sad and positively triumphant. It's everything we need it to be.
[Egle] Mikulionyte and [Vyto] Ruginis are fun together, and [Egle] Vertelyte convincingly re-creates the post-Soviet world in which they're both ultimately trapped.

Having established her premise and characters, writer/director [Lisa] Langseth does absolutely nothing with them, letting Euphoria drift through one scene after another without ever gaining dramatic momentum or emotional weight.
Jake Gyllenhaal's performance is emotionally raw and technically seamless.
[Peter Schønau] Fog is so busy considering the story's philosophical underpinnings that he forgets to render that story in a compelling or urgent manner
The Other Side Of Hope is just as warm and thoughtful as the rest of [Aki] Kaurismäki's body of work, and you might just feel a stab of regret that this story still needs telling.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: She's a terrific subject, and Zevgetis has crafted a film that is, much like Michelle herself, a lot more complex than it might initially seem.
As minimalist horror movies go, this is pretty effective.

It plays like a remake of Crank by someone who didn't realize Crank was a comedy already.

There's no reason this should run almost two hours.

Wow. It's worse than I'd feared.

movie_review_blurb: It's ultimately too slight to stand out in its chosen sub-genre, but Carter's performance as a woman slowly reduced to one raw nerve will keep you watching all the way through to the end.
Structured with a deceptively casual hand, it's charming and smartly observed throughout, and the ensemble cast vanish into their period roles.

Apichatpong's latest venture into low-key magic realism is pleasurable but familiar.
Eddie looks like a cockeyed genius who just had to believe in himself. By the end of the movie, everyone else believes in him, too. So did I. Nice one.
One woman attributes her longevity to never having eaten a vegetable in her life, insisting everyone else eats too many. Bless.
Mostly Reynolds is really funny, joyfully debasing himself and putting everything he has into making this the giddiest, most enjoyable Deadpool movie imaginable.
It isn't even a horror movie, really. I think it's something entirely new -- a kinked romantic comedy with a creepy, queasy edge we've never seen before. Happy Valentine's Day.

Ting and cinematographer Josh Silfen treat their location as a charming, sparkly bubble bustling with romantic potential, and it's great that Chung gets to embody a fully realized character on screen.
Movies like Hail, Caesar! are the reason I will follow Joel and Ethan Coen anywhere.
Writer/director Grímur Hákonarson starts his movie as an observational absurdist comedy but develops it into something far richer.
An evocative journey through a changing world in search of a culture that's disappearing before the travellers' eyes.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a complex, nuanced and surprisingly affecting documentary that's bound to be denounced as propaganda by people who haven't watched it.
Hillcoat's women are, once again, left largely on the sidelines. Only Kate Winslet makes an impression as the matriarch of a Russian Jewish crime family -- and that's because she's badly miscast.

Stephen Hopkins's Race is the sort of biopic that gives the genre a bad name.
Cernan's an engaging subject, and he's got a great story to tell.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Zootopia is a lot of things at once, and all of them are pretty good.
London Has Fallen is as dopey as its predecessor, Olympus Has Fallen. But it's dopey in an entirely different way.
The cast is engaging, and the makeup effects are convincingly squicky. It's a little disappointing that the last act downshifts into a predictable cat-and-mouse chase.
The directorial debut of actor Robert Carlyle, The Legend Of Barney Thomson is a fitfully enjoyable comedy.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's greatest asset is its cast: Chernick and King are very well matched in the leads, and Pollak and Emily Hampshire deliver solid support.

movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Race showed us Stephan James could be a movie star. Across The Line mints him as an actor.
It's an awkward sex comedy with a surprisingly warm heart and some very deep laughs.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Brazilian filmmaker Gabriel Mascaro's Neon Bull finds grim economic commentary in the lives of a handful of people who work in a rodeo, tending bulls that are roped by flashy riders in the ring.

Hiddleston is distressingly effective as a doctor who was already a little unbalanced before his neighbours go all Lord Of The Flies. And as an alpha-male resident, Luke Evans barrels straight over the top and never looks back.
The material cries out for a more disinterested eye.
Whatever it is, it's an experience unlikely ever to be replicated. And maybe that's for the best, but at least we can finally see it on a big screen.
The result is the finest deadpan slapstick grotesquerie.
In a world that already has The Big Short, Money Monster just feels increasingly unnecessary.
Shane Black is back doing the thing he does better than anyone else, writing and directing deliriously entertaining action comedies about mismatched partners battling an escalating threat.

This may be the most gifted cast yet assembled for a superhero movie, and it's enjoyable to simply watch them play pretend together... [However,] Apocalypse too often feels like a reworking of familiar elements.
Every line reading feels like a contractual obligation.
Deftly staged, briskly paced and very funny, thanks largely to Beckinsale's crack timing and Tom Bennett's breakout performance.
I didn't mind spending time with these characters, even when their movie seemed on the verge of shaking itself apart.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hevn [is] a Norwegian/Canadian thriller that's designed like an airplane novel. That's not a slight; the entire movie is packaged for easy digestion and surface appeal.
Who these men are and why they're alone together are left unexplained, which is the smartest thing director Athina Rachel Tsangari and co-writer Efthymis Filippou could have done.
In its quieter moments, Almost Holy allows us to wonder whether the end really does justify the means.

Kill Zone 2 is about half an hour too long, with a plot so convoluted it should come with a flow chart. But none of that matters, because once people start jumping across rooms to murder each other, it's so much damn fun.

Agyness Deyn makes a striking lead as Chris Guthrie, who struggles to escape the shadow of her ferociously religious father and define herself as her own woman, even as she's drawn toward a young man from the village.
When Litz puts us alone in that forest with Sweetpea and her fears, The People Garden has a dark, compelling pull.
While cartoon panthers, bears and orangutans singing, dancing and fighting is the stuff of pure joy, watching lifelike animals do the same thing isn't nearly as pleasurable.

The first and third acts are efficient extended chases, but there's an hour in the middle that's just Costner wandering around London grimacing and bleeding from various wounds. Or at least it felt that way.
To quote the man himself, so what?
The new sci-fi thriller Prisoner X has not learned the lessons of Primer, and that's a shame, because it's treading similar ground. It has a good idea, but no idea how to execute it.

A few moments work very nicely, and Taylor and Scrofano have a zippy chemistry that makes it a pleasure just to watch them sit and talk together. But Sabbagh's script runs out of ideas about an hour in.
In its second half, though, Tykwer and Hanks find a tone that works for both of them, and A Hologram For The King becomes an involving, intriguing drama.
t's fine, and Hockney is an engaging screen presence. But it could have been much more than that.
Larry Weinstein's tribute to the saxophone doesn't know when to stop wailing, but there's enough fascinating material here to appeal to the ordinary viewer, not just woodwind aficionados.

If Sing Street confirms that Carney, who made his name as the writer/director of Once and Begin Again, has only one trick as a filmmaker -- the infectious rapture of musical collaboration -- well, it's a pretty great trick.
Genre fans will appreciate the craft and intelligence with which Saulnier's assembled his movie -- when they're not digging their nails into their thighs.
Viva is competently produced and acted, but I've seen this movie a dozen times before. And so have you.
The longer Too Late goes on, the less there is to it.
It's ridiculous, but in a really engaging way.
The film's real conflict is idealism versus realism... The actualization of that conflict gives the Russo brothers an anchor around which to stage half a dozen top-flight superhero battles.
Disorder is a psychological thriller that plays its story straight from beat to beat, making its ambiguities even more unsettling.
I kept watching to see what McCarthy was going to do next, and I usually enjoyed whatever it was. In a movie like this, that's really all that matters.
4th Man Out's good-naturedness is sadly incapable of overcoming its essential blandness.
Rather against all odds, Pride And Prejudice And Zombies is a great deal of fun.
The premise may be dopey and the budget minimal, but it's all handled in such a winning and cheerful way that resistance is futile.
If a documentary is only as good as its subject, then Marinoni: The Fire In The Frame is golden.
movie_title: Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sean Penn horns in on Liam Neeson's territory in The Gunman, an efficient if undistinguished revenge thriller about a former mercenary turned humanitarian worker forced to race through Africa and Europe when his past acts come back to haunt him.
It ignores the basic requirements of cinema - narrative, tension, emotion - to pile on more scenes of attractive, fit people doing dynamic, envelope-pushing things.
It's quiet, considered and spellbinding, with a great deal of beautiful music - some of it performed exquisitely by Bernstein himself.

Plot-wise, Insurgent doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but that tracks back to Veronica Roth's books, which build an entire world around a fundamentally silly premise and just hope the reader won't notice.
For a movie that has no reason to exist, Disney's Cinderella is pleasant enough.
It's an awfully effective formula. If you're not disgusted by the institutional apathy revealed in The Hunting Ground, you may actually be a sociopath.
I enjoyed watching them work, even as I knew it wouldn't amount to much.
The Cobbler is startlingly thin and naive, especially in regard to the larger implications of its hero's actions.

I could have done with less of Sonny's comical wittering and more of grand dames Smith and Dench sitting around sipping drinks in the sun, but honestly? The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel wasn't made to please me.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The script gets less adventurous as it goes along, slowly shedding every intriguing idea and character detail for an utterly conventional final act.
Worst of all, though, is its wholesale waste of an insanely talented cast - and not just Evans and Monaghan... I enjoy every last one of them, but not like this. Dear god, not like this.

Farrell and Morton are solid, but Chastain's sensational - and Ullmann is canny enough to simply let her rip.

Given how richly his countryman Terence Davies has realized post-war England in movies like Distant Voices, Still Lives and The Deep Blue Sea, the cartoonishness of Queen And Country grates even further.
This is a movie that really wants you to think about some ugly realities, but it doesn't have the balls to make its bad guy genuinely bad.

After the more experimental Frances Ha, Noah Baumbach's While We're Young finds the writer/director synthesizing his earlier observational comedies with his later, crueller character studies of self-destructive intellectuals.
88 runs for 88 minutes, but it really shouldn't. There's barely an hour of plot, revisited again and again in flash-cut montages designed to add an intensity the story itself can't muster.
Being Canadian is more of a pandering stunt than a proper documentary, filled with easy jokes and semi-comical historical observations, but not much in the way of actual insight.
It's a story we've seen a few dozen times before, but first-time director Katz tells it with a nice focus on character.

Lambert played an essential role in encouraging Pete Townshend's songwriting, which is an important tidbit, but most of the info here won't be new to Who fans. That early footage, on the other hand, is documentary gold.
Think of all the great documentaries you've seen about rock and roll. Now imagine a boring one. That, unfortunately, is Can't Stand Losing You: -Surviving The Police.

It all descends into blood and fire as Gosling sifts through his Blu-ray collection to share the images and moods he loves. Does it work as a movie? Nah, not really. But as cinematic mix tapes go, it's kind of cool.
The characters are so weirdly specific and the actors who play them so invested that it kind of works in spite of itself. I have no idea whether anyone else will enjoy it, but I did.
The animal antics, shot primarily in Sri Lanka, are splendidly photographed and frequently charming, but it's hard not to notice how desperately the movie tries to anthropomorphize the characters.
Despite that fact that Pinto is such a vital performer, her character's backstory is handled so clumsily that it feels like one more cliché thrown onto the pile.

The Salt Of The Earth is a fairly conventional biography made somewhat more intimate by a wealth of stills and home-movie footage. But that formal simplicity is merely a way of ensuring its points land clearly and without interference.
Cut Bank is ersatz in almost every way, a parade of dumb people doing foolish things while other, dumber people plod along behind them slowly putting things together.
Jeunet never finds a matching aesthetic, shooting in an over-saturated 3D palette and doubling down on forced Americana, although most of the film was shot in BC and Alberta. It just doesn't work.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Bergland's a strong lead, though, and in Lexie's cranky-caring scenes with best friend Susie (Susan Kent) we can glimpse the much more engaging, and considerably funnier, movie that might have been.
It's crushingly dull and an utter waste of talent.
Sparkes invests the proceedings with a strong sense of place and mood, hinting at Jude's unstable psyche by giving us flashes of the trolls and witches he believes lurk in the woods around his home.

There is a tradition of observational documentaries that present events and images without offering context or insight, but Monsoon doesn't even do that. There's no curiosity, not even a pretense of investigation. It's just tourism.
It's an hour and a half of bros partying heartily and insulting each other while checking out the hot racks on hot ladies, with a few time-travel jokes thrown in.
It occasionally plays like a mashup of Mean Girls and Easy A, but Whitman's performance gives The DUFF a spiky energy all its own.

If you just want to see Bergman mugging for her own camera or clowning around with legendary collaborators like Alfred Hitchcock and Ingmar Bergman, this movie has that.

movie_review_blurb: After about half an hour, I found myself thinking how much nicer it would be to go for a decent walk myself, which isn't really the reaction this sort of movie is supposed to elicit.

movie_review_blurb: I respect the hell out of Behn's work, but this documentary misses the mark.

The characters in "Pride" may exist in a frothy cinematic contraption, but all is not sunshine and roses.
Personally, if I were you, I'd bypass it for a double feature of "Cherry 2000" and "Runaway."

The camera roams the way the human eye would, yet it knows the power of stillness, of letting the image linger and rest. These documentarians masterfully construct their vision to elevate and serve their subject.
...I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story is a profoundly moving documentary.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Privilege is also a crime in Cat from Hell, which once again pits the rich against a supernatural force for whom money holds no currency.
movie_title: Tales from the Darkside: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Here's a movie that would benefit from being broken up by late-night television commercials.
This is an immensely entertaining movie, and if the filmmakers are wise, they'll quit on this high note.
It has a beautiful, low-key approach that earns its cheers and tears without resorting to the manipulative or dramatic tricks of a typical feature film.
Clark clearly has a visual eye, and some of the compositions in his films are breathtaking, but unless his predilections float your boat, his movies are endurance tests.
It's like a thesis whose next draft would be destined for greatness.
Miller is such a character that Drenner takes the advice offered him by many of the filmmakers he interviews: He just turns on the camera and lets Miller work his magic.
O'Connell continues to bring equal measures of toughness and vulnerability to his characters. Despite his good looks, there's an everyman's quality to him, which he uses to full effect in "'71."
Hot Tub Time Machine 2 commits the two biggest sins of the dudebro comedy genre legitimized by the success of The Hangover series. The first is that this sequel exists at all.
This film's tagline should be "Come for the stabbing, stay for the gabbing!"
"The Woman in Black 2" might have served as an effective tribute to movies like "Curse of the Cat People." That is, if it hadn't completely squandered all this goodwill in its last third.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Gambler" should have been called "Three Supporting Characters in Search of a Lead."
Its timeliness is a spine-chilling reminder that those who do not know their history are doomed to repeat it. Its story provides a blueprint not only of the past, but of the way forward.
A substandard "crime drama" that reeks of the Idiot Plot Syndrome.

It strikes a risky, though successful balancing act between being immensely entertaining as a musical feature and making dramatic, important statements about depression, self-worth and female empowerment.
This movie is so tone-deaf that it tries to wring charm from questionable stereotypes about senior citizens and minorities.
I cop to not being a fan of Lynn Shelton's work. Her films fall apart in their third acts.
In the current economy, Monopoly makes a more appropriate board game upon which to base a horror movie, but for what it is, "Ouija" is better than expected.
This is one of Mortensen's best performances, and "The Two Faces of January" is one gorgeously rendered old-school feature.
Without fail, every time I found myself liking this movie, it would break the spell with its ulterior motives.
As a documented record of Hill's story and her achievements, "Anita" is a serviceable, at times riveting documentary.
This may be the Muppets' best onscreen appearance since Kermit strummed his banjo back in 1979.
"Riddick" is better than I expected, and it does provide a decent amount of fun for fans of the genre.
I Declare War plays like a C-student's final exam essay on Lord of the Flies. Any interest in the game is overridden by the massive amounts of allegory lifted straight from Golding's novel.
This looks like a string of screen tests and home movie outtakes of the actors getting hammered on set. It's "Grown Ups 2" for the art house crowd.
Let me list the things Izzy does to Sam, and ask if you'd stick around.

"In A World..." is too good a film to merely focus on ... one plot element, or to present its male characters as one-note villains. These are complex people, funny one moment and infuriating the next.
Cliché is not a bad thing if it's done right. Like a good jazz improvisation, "2 Guns" leads to the same place but not the way you may expect.
Director Nemad Cicin-Sain and co-writer Richard N. Gladstein are both guilty of serving up a totally empty, tonally confused meditation on the creative process.
People are pumped with more bullets than those at the beginning of "Saving Private Ryan"; since they don't bleed, the MPAA considers this "family-friendly," hilariously calling it "frenetic gunplay."
It's a relentless assault on a man who wished to be left alone.
Midnight Run is one of 1988's best movies. It's exciting, funny, and full of fine actors who pull off the tricky machinations of the script.
Kevin Hart is indeed a talented comedian. This is just not his best material.
"Despicable Me 2" lags on occasion, but every time I found my attention waning, the filmmakers did something wicked to goose me.
"This is the End" finds a balanced tone most horror comedies fail to deliver. Grossout humor melds easily with grossout horror, sometimes at the same moment.
My response of "won't that sting?!" would have resulted in Anna hanging up on me, too, but I digress.
I had to wait until halfway through the closing credits for my first, and only, laugh.
Chism's cast is game for her shenanigans, and the biggest pleasure of "Peeples" is watching them cut loose under her direction.
I confess to being a sucker for sports movies, the ones with the "Big Game" at the end. "The Iran Job" has all the requisite elements of that cinematic subgenre, but strives for something deeper.
If you're a sober fan of Snoop Dogg's rap songs, as I am, you're in trouble.

It probably wasn't wise for the filmmakers to end Dirty Harry's reign with Eastwood uttering a post-killing line more suited for Stallone or Schwarzenegger, but from an entertainment standpoint, The Dead Pool doesn't leave one **** outta luck.
For a documentary filled with such joyous, danceable beats, there's still a note of sadness playing through Sample This.
Hearing the star of "Who's the Boss?" drop about 500 f-bombs is one of the film's few pleasures.
It's packaged in an easygoing 83 minutes that sometimes gets too cutesy for its own good but never wears out its welcome.
As exciting as getting a tow from AAA, and just as slow.

It may be the worst romantic comedy I have ever seen, and this is not hyperbole.

"About Last Night" surrenders its predecessor's ellipsis in its title, but thankfully retains the salty mouth and sexual shenanigans that mark it as an adaptation of David Mamet's "Sexual Perversity In Chicago".
It's too early for me to call this the worst movie of 2014, but it's certainly the worst thus far. Endless Love is an interminable mess.
Chinatown is deliciously, intolerably cruel as it toys with us.
My rowdy audience at Do The Right Thing did not cheer the riot, nor did one break out at the end. Like me, they left having seen a reflection of their own lives onscreen.
Her left me as empty as an unplugged monitor.
It broke my nostalgia, casting a gloomy dark cloud over my memories of "Rocky" and "Raging Bull." I didn't need to see this.
This is quite a good sports documentary, moving and unafraid of making you work for its pleasures.
Vince Vaughn can be a ray of sunshine in even the worst movies (see "Be Cool" for the best example of this). Here, I just didn't buy him as a loveable sad-sack.
I was frustrated to the point of rewinding the screener and pausing it so I could take in what was being described. In a theater, you won't have this luxury.
"The Best Man Holiday" has the potential to become a staple of Christmastime movie watching in the 'hood.
A very disjointed, confused, and sloppy movie.
Knoxville immerses himself in the role, radiating affection and concern for his charge. He's completely convincing, even during the most bizarre moments in "Bad Grandpa."

Sure to satisfy theater wonks, Sondheim fans, curious moviegoers and lovers of Broadway. All others need not apply.
movie_title: Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened... (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kevin Hart: What Now? is Kevin Hart at the top of his game. I just wish I had skipped the opening act the way I normally skip the previews.
An unflinching, well-informed and thoroughly researched look at the American system of incarceration, specifically how the prison industrial complex affects people of color.
Holm tweaks expectations with the way he presents the material, and his grip on the film's tricky, tragicomic tone is masterful.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Closet Monster is most successful when it uses fable-like qualities to allow us to feel Oscar's emotions viscerally rather than narratively.
After helming this, an episode of Roots and Best Picture-winner Driving Miss Daisy, Beresford should be forced to join 'Subservient Cinematic Negroes Anonymous.'
If you ever wanted to see a wartime movie that feels directed by a kinder, gentler Michael Bay, Come What May is right up your alley.
A lively, often hilarious collection of talking heads that includes fans and actors from the original and current incarnations of Star Trek.

Logic is dull and all that jazz. What isn't dull, though, is the way Branagh as a director attacks this material.

The ingrained self-hatred of its characters reflect outward toward those who remind them of themselves.
This is a smartly made movie that might win you over. I was pleasantly surprised, because there's something truly Spielbergian about it.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is a juicy, beach read of a movie, the kind of overstuffed story you'd devour in book form while slumming on the sand under an umbrella.
An irresistibly romantic and rousing success.
At 103 minutes, this film has way too much dead weight. Scenes are repeated over and over, and some of the acting would not cut it in a school play.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The committed performances by the cast of talented actors are what elevates Almost Christmas above complaints about its familiarity and melodrama.

Pineda is a great subject, and it's obvious he's the biggest fan of the man who co-wrote and sang most of his current repertoire.
One of the year's best films, and one that transcends the superhero genre to emerge as an epic of operatic proportions.
Something this sleazy should be a lot more fun.
"Proud Mary" doesn't deserve the lack of faith its studio has in it. In fact, it's almost good, so close to success that its flaws truly become frustrating.
Washington gives one of his rare bad performances here, turning Roman into an improv sketch filled with tics, mannerisms and an overreliance on his attire.
Director Dee Rees masterfully executes her character study, filling the frame with visuals as big and powerful as the emotions she draws from her superb cast.
Like Madea, Perry's getting away with attempted murder.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sea Sorrow gives us symbols, speeches and a sense of shame that, in more skillful hands, might have actually been effective.
In the dual roles inspired by Robert Louis Stevenson's classic monster tale, Huppert is superb.
Garrel and his screenwriter, the legendary Jean-Claude Carriere manage to cram a lot of philosophical ideas and concepts into the short running time, but I found myself caring less about them.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Some of the things I'd heard here would not leave me alone for days.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One of the year's best movies.
It's a surprise to discover a cerebral, 25-year-old film following the blueprint for today's endless glut of superhero movies.
It's sexy, fearless, fun and unrepentantly nasty.
The masterful thing about Denzel Washington's direction here is that he doesn't exactly open up the play. Instead, he opens up the visual frame around the players.
Theodore Melfi has a light touch not often found in dramas like this, which makes the material all the more effective.
It's clear Seagal is no longer limber enough to whip all the ass that's flung at him.

A powerful meditation on the origins of an African-American musical genre and the painful reasons for its existence.
"Weiner" is not afraid to take its subject behind the woodshed, and more often than not, he goes willingly.
To the filmmakers, Pastor Gennadiy Mokhnenko is a bit of a superhero. I found myself leaning that way too.
You're hearing some good stories told from the viewpoints of minor characters. This will hold your attention best if you are a "Star Wars" completist or a super-fan.
