Mia Madre feels cold, indifferent and at times condescending toward its protagonist.
These are universal subjects, so one does not have to be of Indian descent to appreciate "Meet the Patels." You'll either learn something new or nod your head with amused familiarity.
Men at Work is patient zero for the plague of Charlie Sheen movies that infected the 1990s.

This film is a little too on-the-nose in its automobile-as-freedom metaphors, but that didn't hurt my enjoyment. I found myself rooting for this small, quiet dramedy to succeed. For the most part, it does just fine.
Perhaps the wimpy ending is exactly what wishy-washy Will Henry deserved. I, on the other hand, deserved better.
If you're not a fan of N.W.A, you'll still find much to enjoy here. If you are a fan, you'll love this movie as much as I did.

The plot description is a good old-fashioned okey-doke, a distraction that lulls you with its absurdity so you'll be blindsided by the lean, suspenseful and effective movie director Jon Watts delivers.
"Call Me Lucky" will be an especially grueling ride for those who can identify with Crimmins' trauma. Yet its toughness does not at all diminish its worth. It remains an essential viewing experience.
"The Outrageous Sophie Tucker" is an outrageously dull documentary. This is not the subject's fault.
No matter how much it may adhere to the well-documented specifics of Zimbardo's work, it is a massive failure.
Quick Change requires a leap of faith from the audience.

The film scratches a lot of surfaces, never venturing too far down the interesting paths it divulges. However, what it does explore makes it a satisfying, lighthearted look at one man's search for perceived vocal machismo.
"Minions" is a big, slobbery dog who licks your face, brings your slippers and humps your leg before turning into an adorable kitten with big eyes and a soulful mew.
The true measure of a good tale is in the telling, and writer-director Noah Buschel spins his yarn in an unexpected, ultimately satisfying fashion.
The timeliness of What Happened, Miss Simone? cannot be understated. It's essential viewing in these times...
The throwback elements of "Fresh Dressed" are probably enough for most people to thoroughly enjoy the film. But nostalgia only gets you so far, and I hungered for more sustenance.
The film feels off-kilter more often than not, though it isn't without its inspired, successful moments.
As tedious as "Set Fire to the Stars" gets, it remains watchable courtesy of the stunning black and white cinematography by Chris Seager.
"Gemma Bovery" is all construction and snooty winks, no emotion. We really don't care what happens to Gemma or anybody else ...
...one can't help but surrender to the astonishing movie magic of The Walk's digitally recreated spectacle.
We're left with Mafiosi and l'amour fou, neither of which is as compelling as a mother's love.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film's heart is in the right place, but its focus is not.
For a lecture, it's pretty entertaining and informative.
Sometimes we need a good sermon, and like the best of sermons, "Barbershop: The Next Cut" dispenses its message with enough humor and wisdom to inspire and linger after it's done.
Something is off from the first scene.
If nothing else, I would have been happier with a film that did something unexpected with its technology. Gorgeous cinematography aside, this was a tough slog.
The predictability of its storytelling beats isn't really the problem, for there is comfort to be found in the dance of the familiar. The issue here is the tone of the material.
Horror ultimately gives way to irritation as the film veers into violent shock tactics and misplaced blame. What begins as a righteous indictment devolves into an unnecessary vendetta.
"Ip Man 3" is pretty much what you'd expect, but there's something extra special about an action movie that ends not on a moment of triumph but one of introspection.
I drove myself crazy trying to find purpose in this story. It plays like a thriller whose thrills have been edited out.
An early candidate for the 2016 worst movies list.
"Almost There" has some extraordinarily fine elements, but its big reveal destroyed all the goodwill it expected I would feel by film's end. Your mileage may vary.
"Hitchcock/Truffaut" offers a lot of ideas to contemplate and discuss, especially if you're a lover of Hitchcock's works.
This is one of the best films of 2015.
I wasn't a fan of the original film, but at least it made some semblance of sense and was decently acted.
...Carol comes off as a hollow exercise in style.
"70 Acres in Chicago: Cabrini Green" continues Bezalel's 20-year look at Cabrini Green, and one of the film's strengths is its casual depiction of the passage of time.
Director Jeffrey Schwarz has made an entertaining, fast-paced and informative film.
Any movie that begins and ends with the sound of a phonograph needle hitting vinyl knows the audience sweet spot it's aiming for, and for those folks, "All Things Must Pass" is a rousing success.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Folks will go to Bridge of Spies for [Tom] Hanks, but will stumble out stunned by [Mark] Rylance.
While the caper plot has its moments, I kept hoping "Trash" would do more than treat its setting as some curiously unexplainable foreign planet.
As a fan of De Palma's work-which doesn't mean I've liked all his movies-I found De Palma riveting.
This self-proclaimed Apple hater wasn't buying. But I admit the product still looks great.
A frenetic French action film that will either get your heart or your head pounding. This is a relentless genre exercise, both exhilarating and exhausting.
